headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forwa
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Forward-looking statements are made based on current expectations, assumptions and beliefs as well as information available to the company at this time. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from these anticipated. Further information about these risks can be found in the company's filings with the SEC. [Operator Instructions] 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Michael Schall, President and Chief Executive Officer for Essex Property Trust. Thank you, Mr. Schall. You may begin.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. I will cover the following topics on the call: first, comment on Q4 an
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. I will cover the following topics on the call: first, comment on Q4 and market conditions; and second, commentary on investment activities. 
On to the first topic. Yesterday, we were pleased to report continued strong operating results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 2015. In the fourth quarter, core FFO per share increased 17% compared to Q4 2014. For the full year, core FFO was $0.42 per share, above the midpoint of the initial 2015 guidance range. For the 5-year period from the 2010 recessionary trough, we have grown core FFO per share by 96%, increased our dividend nearly 7% per year and led the multi-family REIT industry with an annual total return of 19%. Angela Kleiman will comment on guidance in a moment, which anticipates continued strength into 2016. 
As widely reported, an anticipated slowdown in rent growth occurred in Q4 in Northern California. Third-party research firms have reacted by lowering rent growth and occupancy expectations for 2016. We believe that the Q4 slowdown does not materially change the 2016 outlook for Northern California for the following reasons. First, we believe that 2015 rent growth in Northern California was greater than anyone expected. I'd say 2015 was an extraordinary year. This context is important when comparing results because any disruption can appear disappointing. In this case, we expect to go from extraordinary in 2015 to strong in 2016 because the scenario that we outlined in our 2016 market forecast in connection with our Q3 2015 conference call, and we are now reaffirming that forecast. Specifically, we believe market rents will increase by 7.5% in Northern California in 2016, down from the 2015 average of 10.9%. 
Our second comment relates to the typical seasonality in Q4, which, in my 30 years at Essex, always occurs, although at varying intensity. Demand driven by job growth moderated in Q4, which is typical as many companies wait until after the holidays to add workers. New apartment deliveries will also vary throughout the year, and so above-average deliveries in Q4, along with lower demand can cause temporary softness until demand recovers, typically by early February. We estimate that Q4 deliveries of apartments in Northern California represented about 44% of the roughly 10,000 apartments delivered in all of 2015 versus 35% and 25% in Q4 of '14 and '13, respectively. John Burkart will summarize January results in a moment, given his confidence that the Q4 slowdown is not indicative of a trend. 
Our final point relates to our estimation of excess demand relative to supply in 2016. In our market forecast, again unchanged from last quarter, we project the 3 Bay Area counties to generate 2.9% job growth in 2016, significantly lower but still strong relative to the extraordinary job growth of 4.1% for the comparable metros in 2015. That 2.9% Bay Area job growth equates to around 95,000 jobs. Those 95,000 jobs will produce demand for around 47,000 housing units, assuming the typical 2 for 1 relationship between jobs and housing demand. In 2016, we expect the Bay Area to produce around 18,000 homes, both apartment and for sale, which represent only 38% of the demand attributable to job growth. With market occupancy around 96%, expensive single-family homes and demand well in excess of supply, we believe that great price and power will continue in 2016.
Rental affordability is often mentioned as a possible cause to lower rent growth. However, these are high-income and high-cost areas, and fortunately, incomes in the Bay Area are growing substantially. San Jose, for example, has a median household income of around $102,000, and personal incomes grew by 7.3% in 2014 and are estimated to increase 6.5% and 7.1% in 2015 and 2016, respectively. In Santa Clara County, which includes San Jose, monthly rents in the Essex portfolio average around $2,500 as compared to median rents in San Jose of around $2,200. The median income will allow someone without a roommate to rent the either the average Essex apartment or the medium price apartment in the metro area. 
Nothing in this discussion should imply that we lack concern about the U.S. economy, recent market volatility or the resilient fee of tech jobs, all of which are risks to our market outlook. If economic conditions worsen, we may not be able to achieve the macro assumptions driving our forecast, including 2.8% U.S. GDP growth and 2% U.S. job growth. We see nothing in our markets that would indicate that tech jobs are imploding. To the contrary, the tech markets continued to do well, as indicated by San Jose's 4.4% December over the December year-over-year job growth. Further, our analysis of the largest tech companies indicates that they are growing in market capitalization and generating huge amounts of cash. We would have thought 10 years ago that Alphabet and Google would be the world's largest-listed companies. A comparison of the top 10 U.S.-based tech companies against the top 10 nontech companies shows just how much the world has changed. The top 10 tech companies are worth around $2.8 trillion, 21% more than the nontechs, and have $556 billion in cash more than twice as much as the nontechs. Approximately $1.8 trillion of the equity capitalization of the tech leaders was created in the past 10 years over 3x the nontech. 
Finally, while only 3 of the nontech leaders are based in the Essex markets, all of the tech leaders are headquartered on the West Coast. We clearly don't see the end of large investment and technology in the foreseeable future and believe that our portfolio is well positioned for this continued growth. 
To the second topic, investment activity. So far, our acquisition markets have experienced little impact from global economic conditions. Cap rates have not moved much. At this point, A-quality property and locations created at around a 4.25 cap rate using the Essex methodology, but more aggressive buyers are often sub-4. B-quality property and locations typically have cap rates 25 to 50 basis points higher than A-quality property. 
We are seeing 3 significant headwinds affecting development in the West Coast markets, which we believe will moderate apartment supply going forward. First, construction lenders are sizing construction loans based on loan-to-cost ratios of between 60% to 65%, down about 5% from a few months ago. Second, cities continue to increase demand from developers in the form of low-income housing units, higher fees and costly improvement. Finally, construction costs have increased around 10% in each of the past 2 years despite declining commodity prices, as skilled labor forces are inadequate to meet related construction activity. Obviously, the slower housing supply is beneficial to the Essex portfolio overall. 
As previously announced, we sold the 296 units Sharon Green Apartments in Northern California for $245 million or $828,000 per unit and at a cap rate in the high 3% range. We used 10 31 exchanges to reinvest the proceed to Sharon Green into 3 properties that are detailed in the press release. We estimate that core FFO will increase by approximately $1 million in 2016 as a result of these transactions. 
Our business plan for investments is outlined in the press release. We hope that economic uncertainty will bring more transactions to the market and that financing rates will be attractive. Depending upon the stock price, acquisitions may be funded as part of our co-investment program or on our balance sheet. We currently have 2 properties in contract to be sold. Similarly, the use of proceeds from dispositions will also be strongly influenced by the stock price. 
That concludes my comments. Thank you for joining our call today. Now I'll turn the call over to John Burkart.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. 2015 was a great year in the West Coast markets. Our results exceeded our initial revenue guidance in all 3 regions for the combined Essex theory portfolio, and expenses were favorable to guidance leading to an exceptional 10.7% NOI growt
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. 2015 was a great year in the West Coast markets. Our results exceeded our initial revenue guidance in all 3 regions for the combined Essex theory portfolio, and expenses were favorable to guidance leading to an exceptional 10.7% NOI growth, the highest in 15 years. 
Our outperformance was attributable to job growth exceeding expectations and lower-than-expected housing supply. As of December 2015, our markets added 361,000 jobs compared to December 2014, 40 basis points higher than our original projection of 2.5%. A total of 63,000 new units of supply, both multi-family and single-family, was delivered into the markets in 2015. That's about 6,900 units below our original forecast largely for the reasons that Mike mentioned, including labor shortages, municipal delays, rising costs and more stringent letter underwriting. The supply-demand imbalance is the key factor behind our market strength. We estimate, assuming 2 jobs create one unit for housing, as the 331,000 jobs created is equivalent to about 165,000 units of housing demand compared to only 63,000 units of new supply delivered, meaning demand exceeded supply by over 2.5x. 
The fourth quarter, which is the low point seasonal demand and rental rate in our market, was relatively strong across all 3 regions, with a 7.5% increase in gross revenue compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. Achieved rent on new leases were up 8.6% in the fourth quarter compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. 
We have made great progress in our management of the BRE portfolio. However, we still have more work to do with respect to refining unit amenity pricing, lease expiration management and renovation. Therefore, for the purpose of comparable sequential results, the Essex legacy portfolio provides the best insight. Adjusted for occupancy changes, the Essex portfolio achieved 1.6% sequential revenue growth in the fourth quarter of 2015, the same as 2014. 
We continue to find opportunities with our renovation program. We increased the number of units renovated in the same-store portfolio, 143% from 254 units in the fourth quarter of 2014 to 618 units in the fourth quarter of 2015. The scope of the unit churn are site-specific based on opportunities in the marketplace. 
Now I will share some highlights for each region. The Seattle market continues to absorb new supply and push rents outside the CBD higher. Revenues for our Seattle CBD portfolio increased 5.3%, while revenue for the majority of our portfolio, which is located on the East side of Bellevue and Redmond, grew 8.3% for the fourth quarter compared to the prior year's quarter. According to AXIO, the Seattle market had the strongest year since the Great Recession, ended the year with approximately 8% year-over-year rental growth as of December 2015. 
In the Bay Area, the successful technology companies continue to lease or pursue space to grow their companies. The technology-driven San Francisco Peninsula and Silicon Valley market absorbed over 1 million square feet of space in each of the fourth quarter of 2015 or 50% of the total absorption for 2015. 
Also that leased space in Alameda, North San Jose Shoreline, [indiscernible], a division of [indiscernible] leased space in Bruno and Microsoft recently submitted plans for a new campus in Mountain View, with construction expected to begin next year. 
Southern California region continues to be strong, driven by solid job growth in each market. The 8.4% NOI growth rate achieved in 2015 was the highest in 15 years. We expect momentum we saw in 2015 to continue into 2016, given the limited new supply in the Southern California region, although we do expect some challenges in the Downtown L.A. as that local market absorbs the planned deliveries. Rental increases in the San Diego market have increased each year since 2010 and ended the year up 7% over the prior year according to AXIO. 
I'm pleased with our 2015 results, and although I recognize the real economic risks and concerns of the marketplace, the current conditions that we are experiencing in our market gives me confidence that we will achieve our plan outlined in the guidance. 
Our portfolio occupancy as of February 2 is at 96.1%, consistent with our budget. And our net availability out 30 days stand at 5.3%. We are positioned well to take advantage of the spring rental season. 
Looking forward into 2016, we again expect demand to substantially exceed supply in our markets by over 2x, leading to continued rental market strength. 
In January of 2016, our average achieved rent for new leases for our 3 regions was 2.4% above our achieved rent in December of 2015, consistent with our budget. 
I think our momentum positions us well for 2016. Thank you, and I will now turn the call over to Angela Kleiman.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Today, I will briefly review 2015 results then focus on 2016 guidance and provide a balance sheet update. For 2015, I'm pleased to report that our same-property revenue growth for the full year was 8%, which exceeded the midpoint of our gu
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Today, I will briefly review 2015 results then focus on 2016 guidance and provide a balance sheet update. 
For 2015, I'm pleased to report that our same-property revenue growth for the full year was 8%, which exceeded the midpoint of our guidance. Same-property revenue growth and NOI growth for the combined portfolio, which consists of the last 3 quarters of the year, was 7.6% and 10.1%, respectively. Both of these also exceeded the midpoint of our most recent guidance. 
On to 2016. We anticipate another strong year with 11% projected core FFO per share growth, primarily driven by same property gross assumptions. Our top line growth of 7% at the midpoint reflects our expectation of continued favorable supply/demand relationship. For reference, business point is 25 basis points higher than our initial guidance for 2015, which was 6.75%. 
We are projecting higher operating expense growth of 3.75% at the midpoint. Controllable expenses are expected to increase modestly at around 1% for the year. Therefore, the 2 key drivers to expense increase are as follows: first, higher utility costs. Know that 2015 utility cost increase was only 0.3%, so very muted, primarily due to water conservation. And second, an increase in our allocation to property management expense. This is consistent with what we've previously communicated. We will review this allocation on a regular basis in conjunction with our transformation plan. The new management fee allocation equates to 2.4% of revenues, which is less than 3% commonly used within the industry. The resulting bottom line is that we are expecting another strong year, with 8.5% NOI growth at the midpoint. 
As for G&A, the increase by 5% of the midpoint is primarily due to our new corporate headquarters lease. The offset to this expense as discussed in a previous call this the yield from reinvesting the proceeds from the sale of our former Palo Alto headquarters. Thereby, the resulting net impact [indiscernible] $0.01 per share. 
For the first quarter this year, we are projecting core FFO per share at the midpoint to be $0.03 below fourth quarter of last year. The reduction is attributed to onetime items such as favorable variance in the fourth quarter and property tax with the legacy BRE portfolio, generating $0.04 of core FFO per share. In addition, we have recently sold several properties, including Sharon Green, and have not fully redeployed its proceeds. The result is $0.01 per share drag on the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter last year. 
Other assumptions to our guidance can be found on Page 5 of the press release and S-14 of the supplemental. 
Moving on to the balance sheet. We repaid $150 million of private placement bonds in January and have assumed an unsecured bond offering in our guidance for 2016. The only noteworthy maturity remaining in 2016 is the $200 million term loan in the fourth quarter. We have several options available to refinance this debt, which allows us to be opportunistic. 
We generally favor refinancing majorities with unsecured debt that is 5- to 10-year in terms depending on the interest rate curve and the related spreads. 
Lastly, we are ahead of our scheduled in reducing our net debt-to-EBITDA to 5.8x due to substantial growth in EBITDA. Based on recent $215 stock price, our leverage from debt-to-market cap is at 27%. 
In comparison, heading into the great '08 recession, our leverage was 35% at the end of 2007. Therefore, with our $1 billion line of credit extended to 2021, unfunded commitments of $230 million, which is below 3% of total market cap and with a light maturity schedule over the next several years, we are well positioned to be opportunistic and to weather any substantial capital market dislocation. 
That concludes my remarks, and I will now turn the call over to the operator for questions.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kris Trafton from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kris Trafton from Credit Suisse.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the same-store revenue growth guidance. Looks like you're modeling about 100 basis point decrease in the revenue and growth rate. But since 2015 rent growth was about 70 basis points higher than 2014, would it
componenttext: I just wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the same-store revenue growth guidance. Looks like you're modeling about 100 basis point decrease in the revenue and growth rate. But since 2015 rent growth was about 70 basis points higher than 2014, would it be safe to assume that maybe there's 50-or-so basis points in higher loss to lease their? And then I appreciate the San Francisco slowdown, but does that really gets all the way down to the revenue growth rate guidance that you have for '16?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kris, this is Mike, and if I miss a piece of your question, please correct me. But our general thesis has been that Northern California is obviously the strongest market for a long time and Seattle right behind it. But over time, we expect that Southern C
componenttext: Kris, this is Mike, and if I miss a piece of your question, please correct me. But our general thesis has been that Northern California is obviously the strongest market for a long time and Seattle right behind it. But over time, we expect that Southern California to slowly improve while Northern California, which was hitting this double-digit NOI growth rates, would slowly decline. I think there we're still anticipating that process to occur, although the resiliency in the tech markets has been a little bit surprising to us, obviously, a positive surprise. And so I think the numbers this year we have -- again, to go to the forecast, the market forecast, we have Northern California at about 7.5%, and our guidance is marginally higher than that. And so we are expecting a little bit of loss-to-lease usage. That will be the delta in the 2 different numbers. So does that make sense as it relates to Northern Cal?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. It just seems that, that would imply pretty strong slowdown, given the lost lease is higher this time this year then versus some time last year.
componenttext: Great. It just seems that, that would imply pretty strong slowdown, given the lost lease is higher this time this year then versus some time last year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it was at the end of the year, loss-to-lease was 2.8%. And so it decelerated a lot in Q4. Of course, Q4 was a dip, and it is higher at the end of January than it was at the end of December. Again, you have the impact of what we think happened again
componenttext: Well, it was at the end of the year, loss-to-lease was 2.8%. And so it decelerated a lot in Q4. Of course, Q4 was a dip, and it is higher at the end of January than it was at the end of December. Again, you have the impact of what we think happened again as I mentioned in my comments. We had lumpy supply hitting the market in Q4 in Northern California. And when that happens, some people are trying to lease up their apartment buildings, becoming more aggressive with respect to concessions and/or rent levels. And when that happens, everyone else adjusts along with it. And again, this is within a period that you always have lower demand for a variety of reasons. And so you have lower demand. You have too much hitting the marketplace, and owners reacting very aggressively. I think that, that, as John Burkart pointed, out has largely the run the course because now demand has returned to normal levels. Some of those lease-ups have adjusted in price. And as a result of world looks, I could say, more or less on track for what we thought was going to happen. So again, from my perspective, the fourth quarter is the lease relevant quarter. And I know seems like the analysts focus on it many times over the last 10 years. And I think that they give it too much weight in terms of the overall relevance of the quarter. It's the least relevant. Things can happen is that of the slowdown of demand, and I think that's what happened this year, and it's happened many times before.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then second, it looks like there's going to be a strong net acquirer next year or 2 [ph]. And even though you have near-historical low cost of capital and private valuation and apartment haven't probably peaked yet, [indiscerni
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then second, it looks like there's going to be a strong net acquirer next year or 2 [ph]. And even though you have near-historical low cost of capital and private valuation and apartment haven't probably peaked yet, [indiscernible] expense is this mostly a function of your implied cap rate relative to your price relative to NAV? And then, I guess, generally what's the rationale for being the strong net buyer this year when peers kind of across the board or having that pillars?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're going to be a more aggressive seller and a more aggressive, not a more aggressive buyer, we're going to be consistent on the buy side, and we're going to be more aggressive seller. The question is how we fund that activity. And we have a co-
componenttext: I think we're going to be a more aggressive seller and a more aggressive, not a more aggressive buyer, we're going to be consistent on the buy side, and we're going to be more aggressive seller. The question is how we fund that activity. And we have a co-investment program that if we don't like the stock price, in other words, if we think the stock price implied return is higher than the asset that we buy, we're obviously not going to issue the stock in order to buy it. So we're going into a co-investment-type function. I think, as we look back at many years of doing this, we do best when there's a disruption in the marketplace. And assets can sometimes be mispriced. And if that happens, we went to be ready to do so. Again, I think the chances of exactly where we're funded change everyday, change with the stock price based on today's price. Obviously, we would not be excited about using our stock. But if you go back 3 months, our stock price and the market in general have been all over the place. And we can't tell you what's going to happen in the future. We just recognize that it's a very volatile period of time, and I guess, we would ask people to trust us to make wise decisions with respect to how we conduct ourselves in the investment markets. It is possible that they will do nearly that much in acquisitions if we can't find transactions and relative to our cost of capital that makes sense.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico with UBS.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I think at one point, you'd said back in November when you were looking at the sale of Sharon Green, you're contemplating -- contemplated doing a stock buyback, and instead, you went to 10 31 acquisition route. I mean, looking at your stock today, i
componenttext: Mike, I think at one point, you'd said back in November when you were looking at the sale of Sharon Green, you're contemplating -- contemplated doing a stock buyback, and instead, you went to 10 31 acquisition route. I mean, looking at your stock today, it's lower than November. And presumably, you would still go out and do a sizable disposition and potentially buy back your stock. I mean, how are you thinking about that today?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Nick. The answer is we can't possibly predict. It's all over the place. And it's hard to run the business and enter into transactions to take, what, 60 days to close and expect anything with respect to your stock price. As it rela
componenttext: That's a great question, Nick. The answer is we can't possibly predict. It's all over the place. And it's hard to run the business and enter into transactions to take, what, 60 days to close and expect anything with respect to your stock price. As it relates to Sharon Green, you're right. Originally, we had intended to 10 31 exchange around 2/3 of the proceeds, pull forward the dividend in order to create the money that we could use for stock buyback. We changed the plan when the stock was in the 2 30 to 2 40 range and decided to 10 31 exchange everything. But that demonstrates how we think about the world. We try to again make good decisions with our eye focused on building NAV per share, and building cash flow per share. And it's worked out for us really well over a lot of years, and we'll continue doing that doing forward. But to your point, it is incredibly difficult to plan exactly what we're going to do when the world is changing so much. And I would say the same thing is true with respect to our guidance. We issued our market forecast last quarter. Many may argue that the prospects for GDP growth are not nearly as good today as they were just a couple of months ago, but the reality is, who knows? We're using a number that economy.com, the 2.8% GDP growth, with the expectation that the economy will improve, improve as we go through 2016. But the reality is we don't know that either. We try to, again be -- react to the business, keep our eyes focused on the transaction activity out there and then make the decisions. We expect this to be a challenging year from the perspective of uncertainty and volatility. And again, I think that we generally do well in that type of environment, certainly, with respect to transaction because things can become more mispriced and/or they're -- it could cause sellers, for example -- the uncertainty can often cause sellers to become more interested in selling, so maybe we'll see more transactions at the marketplace. I know on the development side, the construction side, there are cost increases and other factors of cost development deals to not pencil the way the developers had hoped that they would pencil. And that could lead to some other opportunities in that area. Again, I don't know what's going to happen this year. And to any greater extent, there's so much volatility out there, but we think that the have produced the scenario that makes sense, given the broader environment. And we will see what happens.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: If you're talking year-over-year, not in '16, not likely. This is John Burkart, I should say. headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of maybe the relative strength in Southern California versus the moderation in Northern California, would you expect, without giving 2017 guidance, would you expect them to meet somewhere in between? Or would you expect Northern Californ
componenttext: And then in terms of maybe the relative strength in Southern California versus the moderation in Northern California, would you expect, without giving 2017 guidance, would you expect them to meet somewhere in between? Or would you expect Northern California to come down towards Southern California is or conversely the other way?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, this is Michael Schall. Now you're going to the unknowables, obviously, when you get into 2017. That's far enough away that it's difficult to see that far because the world is changing, as you know, rather quickly. But I will say that the point that
componenttext: Nick, this is Michael Schall. Now you're going to the unknowables, obviously, when you get into 2017. That's far enough away that it's difficult to see that far because the world is changing, as you know, rather quickly. But I will say that the point that I made in my comments about what is the impact of, well, this incredible wealth has been created by Alphabet and I think I said Google. I meant Apple in my comments. The tremendous amount of cash is there. The wealth has been created, et cetera. What is the long-term impact of that on the marketplace if you look out 2 or 3 years? And we don't know the answer to that. We think it's pretty positive. And as an example, we can cite what happened when Bill Gates decided to move Microsoft to Seattle and really form that business in the Seattle market. I think it transformed Seattle in ways that we can't really understand. There are books that are written about this and we talked about them before. But again, this incredible wealth generation will increase economic activity, we know that. It will bring the best and brightest people into the marketplaces. And those that own these companies will reinvest those funds in ways that are generally very, very good for the economy. So that is part of the equation that's difficult to predict if you get beyond 2017 and '18, although I wouldn't count the tech market of the out of the ballgame with respect to growth rate in '17 and '18 because of this factor. Again, it's hard to understand it exactly right now, but looking at Seattle as an example, I think you'll see continued development in these markets for a longer period of time.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I mean, typically, loss-to-lease will peak in July, and the number will be roughly half in December what it was in July. So last July, it was around 7 to 8. I think it was 8. And so you would expect December to be around 4, and it
componenttext: That's a good question. I mean, typically, loss-to-lease will peak in July, and the number will be roughly half in December what it was in July. So last July, it was around 7 to 8. I think it was 8. And so you would expect December to be around 4, and it was 2.8. So it was a little bit less, but again, we attribute that to the unique factors that occurred in Q4. I don't think that, that's a normal deviation. So -- but I would expect another good year, and I think that we will peak in loss-to-lease probably in July, and somewhere around 7% is what I would guess.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Greg Van Winkle of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Greg Van Winkle of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. We tend to be a little bit conservative and try to be thoughtful in how we're looking at the world. And so yes, 2015 was an exceptional year, no question about it. We think 2016 will be very strong. We've laid out the numbers as far as job g
componenttext: This is John. We tend to be a little bit conservative and try to be thoughtful in how we're looking at the world. And so yes, 2015 was an exceptional year, no question about it. We think 2016 will be very strong. We've laid out the numbers as far as job growth, and supply in the market is still very supply-constrained. So we do expect 2016 to be a very good year. And I think it's very positive. We're not anticipating that market slowing down. Its doing very well right now.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then been there in the center of the tech world in San Francisco. I'm curious what your thoughts are on AirBNB. We're seeing some of your competitors start to discuss partnering with them. And I'm curious whether you're viewing AirBNB as
componenttext: Okay, great. And then been there in the center of the tech world in San Francisco. I'm curious what your thoughts are on AirBNB. We're seeing some of your competitors start to discuss partnering with them. And I'm curious whether you're viewing AirBNB as a potential opportunity at this point or more of a threat or just something you just I disfigure out?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- this is John again. With AirBNB or any of these sharing economies entities, what they're trying to accomplish is really deal with one of their issues, which is probably addition of the leases to sublet space. So a lot of it discussion peop
componenttext: Yes, I think -- this is John again. With AirBNB or any of these sharing economies entities, what they're trying to accomplish is really deal with one of their issues, which is probably addition of the leases to sublet space. So a lot of it discussion people are think that they're try to move apartments into hotel situations, and that's not really the case, at least not what I've seen or heard. It's really not our -- we try to work with the landlords, the landlords to allow their residents to, under certain circumstances, move forward and sublet some space. And that concept is an exchange for a very small fee to the landlord. That is really their goal. From my perspective, there's a couple of issues out there that are pretty important, which includes with municipalities that commonly forbid this. So that would be another issue. And really the biggest issue is our resident satisfaction for our current residents. And so weighing a relatively small fee versus the precedent satisfaction of impact of the quality of life to our residents really doesn't seem like a program that would make sense. We're aware of these things were watching the states, but I don't think it's something that you guys see anyone jump into in a big way.

componenttext: And kind of a similar light, I guess, given the credit market disruptions and then you mentioned even some supply challengers in downtown L.A. Is that -- are you seeing developers bring market, bring assets to market just looking to kind of unload today amid some of the disruptions?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mike again. We just don't see that much transaction volume out there of the properties that we want to own. There are transactions. If you look at the broader transaction markets, there are plenty of real estate trade in hand, but we tend to be very
componenttext: It's Mike again. We just don't see that much transaction volume out there of the properties that we want to own. There are transactions. If you look at the broader transaction markets, there are plenty of real estate trade in hand, but we tend to be very focused on more of the urban and the higher-quality suburban areas, suburban transit, for example, areas. And so we're very selective. And those -- that product does not come to market often. And what it does, we're obviously very excited about it. So again, it's hard to anticipate exactly what is going to happen, given all this disruption. We hope for a more active transaction market going forward. And if we find that, then you can expect us to be pretty active. But we just don't know at this point.

componenttext: Have the unique drivers that you described in Northern Cal that drove the rent weakness in 4Q '15 already reversed in January? Or is it too early to tell?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. Let me give you some insight there. I'm going to give you some rents here. This is year-over-year rent so you can get a feel for what was going on there. So in November, our achieved rents on new leases were up about 10.4% in Northern C
componenttext: Yes, this is John. Let me give you some insight there. I'm going to give you some rents here. This is year-over-year rent so you can get a feel for what was going on there. So in November, our achieved rents on new leases were up about 10.4% in Northern California. In December, that number dropped to 4.9%, and that's what everyone has noted. In January, we went back up to 8.9%. So January turned around. It was much better for us in Northern California, and those rents in January, of course, are above December rents and above year-over-year significantly. It's a little early to tell at this point in time because again, there's still not a lot of transactions that go on in November, December, and January. But what we're seeing is very positive. It's consistent with our plan for the year, and we feel good about things.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I -- let me just interject for second. Sorry about that. But consider, again, I think a lot of it was supply-driven, a lot of supply hitting the market in December and move outs by homes. I think there was a piece of that in the with Fed interest rate
componenttext: Can I -- let me just interject for second. Sorry about that. But consider, again, I think a lot of it was supply-driven, a lot of supply hitting the market in December and move outs by homes. I think there was a piece of that in the with Fed interest rate increases, more people went out and bought a home. And so we have more move-outs to buy homes. So there were a number of supply factors, again, hitting in the seasonally lowest demand period. So it makes sense. What John said, I think, makes total sense that there was a relatively sharp snapback as soon as those conditions normalized.

componenttext: Yes, this is John Burkart. I'll talk about the lease estimate, and then I'll have John talk about the starts. But on the lease-ups, what we saw really a tale of 2 stories. We have the MB360 where we continue to power on with a highly some philosophy. In that particular case, we lowered our net effective rent a little bit to keep velocity. In Epic, we kept that a little bit higher. We had a Phase 1 and Phase 2 leasing out of the same building. And in that case, we are velocity went down a little bit. But again, all of this is according to plan. So overall, we finished up the 1 South Market lease-up in the quarter. Epic, we're very close. We're over 90%. And MB360 is playing a long, as you can see. The concern that people have, certainly share of we read the papers and we listen reached out on off a lot of people, and of course, including the managers that are running the lease-ups and had good conversations with all of them. And their view was this was really consistent with seasonal issues, with some level of -- as far as demand goes, and then the supply impacting the rents. So hopefully that helps. And I'll let John talk about planned development.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Hi. It's John Eudy. We anticipate 3 starts this year around roughly mid-$400 million or $500 million range, all 3 of which have order land costs and a settlement costs that were prior to the big spike that we've seen in the last 1.5 years. We're going to be facing the current construction cost, of course, but because of our bases is as much lower, that's why the starts makes sense. And that is a if I adoptable transact on the same deals today or at least over the last 6 months, with current land prices fees transactions in the cities, we probably wouldn't be able to do the deals. Hence, we have what we have in the box, and we anticipate it happening by end of the year.

componenttext: Okay, okay. The total return swap and the refinancing on that? Essentially, it was to lower our interest rates. It's $1.4 million of savings. componenttext: Actually, the structure itself is more simplified. And so if you want we can talk a little bit more after the call. But this is [indiscernible] plus 70, and the other one was a Fannie credit-enhanced. So the trade-off in terms of structure is not more complex.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, this is John. From the BRE perspective as far as the legacy portfolio, we've certainly come a long way. As I mentioned in my remarks, some of the opportunities we still have going forward, specifically with that portfolio relating to amenity re
componenttext: Sure. Yes, this is John. From the BRE perspective as far as the legacy portfolio, we've certainly come a long way. As I mentioned in my remarks, some of the opportunities we still have going forward, specifically with that portfolio relating to amenity refi and the amenity adjustments and expirations. And the expirations have yet been commented on several times, but for clarity, clearly we could fix that. It was in a 12-month period as the lease expires, It's [indiscernible] into a certain bucket. The problem is it's not the best thing to do economically. Typically, you're better to work through that over a couple of year period and not force people to take actions that are inconsistent with the market. So we just tried to move it on the margin, and that's what we're doing. As it relates to the amenity adjustment, that takes several years to get right and, frankly, on the FX legacy side, we're still refining that as well, trying to really connect with how the market perceives the different valuation of our similar unit types and makes adjustments as an ongoing effort at our company. It just needed a lot more work on the BRE side as they really just started that revenue management process. On the big picture, on the expense side, things aren't pretty good quarter there. We now have the BRE portfolio, legacy portfolio, performing on a controllable expense basis, admin and those types of expenses on a per-unit basis, below the Essex portfolio, and that makes sense that portfolio in several newer than ours. And so we've a lot of work and we have that in very good order. From a management perspective, we have great people, and that is completely intermixed throughout the portfolio. So there is no Essex or BRE assets there. All Essex assets and how we manage them is almost exactly the same as a few new ones that are getting cleaned up. But basically, almost 100% the same. So that's come a long way, and we're very pleased with where that's that. On the renovations, the last piece, that these takes on again, our renovation program was pretty focused on making sure our product meets the market exactly. It's a very asset-by-asset program. And so we mentioned that the of launched it, which we have. 2016 will have a greater focus on the BRE portfolio as a percentage, then move on to the Essex portfolio and a switch from this last year. And we'll continue to explore those opportunities. Hopefully, that answers the question.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a few questions here. First, Mike, I appreciate your comments on tech and the jobs out there in your opening remarks. And looking -- I guess what was a little surprising is looking at your job forecast of the latest one in your sub today versus the one
componenttext: So a few questions here. First, Mike, I appreciate your comments on tech and the jobs out there in your opening remarks. And looking -- I guess what was a little surprising is looking at your job forecast of the latest one in your sub today versus the one a year ago, the job growth forecasts are sort of similar. And yet, obviously, the news headlines today are clearly fresher than they were a year ago, but Twitter, Yahoo!, you see some of these companies that are in the news, whether for business model issues or space giveback on their office use. I'm just trying to reconcile the two. What would be the things that you guys would look for that would tell you something is happening, a red flag out there that would tell you that things may be changing? Because the outlook that you gave in your job picture is a bit different than sort of a sentiment if you read the newspapers or speak to folks, not your folks, but speak to the that's on this side of the country.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex, it's Mike. Yes, I mean, the one point that we pretty dramatically outperformed the job forecast last year. So yes, this year, as a forecast, it's pretty similar to last year, but you have the large outperformance in the middle of that, which we
componenttext: Yes, Alex, it's Mike. Yes, I mean, the one point that we pretty dramatically outperformed the job forecast last year. So yes, this year, as a forecast, it's pretty similar to last year, but you have the large outperformance in the middle of that, which we didn't expect, obviously. So we're going back to what we consider to be a more sustainable job forecast. And so going forward, how do we detect the things are different from plan? We would use our own portfolio as being a primary source. Typically, what happens in the portfolio when you look at 30-day affordability and some of the other portfolio metrics, you would see dislocation happening more quickly than the data vendors will pick it up generally by 1 or 2 months. So we would generally see that hiccup happening right in the rental activity and affordability. So we'd look for that, and that'll be the primary trigger to focus more effort on what's going on. In terms of what we're most concerned about, a lot of people talk about the unicorns out there. And we're less concerned about them, more concerned about the large tech companies because when you look at the number of employees, it's pretty dramatically different. Again, back to our top 10 tech public companies. There's about -- they have about 165,000 employees in the Bay Area, whereas the top 20 unicorns have about 11,000 employees in the Bay Area. So we are clearly more concerned about the top 10 or the big tech companies, but we're also -- on the flipside, we also recognize that they have such tremendous financial capabilities, again, the amount of cash that they have, the amount of growth that they've generated, the office space that they are leasing and the overall commercial activity. There's nothing to us that appears to be a hiccup in what their activities are, and that is what's really driving or anchoring our forecast for next year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, I just want to address your comment about office space because we saw the same thing, which was Google and Apple. They were pulling back in their office lease in the East Coast. But when we looked at the big picture, we also recognized that they exp
componenttext: Alex, I just want to address your comment about office space because we saw the same thing, which was Google and Apple. They were pulling back in their office lease in the East Coast. But when we looked at the big picture, we also recognized that they expanded their office space here, close to headquarters. So there's been a conscious decision to try to be more centralized. But net office space concerns, they have not decreased than they have been. The news about Yahoo! laying off 700 [ph] employees. But what we also saw was Sony PlayStation entertainment moving to headquarters from Japan to San Mateo and expanding, obviously, the office needs and which will bring in another what we would expect 700 to 800 or hiring 700 to 800 new employees. [indiscernible] contact.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Angela, I appreciate that. The second question is you guys -- one of the 10 31 properties was Downtown L.A. You guys have been investing in Downtime L.A. for quite some time. So just sort of curious, now that you've had a number of properties there,
componenttext: Okay, Angela, I appreciate that. The second question is you guys -- one of the 10 31 properties was Downtown L.A. You guys have been investing in Downtime L.A. for quite some time. So just sort of curious, now that you've had a number of properties there, how do you view that the properties have been performing relative to your underwriting?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, it's Mike. They performed generally in line with our underwriting. There is a pretty significant amount of supply coming into the Downtown. And from our perspective, that's going to require people that are working in the Downtown but living somewher
componenttext: Alex, it's Mike. They performed generally in line with our underwriting. There is a pretty significant amount of supply coming into the Downtown. And from our perspective, that's going to require people that are working in the Downtown but living somewhere else to relocate to the Downtown. And we expect that to be somewhat choppy. But the overall supply/demand of L.A. is incredibly positive to us. Los Angeles County produces somewhere around 0.5% or 0.6% of its stock every year. And it's getting -- demand growth that is well in excess of that, but that supply is focused really on the CBD LA as that transitions from being a sleepy downtown to being a 24-hour city. And we believe that, that is on track, and we believe that the long haul our long-term potential is fantastic in that marketplace, even though there might be some bumps along the way.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim Sullivan with Cowen & Company.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Mike, at the risk of beating this dead horse on the demand forecast, just to make sure I understand, in your prepared comments, I think you mentioned economy.com as the source of, I guess, as the U.S. GDP forecast assumption and the national job growth assumption. For the individual markets, is that data also economy.com? Or is that based on your own research or some other local research source you look at?

componenttext: Do you mean the job forecast by market?

componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Or the economic forecast?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the job forecast by market. And I understood you to say that the economy.com forecast was both job and GDP. Is that now right?
componenttext: Well, the job forecast by market. And I understood you to say that the economy.com forecast was both job and GDP. Is that now right?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really is a -- we use a variety of data vendors. And again, we prepared this forecast last quarter. So the world was a little bit different then. And we can go through the process of changing the forecast dramatically, but the reality is the world is c
componenttext: It really is a -- we use a variety of data vendors. And again, we prepared this forecast last quarter. So the world was a little bit different then. And we can go through the process of changing the forecast dramatically, but the reality is the world is changing so rapidly that you can't change the forecast every month, which would almost be necessary based on the amount of volatility we've had in the marketplace. But what our process is, is we use the macro data for the broad macro numbers, which is U.S. GDP growth and U.S. job growth, and then we drive the more specific market forecast based on our own supply/demand analysis. And Angela has come up with a regression analysis that takes into account various different factors, including both supply and demand. It includes wage growth, for example, as one of the key items or affordability. And so the economic rent growth in our market forecast is Essex proprietary, but it's driven by macro numbers that come from data providers. I think 2.8% is the highest of the data providers, as I recall. Looking at the list, there are some in the 1.5% range. Again, we could change this on an ongoing basis, but to what point? I think that the forecast looks achievable. If you look at last year, we missed the GDP forecast but outperformed on the job side. So is this a perfect science? Obviously, it's not. And it seems like we had resilience on the job growth side relative to historical relationships. And again, I think it goes back to that wealth incredible -- wealth creation that we've had on the West Coast that is really driving economic activity that is disconnecting from a lot of the data going back 5 or 10 years. So I think a lot of things are happening. It seems to us that these are achievable numbers. And again, we'll see. We expect the volatile years. I know everyone knows.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Well, again, we use data providers to give us the list of transactions, and then, inevitably, you have the same project called 3 different things. And so you try to go through and identify, just what our team does, we try to go through and we identify where each project is. And then based on that, we eliminate the duplication in the data, and we think we get a much better forecast as a result of that than a lot of the data providers have. We excluded from this student housing, senior housing and some of the other categories and others, including their data as well, as historically that has not proven that relevant to our overall activity.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike. It's a great question. Again, let's put this in the unknowable category. And when it comes to the unknowables, I have to go back and maybe summarize what I've seen in the last 30 years as it relates to Northern California. And I've seen huge
componenttext: This is Mike. It's a great question. Again, let's put this in the unknowable category. And when it comes to the unknowables, I have to go back and maybe summarize what I've seen in the last 30 years as it relates to Northern California. And I've seen huge dislocation and disruption. Obviously, the Internet period was an incredible period in terms of that. And for example, you had, I think price-to-sales ratios were something like 49x in year 2000, and they're more like 7 now. So you had an incredible asset bubble with respect to these tech companies, and that went on for a lot longer than anyone expected it to go one and ultimately had a horrific effect of things. I think that, that really is the exception, though. When you look at 2007, 2008 -- 2008, 2009 recession, actually, the tech world did rather well. It was construction, government, manufacturing, except for they did incredibly poorly and thank everything. I think that that's actually more of my belief with respect to the tech world. It's not necessarily the tech world that tends to be so volatile in terms of employment. It's the broader economy. So I don't have necessarily any great fear about tech itself. I have fear about just generally what's happening in the economy because, I think, actually, tech, with the one notable exception of the Internet boom and bust period, the tech has actually done reasonably well during economic cycles and the downturns.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd ask, where else are you going to go? So I mean, what are you -- you can spend cash at 20 basis points or something like that. But I mean, as we look at the industries and what's happening in the world, it seems like tech is actually pretty wel
componenttext: I guess I'd ask, where else are you going to go? So I mean, what are you -- you can spend cash at 20 basis points or something like that. But I mean, as we look at the industries and what's happening in the world, it seems like tech is actually pretty well positioned relative to some of the other choices. We know that Southern California, for example, is a more diversified economy and, therefore, will have less dislocation, but again, not the same growth rate either. So if we see significant dislocation in the tech markets, we will obviously try to move more the portfolio southward. There is a small bias toward that, as you saw in the Sharon Green transaction, where we sell Northern California and we reinvest 2/3 Northern California, 1/3 Southern California. I think you will continue to see some of that happen. But again, we're not in a mindset that we need to divest of tech -- the tech market.

componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Mike. And Keith is still here. I talked him this morning. He asked what happened to his $240 stock price. Keith is always with us. Again, it goes back to that relationship between asset values and the stock price. And that has been changing see
componenttext: Rich, it's Mike. And Keith is still here. I talked him this morning. He asked what happened to his $240 stock price. Keith is always with us. Again, it goes back to that relationship between asset values and the stock price. And that has been changing seemingly everyday, and we sure would like to see some consistency in stock price before we make big strategic decisions. And unfortunately, that's probably not going to happen this year. And so we will look for opportunities, much like Sharon Green Apartments, where we think we can sell an asset and the either by the stock back or pay a special dividend. Both of them are potentially attractive to us. And we want to see some meaningful pickup in terms of impact on NAV per share. So today, that is probably there, but it wasn't there last week. And again, the trend -- it takes, what, 60 to 90 days to actually go through the transaction process. And then you have got to work through the reinvestment plan. So we're trying to do the best we can. I will tell you that we will sell more assets this year than we've sold for the last several years. And I think that, that will continue to trend. And we'll look for both really 2 different things: one, pairing off the assets that we think will underperform over the longer period, which will probably be in the higher cap rate type of area, but then the more opportunistic, much like Sharon Green, after the at a attractive, very aggressive cap rates that we can redeploying the positive spreads. So we'll be looking at those.

componenttext: That's always the case. We're always concerned that we're missing something. And I'll say, in the fourth quarter, there were more move-outs to buy homes, and that caused some availability increase. Again, I think a lot of it was tied to the said action and the belief that you need to get into a house now as opposed to wait, which turned out to probably be the wrong answer. But that 30-day availability has really been the bedrock of our management of both price and where the market is going. And it's a pretty sensitive variable, and I think it captures appropriately what's going on in the marketplace. So we're going to pay particular attention to that. And then if that moves, then the next position -- next point is, hey, is this a onetime only? Or is it a trend? And so we'll be trying to figure that out right after there's some move-out in that area. As John has indicated, January bounced back so nicely that we don't think that what happened in Q4 is anything other than an isolated occurrence.

componenttextpreview: As you've discussed on the call, Mike, I think that Essex has earned a reputation as one that will adjust as needed to the change in cost of capital. But just have a couple of questions on specific things that I'd like to understand how you think about co
componenttext: As you've discussed on the call, Mike, I think that Essex has earned a reputation as one that will adjust as needed to the change in cost of capital. But just have a couple of questions on specific things that I'd like to understand how you think about couple of specific things. The first is I think that you suggested that if the stock price is unfavorable, you would shift away from wholly-owned acquisitions and more towards a co-investment. But how do you think about co-investments relative to just making no acquisitions at all?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, we have to be able to add per-share growth, NAV and cash flow to the portfolio. And I don't know if we've shared with you, but we have an accretion model that we run for every deal that tries to measure those against the portfolio. And again, we're t
componenttext: Hey, we have to be able to add per-share growth, NAV and cash flow to the portfolio. And I don't know if we've shared with you, but we have an accretion model that we run for every deal that tries to measure those against the portfolio. And again, we're trying to add value to the stock, not to track value from the stock. And our process is really designed around that. And so we do not feel compelled to do transactions just for the sake of doing transactions. And we certainly don't feel compelled to do transactions for "strategic reasons." We want to make deals that make sense and that are additive to shareholder value over the long haul. And that -- we started all the way back to 1995, 1996. We talked about what our long-term goals were, and they are as relevant today as they were back then. And we said basically, "Hey, if we can grow effectively what's core FFO versus FFO back then, at somewhere around 8% or 9% a year and pay a dividends that's in the 4% or 5% range, that's going to be a really great thing for shareholders." And we've stayed true to that, and we've added a little bit of NAV sensitivity to it as well. But that's what makes these entities do well over the long haul. And as you know, it's worked out pretty well for shareholders and us.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Second question, it just relates to the logistics of hypothetically selling assets and buying back stock. Would you -- if you were to tee up assets for sale and you have maybe have some confidence in the private market, would you take that private
componenttext: Great. Second question, it just relates to the logistics of hypothetically selling assets and buying back stock. Would you -- if you were to tee up assets for sale and you have maybe have some confidence in the private market, would you take that private market risk and buy back stock immediately? Or would you weigh the 60-ish days that it takes to close, have the cash on hand and then buy back the stock? How do you think about those decisions?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't like them, Dave, to answer your question, because the transaction market again, they're all over the place. And the ability to close, with all the variables are making it risky. But then again, we've seen this with the Sharon Green transaction wh
componenttext: We don't like them, Dave, to answer your question, because the transaction market again, they're all over the place. And the ability to close, with all the variables are making it risky. But then again, we've seen this with the Sharon Green transaction where roughly 2/3, we were going to exchange and we're going to pull a dividend forward and do -- buy some stock back if we saw some weakness there. And that was on the table for about 10 seconds and then off the table. So it's really incredibly challenging thing to do that matches off in a way that is additive to the shareholders. Fortunately, Angela, it's her job to make that happen. Angela, you and add anything to that? Hey, it's challenging. One of the most difficult things, I think, we've had to do this year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the only thing that I would add is yes, I agree that this is challenging. But we can't move generally pretty quickly and when you do have a very flexible balance sheet. So we have a track record of doing the right thing, and we're going to c
componenttext: Well, I think the only thing that I would add is yes, I agree that this is challenging. But we can't move generally pretty quickly and when you do have a very flexible balance sheet. So we have a track record of doing the right thing, and we're going to continue doing that.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, but on that specific point, it sounds like it's fluid. You don't have a hard fast rule that you have to weigh the cash in the door before you go buy back the stock. You evaluate it on a case-by-case basis.
componenttext: Understood, but on that specific point, it sounds like it's fluid. You don't have a hard fast rule that you have to weigh the cash in the door before you go buy back the stock. You evaluate it on a case-by-case basis.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's magnitude, right, Dave? I mean, if cap rates go up 100 basis points and the stock goes down, then you're compelled to do it, and you feel like, hey, under any scenario, we're going to be able to capture that difference in valuation. If the magnitud
componenttext: That's magnitude, right, Dave? I mean, if cap rates go up 100 basis points and the stock goes down, then you're compelled to do it, and you feel like, hey, under any scenario, we're going to be able to capture that difference in valuation. If the magnitudes are relatively thin, then why would you take the risk? The risk becomes more apparent. So it's a question that really doesn't have an answer. We do not have any preset biases. As you know, we try to be pretty thoughtful about looking at things and keeping risk in mind and not do things just because the common wisdom is to do them, but rather do things because we can add value to them. And so again, it's going to be case-by-case, it will be an interesting year. And I hope the stock does well, but if it doesn't, we'll come up with another plan. I can assure you that.
