headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. And as a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are f
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. And as a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Forward-looking statements are made based on current expectations, assumptions and beliefs as well as information available to the company at this time. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from these anticipated. Further information about these risks can be found in the company's filings with the SEC. [Operator Instructions] 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Michael Schall, President and Chief Executive Officer for Essex Property Trust. Thank you, Mr. Schall. You may begin.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. I will cover the following topics on the call: first, comment on Q4 an
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. I will cover the following topics on the call: first, comment on Q4 and market conditions; and second, commentary on investment activities. 
On to the first topic. Yesterday, we were pleased to report continued strong operating results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 2015. In the fourth quarter, core FFO per share increased 17% compared to Q4 2014. For the full year, core FFO was $0.42 per share, above the midpoint of the initial 2015 guidance range. For the 5-year period, from the 2010 recessionary trough, we have grown core FFO per share by 96%, increased our dividend nearly 7% per year and led the multifamily REIT industry with an annual total return of 19%. Angela Kleiman will comment on guidance in a moment, which anticipates continued strength into 2016. 
As widely reported, an unanticipated slowdown in rent growth occurred in Q4 in Northern California. Third-party research firms have reacted by lowering rent growth and occupancy expectations for 2016. We believe that the Q4 slowdown does not materially change the 2016 outlook for Northern California for the following reasons. First, we believe that 2015 rent growth in Northern California was greater than anyone expected. I'd say, 2015 was an extraordinary year. This context is important when comparing results because any disruption can appear disappointing. In this case, we expect to go from extraordinary in 2015 to strong in 2016, which is the scenario that we outlined in our 2016 market forecast in connection with our Q3 2015 conference call, and we are now reaffirming that forecast. Specifically, we believe market rents will increase by 7.5% in Northern California in 2016, down from the 2015 average of 10.9%. 
Our second comment relates to the typical seasonality in Q4, which, in my 30 years at Essex, always occurs, although at varying intensity. Demand driven by job growth moderated in Q4, which is typical as many companies wait until after the holidays to add workers. New apartment deliveries will also vary throughout the year, and so above-average deliveries in Q4, along with lower demand, can cause temporary softness until demand recovers, typically by early February. We estimate that Q4 deliveries of apartments in Northern California represented about 44% of the roughly 10,000 apartments delivered in all of 2015 versus 35% and 25% in Q4 '14 and '13, respectively. John Burkart will summarize January results in a moment, given his confidence that the Q4 slowdown is not indicative of a trend.
Our final point relates to our estimation of excess demand relative to supply in 2016. In our market forecast, again unchanged from last quarter, we project the 3 Bay Area counties to generate 2.9% job growth in 2016, significantly lower but still strong relative to the extraordinary job growth of 4.1% for the comparable metros in 2015. That 2.9% Bay Area job growth equates to around 95,000 jobs. Those 95,000 jobs will produce demand for around 47,000 housing units, assuming the typical 2-for-1 relationship between jobs and housing demand. In 2016, we expect the Bay Area to produce around 18,000 homes, both apartments and for sale, which represent only 38% of the demand attributable to job growth. With market occupancy around 96%, expensive single-family homes and demand well in excess of supply, we believe that great pricing power will continue in 2016.
Rental affordability is often mentioned as a possible cause for lower rent growth. However, these are high-income and high-cost areas, and fortunately, incomes in the Bay Area are growing substantially. San Jose, for example, has a median household income of around $102,000 and personal incomes grew by 7.3% in 2014 and are estimated to increase 6.5% and 7.1% in 2015 and 2016, respectively. In Santa Clara County, which includes San Jose, monthly rents in the Essex portfolio average around $2,500 as compared to median rents in San Jose of around $2,200. The median income will allow someone without a roommate to rent either the average Essex apartment or the medium price apartment in the metro area. 
Nothing in this discussion should imply that we lack concern about the U.S. economy, recent market volatility or the resiliency of tech jobs, all of which are a risk to our market outlook. If economic conditions worsen, we may not be able to achieve the macro assumptions driving our forecast, including 2.8% U.S. GDP growth and 2% U.S. job growth. We see nothing in our markets that would indicate that tech jobs are imploding. To the contrary, the tech markets continued to do well, as indicated by San Jose's 4.4% December over the -- December year-over-year job growth. Further, our analysis of the largest tech companies indicates that they are growing in market capitalization and generating huge amounts of cash. Who would have thought 10 years ago that Alphabet and Google would be the world's largest listed companies.
A comparison of the top 10 U.S.-based tech companies against the top 10 non-tech companies shows just how much the world has changed. The top 10 tech companies are worth around $2.8 trillion, 21% more than the nontechs, and have $556 billion in cash more than twice as much as the nontechs. Approximately $1.8 trillion of the equity capitalization of the tech leaders was created in the past 10 years, over 3x the nontech. 
Finally, while only 3 of the non-tech leaders are based in the Essex market, all of the tech leaders are headquartered on the West Coast. We clearly don't see the end of large investments in technology in the foreseeable future and believe that our portfolio is well positioned for this continued growth. 
To the second topic, investment activity. So far, acquisition markets have experienced little impact from global economic conditions. Cap rates have not moved much. At this point, A-quality property and locations trade at around a 4 1/4 cap rate using the Essex methodology, but more aggressive buyers are often sub-4. B-quality property and locations typically have cap rates 25 to 50 basis points higher than A-quality property.
We are seeing 3 significant headwinds affecting development in the West Coast markets, which we believe will moderate apartment supply going forward. First, construction lenders are sizing construction loans based on loan-to-cost ratios of between 60% to 65%, down about 5% from a few months ago. Second, cities continue to increase demands from developers in the form of low-income housing units, higher fees and costly improvement. Finally, construction costs have increased around 10% in each of the past 2 years, despite declining commodity prices as skilled labor forces are inadequate to meet related construction activity. Obviously, the slower housing supply is beneficial to the Essex portfolio overall. 
As previously announced, we sold the 296-unit Sharon Green Apartments in Northern California for $245 million or $828,000 per unit and at a cap rate in the high 3% range. We used 1031 exchanges to reinvest the proceed to Sharon Green into 3 properties that are detailed in the press release. We estimate that core FFO will increase by approximately $1 million in 2016 as a result of these transactions. 
Our business plan for investments is outlined in the press release. We hope that economic uncertainty will bring more transactions to the market and that financing rates will be attractive. Depending upon the stock price, acquisitions may be funded as part of our co-investment program or on our balance sheet. We currently have 2 properties in contract to be sold. Similarly, the use of proceeds from dispositions will also be strongly influenced by the stock price. 
That concludes my comments. Thank you for joining our call today. Now, I'll turn the call over to John Burkart.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. 2015 is a great year in the West Coast market. Our results exceeded our initial revenue guidance in all 3 regions for the combined Essex BRE portfolio, and expenses were favorable to guidance, leading to an exceptional 10.7% NOI growth, t
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. 2015 is a great year in the West Coast market. Our results exceeded our initial revenue guidance in all 3 regions for the combined Essex BRE portfolio, and expenses were favorable to guidance, leading to an exceptional 10.7% NOI growth, the highest in 15 years. 
Our outperformance was attributable to job growth exceeding expectations and lower-than-expected housing supply. As of December 2015, our markets added 361,000 jobs compared to December 2014, 40 basis points higher than our original projection at 2.5%. A total of 63,000 new units of supply, both multifamily and single-family, was delivered into the markets in 2015. That's about 6,900 units below our original forecast, largely for the reasons that Mike mentioned, including labor shortages, municipal delays, rising costs and more stringent lender underwriting. The supply-demand imbalance is the key factor behind our market's strength. We estimate, assuming 2 jobs create 1 unit demand for housing, that the 331,000 jobs created is equivalent to about 165,000 units of housing demand compared to only 63,000 units of new supply delivered, meaning demand exceeded supply by over 2.5x. 
The fourth quarter, which is the low point seasonal demand and rental rate in our market, was relatively strong across all 3 regions, with a 7.5% increase in gross revenue compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. Achieved rent on new leases were up 8.6% in the fourth quarter compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. 
We've made great progress in our management of the BRE portfolio. However, we still have more work to do with respect to refining unit, amenity pricing, lease expiration management and renovation. Therefore, for the purpose of comparable sequential results, the Essex legacy portfolio provides the best insight. Adjusted for occupancy changes, the Essex portfolio achieved 1.6% sequential revenue growth in the fourth quarter of 2015, the same as 2014. 
We continue to find opportunities with our renovation program. We increased the number of units renovated in the same-store portfolio, 143% from 254 units in the fourth quarter of 2014 to 618 units in the fourth quarter of 2015. The scope of the unit churn are site-specific based on opportunities in the marketplace. 
Now I will share some highlights for each region. The Seattle market continues to absorb new supply and push rents outside the CBD higher. Revenues for our Seattle CBD portfolio increased 5.3%, while revenue for the majority of our portfolio, which is located on the east side near Bellevue and Redmond, grew 8.3% for the fourth quarter compared to the prior year's quarter.
According to AXIO, the Seattle market had the strongest year since the Great Recession, ended the year with approximately 8% year-over-year rental growth as of December 2015. 
In the Bay Area, the successful technology companies continue to lease or pursue space to grow their company. The technology-driven San Francisco Peninsula and Silicon Valley markets absorbed over 1 million square feet of space in each of the -- in each -- in the fourth quarter of 2015 or 50% of the total absorption for 2015.
Alphabet leased space in Alameda, North San Jose, Shoreline. YouTube, a division of Alphabet, leased space in San Bruno. And Microsoft recently submitted plans for a new campus in Mountain View, with construction expected to begin next year. 
Southern California region continues to be strong, driven by solid job growth in each market. The 8.4% NOI growth rate achieved in 2015 was the highest in 15 years. We expect momentum we saw in 2015 to continue into 2016, given the limited new supply in the Southern California region, although we do expect some challenges in the Downtown L.A. as that local market absorbs the planned deliveries. Rental increases in the San Diego market have increased each year since 2010 and ended the year up 7% over the prior year, according to AXIO. 
I'm pleased with our 2015 results. And although I recognize the real economic risks and concerns in the marketplace, the current conditions that we are experiencing in our market gives me confidence that we will achieve our plan outlined in the guidance. 
Our portfolio occupancy as of February 2 is at 96.1%, consistent with our budget. And our net availability of 30 days stands at 5.3%. We are positioned well to take advantage of the spring rental season. 
Looking forward into 2016, we again expect demand to substantially exceed supply in our markets by over 2x, leading to continued rental market strength. In January of 2016, our average achieved rent for new leases for our 3 regions was 2.4% above our achieved rent in December of 2015, consistent with our budget. I think our momentum positions us well for 2016.
Thank you, and I will now turn the call over to Angela Kleiman.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Today, I will briefly review 2015 results, then focus on 2016 guidance and provide a balance sheet update. For 2015, I'm pleased to report that our same-property revenue growth for the full year was 8%, which exceeded the midpoint of our g
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Today, I will briefly review 2015 results, then focus on 2016 guidance and provide a balance sheet update. 
For 2015, I'm pleased to report that our same-property revenue growth for the full year was 8%, which exceeded the midpoint of our guidance. Same-property revenue growth and NOI growth for the combined portfolio, which consists of the last 3 quarters of the year, was 7.6% and 10.1%, respectively. Both of these also exceeded the midpoint of our most recent guidance. 
On to 2016. We anticipate another strong year with 11% projected core FFO per share growth, primarily driven by same-property growth assumptions. Our top line growth of 7% at the midpoint reflects our expectation of continued favorable supply/demand relationship. For reference, business volume is 25 basis points higher than our initial guidance for 2015, which was 6.75%. 
We are projecting higher operating expense growth of 3.75% at the midpoint. Controllable expenses are expected to increase modestly at around 1% for the year. Therefore, the 2 key drivers to expense increase are as follows: first, higher utility costs. Know that 2015 utility cost increase was only 0.3%. So very muted, primarily due to water conservation. And second, an increase in our allocation to property management expense. This is consistent with what we've previously communicated. We will review this allocation on a regular basis in conjunction with our transformation plan. The new management fee allocation equates to 2.4% of revenues, which is less than 3% commonly used within the industry. The resulting bottom line is that we are expecting another strong year, with 8.5% NOI growth at the midpoint. 
As for G&A, the increase by 5% of the midpoint is primarily due to our new corporate headquarters lease. To offset to this expense as discussed on a previous call, is the yield from reinvesting the proceeds from the sale of our former Palo Alto headquarters. Thereby, the resulting net impact to FFO is $0.01 per share. 
For the first quarter this year, we are projecting core FFO per share at the midpoint to be $0.03 below fourth quarter of last year. The reduction is attributed to onetime items such as favorable variance in the fourth quarter and property tax for the legacy BRE portfolio, generating $0.04 of core FFO per share. In addition, we have recently sold several properties, including Sharon Green, that have not fully redeployed its proceeds. The result is $0.01 per share drag on the first quarter compared to the fourth quarter of last year. 
Other assumptions to our guidance can be found on Page 5 of the press release and S-14 of the supplemental. 
Moving on to the balance sheet. We repaid $150 million of private placement bonds in January and have assumed an unsecured bond offering in our guidance for 2016. The only noteworthy maturity remaining in 2016 is the $200 million term loan in the fourth quarter. We have several options available to refinance this debt, which allows us to be opportunistic. 
We generally favor refinancing of maturities with unsecured debt that is 5- to 10-year in terms depending on the interest rate curve and the related spreads. 
Lastly, we are ahead of our scheduled in reducing our net debt-to-EBITDA to 5.8x due to substantial growth in EBITDA. Based on recent $215 stock price, our leverage from debt-to-market cap is at 27%. 
In comparison, heading into the great '08 recession, our leverage was 35% at the end of 2007. Therefore, with $1 billion line of credit extended to 2021, unfunded commitments of $230 million, which is below 3% of total market cap and with a light maturity schedule over the next several years, we are well positioned to be opportunistic and to weather any substantial capital market dislocation. 
That concludes my remarks, and I will now turn the call over to the operator for questions.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the same-store revenue growth guidance. Looks like you're modeling about 100 basis point decrease in the revenue growth rate. But since 2015 rent growth was about 70 basis points higher than 2014, would it be safe to assume that maybe there's 50-or-so basis points in higher loss to lease their? And then appreciate the at San Francisco slowdown, but does that really gets all the way down to the revenue growth rate guidance that you have for '16?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Kris. This is Mike. And if I missed a piece of your question, please, go ahead and correct me. But our general thesis has been that Northern California has obviously been the strongest market for a long time and Seattle right behind it. But over time,
componenttext: Hi, Kris. This is Mike. And if I missed a piece of your question, please, go ahead and correct me. But our general thesis has been that Northern California has obviously been the strongest market for a long time and Seattle right behind it. But over time, we expected Southern California to slowly improve while Northern California, which was hitting these double-digit NOI growth rates, would slowly decline. I think that we're still anticipating that process to occur, although the resiliency in the tech markets has been a little bit surprising to us, obviously, a positive surprise. And so I think the numbers this year we have -- again, to go to the forecast, the market forecast, we have Northern California at about 7.5%, and our guidance is marginally higher than that. And so we are expecting a little bit of a loss to lease usage. That will be the delta in the 2 different numbers. So does that make sense as it relates to Northern Cal?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It just seems like that would imply pretty strong slowdown, given that the loss to lease is higher this time this year than versus some time last year.
componenttext: Right. It just seems like that would imply pretty strong slowdown, given that the loss to lease is higher this time this year than versus some time last year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it was at the end of the year, loss to lease was 2.8%. And so it decelerated a lot in Q4. Of course, Q4 was a dip, and it is higher at the end of January than it was at the end of December. Again, you have the impact of what we think happened again,
componenttext: Well, it was at the end of the year, loss to lease was 2.8%. And so it decelerated a lot in Q4. Of course, Q4 was a dip, and it is higher at the end of January than it was at the end of December. Again, you have the impact of what we think happened again, as I mentioned in my comments, we had lumpy supply hitting the market in Q4 in Northern California. And when that happens, some people are trying to lease-up their apartment buildings, becoming more aggressive with respect to concessions and/or rent levels. And when that happens, everyone else adjusts along with it. And again, this is within a period that you always have lower demand for a variety of reasons. And so you have lower demand. You have too much hitting the marketplace, and owners reacting very aggressively. I think that, that, as John Burkart have pointed out is largely the run the course because now demand has returned to normal levels. Some of those lease-ups have adjusted in price. And as a result of what it looks like, it's more or less on track for what we thought was going to happen. So again, from my perspective, the fourth quarter is the least relevant quarter. And I know seems like the analysts focus on it many times over the last 10 years. And I think that they give it too much weight in terms of the overall relevance of the quarter. It's the least relevant. Things can happen just given the slowdown in demand. And I think that's what happened this year, and it's happened many times before.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then second, it looks like you're going to be a strong net acquirer next year, too. And even though you have near-historical low cost of capital and private valuations in apartment haven't probably peaked yet, valuations are st
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then second, it looks like you're going to be a strong net acquirer next year, too. And even though you have near-historical low cost of capital and private valuations in apartment haven't probably peaked yet, valuations are still pretty expense and just -- is this mostly a function of your implied cap rate relative -- price relative to NAV? And then I guess, generally, what's the rationale for being strong net buyer this year when peers kind of across the board are having that pillars?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're going to be a more aggressive seller and a more aggressive -- well, not a more aggressive buyer. We're going to be consistent on the buy side, and we're going to be a more aggressive seller. The question is, how we fund that activity. And so
componenttext: I think we're going to be a more aggressive seller and a more aggressive -- well, not a more aggressive buyer. We're going to be consistent on the buy side, and we're going to be a more aggressive seller. The question is, how we fund that activity. And so we have a co-investment program that if we don't like the stock price, in other words, if we think the stock price implied return is higher than the asset that we buy, we're obviously not going to issue the stock in order to buy it. So we will go into a co-investment-type function. I think, as I look back at many years of doing this, we do best when there's a disruption in the marketplace. And assets can sometimes be mispriced. And if that happens, we want to be ready to do so. Again, I think the chances of exactly where we fund it change everyday, change with the stock price. Based on today's price, obviously, we would not be excited about using our stock. But if you go back 3 months, our stock price and the market in general have been all over the place. And we can't tell you what's going to happen in the future. We just recognize that it's a very volatile period of time, and I guess, we would ask people to trust us to make wise decisions with respect to how we conduct ourselves in the investment markets. It is possible that we won't do nearly that much in acquisitions, if we can't find transactions relative to our cost of capital that makes sense.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico with UBS.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I think at one point, you'd said that back in November when you were looking at the sale of Sharon Green, you contemplating -- contemplated doing a stock buyback, and instead, you went to 1031 acquisition route. I mean, looking at your stock today,
componenttext: Mike, I think at one point, you'd said that back in November when you were looking at the sale of Sharon Green, you contemplating -- contemplated doing a stock buyback, and instead, you went to 1031 acquisition route. I mean, looking at your stock today, it's lower than November. And presumably, you would still go out and do a sizable disposition and potentially buy back your stock. I mean, how are you thinking about that today?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Nick. The answer is we can't possibly predict. It's all over the place. And it's hard to run a business and enter into transactions that take, what, 60 days to close and expect anything with respect to your stock price. As it rela
componenttext: That's a great question, Nick. The answer is we can't possibly predict. It's all over the place. And it's hard to run a business and enter into transactions that take, what, 60 days to close and expect anything with respect to your stock price. As it relates to Sharon Green, you're right. Originally, we had intended to 1031 exchange around 2/3 of the proceeds, pull forward a dividend in order to create some money that we could use for a stock buyback. We changed the plan when the stock was in the $230 to $240 range and decided to 1031 exchange everything. But that demonstrates how we think about the world. We try to, again, make good decisions with our eye focused on building NAV per share and building cash flow per share. And it's worked out for us really well over a lot of years, and we'll continue doing that doing forward. But to your point, it is incredibly difficult to plan exactly what we're going to do when the world is changing so much. And I would say the same thing is true with respect to our guidance. We issued our market forecast last quarter. Many may argue that the prospects for GDP growth are not nearly as good today as they were just a couple of months ago, but the reality is, who knows? We're using the numbers at economy.com, the 2.8% GDP growth, with the expectation that the economy will improve as we go through 2016. But the reality is we don't know that either. We try to, again, be -- react to the business, keep our eyes focused on the transaction activity out there and then make the decisions. We expect this to be a challenging year from the perspective of uncertainty and volatility. And again, I think that we generally do well in that type of environment, certainly with respect to transaction because things tend to become mispriced and/or they're -- it could cause sellers, for example -- the uncertainty can often cause sellers to become more interested in selling. So maybe we'll see more transactions at the marketplace. I know on the development side, construction side, there are cost increases and other factors have caused development deals to not pencil the way that developers had hoped that they would pencil. And that could lead to some other opportunities in that area. Again, I don't know what's going to happen this year. And to any greater extent, there's so much volatility out there. But we think that we have produced this scenario that makes sense, given the broader environment. And we will see what happens.

componenttext: And then in terms of maybe the relative strength of Southern California versus the moderation in Northern California, would you expect -- without giving 2017 guidance, would you expect them to meet somewhere in between? Or would you expect Northern California to come down to where Southern California is or conversely the other way?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Nick. This is Mike Schall. Now you're going to the unknowables, obviously, when you get into 2017. That's far enough away that it's difficult to see that far because the world is changing, as you know, rather quickly. But I will say that the point th
componenttext: Hey, Nick. This is Mike Schall. Now you're going to the unknowables, obviously, when you get into 2017. That's far enough away that it's difficult to see that far because the world is changing, as you know, rather quickly. But I will say that the point that I made in my comments about what is the impact of, well, this incredible wealth has been created by Alphabet. And I think I said Google. I meant Apple in my comments. The tremendous amount of cash is there. The wealth has been created, et cetera. What is the long-term impact of that on the marketplace if you look out 2 or 3 years? And we don't know the answer to that. We think it's pretty positive. And as an example, we can cite what happened when Bill Gates decided to move Microsoft to Seattle and really formed that business in the Seattle market, I think it transformed Seattle in ways that we can't really understand. There are books that are written about this, and we've talked about them before. But again, this incredible wealth generation will increase economic activity. We know that. It will bring the best and brightest people into the marketplaces. And those that own these companies will reinvest those funds in ways that are generally very, very good for the economy. So that is part of the equation that's difficult to predict, if you get beyond 2017 and '18, although I wouldn't count the tech market out of the ballgame with respect to growth rate in '17 and '18 because of this factor. Again, it's hard to understand it exactly right now. But looking at Seattle as an example, I think you'll see continued development in these markets for a longer period of time.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just you talked about the loss to lease in the portfolio. So if 2016 plays out how guidance in your market growth assumptions assume, what would you expect the loss-to-lease of the portfolio to be at the end of 2016?

componenttext: That's a good question. I mean, typically, loss to lease will peak in July, and the number will be roughly half in December what it was in July. So last July, it was around 7 to 8. I think it was 8. And so you would expect December to be around 4, and it was 2.8. So it was a little bit less, but again, we attribute that to the unique factors that occurred in Q4. I don't think that, that's a normal deviation. So -- but I would expect another good year, and I think that we will peak in loss to lease, probably in July, and somewhere around 7% is what I would guess.

componenttext: This is John. We tend to be a little bit conservative and try to be thoughtful in how we're looking at the world. And so yes, 2015 was an exceptional year, no question about it. We think 2016 will be very strong. We've laid out the numbers as far as job growth, and supply in the market is still very supply-constrained. So we do expect 2016 to be a very good year. And I think it's very positive. We're not anticipating that market slowing down. Its doing very well right now.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then been there in the center of the tech world in San Francisco. I'm curious what your thoughts are on Airbnb. We're seeing some of your competitors start to discuss partnering with them. And I'm just curious whether you're viewing Airbn
componenttext: Okay, great. And then been there in the center of the tech world in San Francisco. I'm curious what your thoughts are on Airbnb. We're seeing some of your competitors start to discuss partnering with them. And I'm just curious whether you're viewing Airbnb as a potential opportunity at this point or more of a threat or just something you just I disfigure out?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- this is John again. With Airbnb or any of these sharing economies entities, what they're trying to accomplish is really deal with one of their issues, which is the prohibition in the leases to sublet space. So a lot of the discussion peopl
componenttext: Yes, I think -- this is John again. With Airbnb or any of these sharing economies entities, what they're trying to accomplish is really deal with one of their issues, which is the prohibition in the leases to sublet space. So a lot of the discussion people -- I think people think that they're trying to move the apartments into hotel-type situations, and that's not really the case, or at least not what I've seen or heard. It's really a matter of trying to work with the landlords. Of course, the landlords do allow their residents to, under certain circumstances, move forward and sublet some space. And that concept is an exchange for a very small fee to the landlord. That is really their goal. From my perspective, there's a couple of issues out there that are pretty important, which includes in municipalities who commonly forbid this. So that would be another issue. And really the biggest issue is our resident satisfaction for our current residents. And so weighing a relatively small fee versus the precedent satisfaction of the impact of the quality of life to our residents really doesn't seem like a program that would make sense. We're aware of these things. We watch these things, but it's I don't think it's something that you're going to see anyone jump into in a big way.

componenttext: Yes, this is Mike, Austin. Yes, we are. It's one of the areas that we're looking at. In the development area, we all know that there's permits that are being pulled. And those, generally speaking, do not meet our underwriting criteria for -- to get us excited about a development. But we are looking at some of them as it relates to a joint venture-type opportunity, which could include potentially a mezz-type of transaction. So yes, definitely something we're looking at.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in kind of a similar light, I guess, given the credit market disruptions and then you mentioned even some supply challengers in L.A. Is that -- are you seeing developers bring market, bring assets to market just looking to kind of unload today am
componenttext: And then in kind of a similar light, I guess, given the credit market disruptions and then you mentioned even some supply challengers in L.A. Is that -- are you seeing developers bring market, bring assets to market just looking to kind of unload today amid some of the disruptions?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mike again. We just don't see that much transaction volume out there of the properties that we want to own. There are transactions. If you look at the broader transaction markets, there are plenty of real estate be trade in hand, but we tend to be ve
componenttext: It's Mike again. We just don't see that much transaction volume out there of the properties that we want to own. There are transactions. If you look at the broader transaction markets, there are plenty of real estate be trade in hand, but we tend to be very focused on more of the urban and the higher-quality suburban areas, suburban transit, for example, areas. And so we're very selective. And those -- that product does not come to market often. And what it does, we're obviously very excited about it. So again, it's hard to anticipate exactly what is going to happen, given all this disruption. We hope for a more active transaction market going forward. And if we find that, then you can expect us to be pretty active. But we just don't know at this point.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Hi, Jana, it's Mike. No, we're not. We have identified the markets that we want to be in, and we're going to stay focused on them. And I think the -- our reputation as a local sharpshooter is important to us. And anything outside of our existing markets would be viewed as a deviation from the plan. So no, we're not looking at anything else.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Have the unique drivers that you described in Northern Cal that drove the rent weakness in 4Q '15 already reversed in January? Or is it too early to tell?
componenttext: Have the unique drivers that you described in Northern Cal that drove the rent weakness in 4Q '15 already reversed in January? Or is it too early to tell?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. Let me give you just some insight there. I'm going to give you some rents here. This is year-over-year rent so you can get a feel for what was going on there. So in November, our achieved rents on new leases were up about 10.4% in North
componenttext: Yes, this is John. Let me give you just some insight there. I'm going to give you some rents here. This is year-over-year rent so you can get a feel for what was going on there. So in November, our achieved rents on new leases were up about 10.4% in Northern California. In December, that number dropped to 4.9%, and that's what everyone has noted. In January, we went back up to 8.9%. So January turned around and was much better for us in Northern California. And those rents in January, of course, are above December rents and above year-over-year significantly. It's a little early to tell at this point in time, because, again, there's still not a lot of transactions that go on in November, December, and January. But what we're seeing is very positive. It's consistent with our plan for the year, and we feel good about things.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would you say January is back to normal seasonality? Or is it a sharper snapback?
componenttext: Would you say January is back to normal seasonality? Or is it a sharper snapback?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it was a sharper snapback, really nearing the drop in December.
componenttext: No, it was a sharper snapback, really nearing the drop in December.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I -- let me just interject for a second. Sorry about that. But consider, again, I think a lot of it was supply driven, a lot of supply hitting the market in December and move-outs to buy homes. I think there was a piece of that in that. With Fed inter
componenttext: Can I -- let me just interject for a second. Sorry about that. But consider, again, I think a lot of it was supply driven, a lot of supply hitting the market in December and move-outs to buy homes. I think there was a piece of that in that. With Fed interest rate increases, more people went out and bought a home. And so we have more move-outs to buy homes. So there were a number of supply factors, again, hitting in the seasonally lowest demand period. So it makes sense. What John said, I think, makes total sense that there was a relatively sharp snapback as soon as those conditions normalized.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just lastly, can you talk about any trends you saw in your current lease-ups and give us any details on your planned new starts for this year?
componenttext: That's helpful. And just lastly, can you talk about any trends you saw in your current lease-ups and give us any details on your planned new starts for this year?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John Burkart. I'll talk about the lease estimate, and I'll have John talk about the starts. But on the lease-ups, what we saw really a tale of 2 stories. We have the MB360, where we continue to power on with a highly lease-up velocity. In tha
componenttext: Yes, this is John Burkart. I'll talk about the lease estimate, and I'll have John talk about the starts. But on the lease-ups, what we saw really a tale of 2 stories. We have the MB360, where we continue to power on with a highly lease-up velocity. In that particular case, we lowered our net effective rents a little bit to keep velocity. In Epic, we kept rents a little bit higher. We had a Phase 1 and Phase 2 leasing out of the same building. And in that case, we -- our velocity went down a little bit. But again, all of this is according to plan. So overall, we finished up the 1 South Market lease-up in the quarter. Epic, we're very close. We're over 90%. And MB360 is playing along, as you can see. The concern that people had, certainly share, we read the papers and we listen, reached out to an awful lot of people, and of course, including the managers that are running the lease-ups and had good conversations with all of them. And their view was this is really consistent with seasonal issues, with some level of -- as far as demand goes, and then the supply impacting the rents. So hopefully that helps. And I'll let John talk about planned development.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi. It's John Eudy. We anticipate 3 starts this year, around roughly mid-$400 million to $500 million range, all 3 of which have order land costs and entitlement costs that were prior to the big spike that we've seen in the last 1.5 years. We are going to
componenttext: Hi. It's John Eudy. We anticipate 3 starts this year, around roughly mid-$400 million to $500 million range, all 3 of which have order land costs and entitlement costs that were prior to the big spike that we've seen in the last 1.5 years. We are going to be facing the current construction cost, of course, but because of our basis is much lower, that's why the starts make sense. I can say if I was out to go transact on the same deals today or at least over the last 6 months, with current land prices and fees, exactions from the cities, we probably wouldn't be able to do the deals. Hence, we have what we have in the box, and we anticipate it happening by end of the year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Can you tell us which markets they're in and what your expected deals are?

componenttext:
,
Sure. One is in the Southern California, in a prime market. One is in Silicon Valley and a property that you're probably aware that we bought out of bankruptcy and right after the 2010 meltdown at a very low land basis. And then the other one is in Northern California, in a Ground Zero location.

componenttext: Okay, okay. The total return swap and the refinancing on that. Essentially, it just -- it was to lower our interest rates. It's $1.4 million of savings. The $4.3 million noncash write-off was essentially the -- on the amortized loan fees. So it was just an economical decision that was in our favor in terms of the cost of debt. Is that what you're looking for?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Actually, the structure itself is more simplified. And so if you want, we can talk a little bit more after the call. But this is [indiscernible] plus 70, and the other one was a Fannie credit enhanced. So the trade-off in terms of structure is not more complex.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then my other question was just, can you provide an update on Phase 3 and the progress with the area in that regard?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, this is John. From the BRE perspective as far as the legacy portfolio, we've certainly come a long way. As I mentioned in my remarks, some of the opportunities we still have going forward, specifically with that portfolio relating to amenity re
componenttext: Sure. Yes, this is John. From the BRE perspective as far as the legacy portfolio, we've certainly come a long way. As I mentioned in my remarks, some of the opportunities we still have going forward, specifically with that portfolio relating to amenity refi and the amenity adjustments and expirations. And the expirations have been commented on several times, but for clarity, clearly we can fix that. It was in a 12-month period. As the lease expires, it force things into a certain bucket. The problem is it's not the best thing to do economically. Typically, you're better to work through that over a couple of year period and not force people to take actions that are inconsistent with the market. So we just try to move it on the margin, and that's what we're doing. As it relates to the amenity adjustments, that takes several years to get right and, frankly, on the Essex legacy side, we're still refining that as well, trying to really connect with how the market perceives the different valuations of our similar unit types and make adjustments as an ongoing effort at our company. It just needed a lot more work on the BRE side as they really just started that revenue management process. On the big picture, on the expense side, things aren't pretty good order there. We now have the BRE portfolio, legacy portfolio, performing on the controllable expense basis, means admin and those types of expenses on a per-unit basis, below the Essex portfolio, and that makes sense that portfolio is little newer than ours. And so we've -- but it also a lot of work and we have that in very good order. From a management perspective, we have great people, and that is completely intermixed throughout the portfolio. So there is no Essex or BRE assets there. All Essex assets and how we manage them is almost exactly the same as a few nuance items that are getting cleaned up, but, basically, almost 100% the same. So that's come a long way, and we're very pleased with where that's at. On the renovation, the last big piece, that piece takes time. Again, our renovation program was pretty focused on making sure our product meets the market exactly. It's a very asset-by-asset program. And so we mentioned that we get launched it, which we have. 2016 will have a greater focus on the BRE portfolio as a percentage, then move along the Essex portfolio, and there's a switch from this last year. And we'll continue to explore those opportunities. Hopefully, that answers the question.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So few questions here. First, Mike, I appreciate your comments on tech and the jobs out there in your opening remarks. And looking -- I guess, what was a little surprising is, looking at your job forecast, the latest one in your sub today versus the one a
componenttext: So few questions here. First, Mike, I appreciate your comments on tech and the jobs out there in your opening remarks. And looking -- I guess, what was a little surprising is, looking at your job forecast, the latest one in your sub today versus the one a year ago, the job growth forecasts are sort of similar. And yet, obviously, the news headlines today are clearly fresher than they were a year ago, but Twitter, Yahoo!, you see some of these companies that are in the news, whether for business model issues or space giveback on their office use. I'm just trying to reconcile the 2. What would be the things that you guys would look for that would tell you something is happening, a red flag out there that would tell you that things may be changing, because the outlook that you gave in your job picture is a bit different than sort of the sentiment, if you read the newspapers or speak to folks, not your folks, but speak to the -- another side of the country.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex, it's Mike. Yes, I mean, the one point is that we pretty dramatically outperformed the job forecast last year. So yes, this year, as a forecast, it's pretty similar to last year, but you have the large outperformance in the middle of that, which
componenttext: Yes, Alex, it's Mike. Yes, I mean, the one point is that we pretty dramatically outperformed the job forecast last year. So yes, this year, as a forecast, it's pretty similar to last year, but you have the large outperformance in the middle of that, which we didn't expect, obviously. So we're going back to a what we consider to be a more sustainable job forecast. And so going forward, how do we detect the things are different from plan? We would use our own portfolio as being a primary source. Typically, what happens in the portfolio when you look at 30-day Ford availability and some of the other portfolio metrics, you will see dislocation happening more quickly than the data vendors will pick it up generally by 1 or 2 months. So we would generally see that hiccup happening right in the rental activity and Ford affordability. So we'll look for that, and that will be the primary trigger to focus more effort on what's going on. In terms of what we're most concerned about, a lot of people talk about the unicorns out there. And we're less concerned about them, more concerned about the large tech companies, because when you look at the number of employees, it's pretty dramatically different. Again, back to our top 10 tech public companies, there's about -- they have about 165,000 employees in the Bay Area, whereas the top 20 unicorns have about 11,000 employees in the Bay Area. So we are clearly more concerned about the top 10 or the big tech companies, but we're also -- on the flip side, we also recognize that they have such tremendous financial capabilities, again, the amount of cash that they have, the amount of growth that they've generated, the office space that they are leasing and the overall commercial activity. There is nothing to us that appears to be a hiccup in what their activities are, and that is what's really driving or anchoring our forecast for next year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, I just want to address your comment about office space, because we saw the same thing, which was Google and Apple. They were pulling back in their office lease in the East Coast. But when we looked at the big picture, we also recognized that they ex
componenttext: Alex, I just want to address your comment about office space, because we saw the same thing, which was Google and Apple. They were pulling back in their office lease in the East Coast. But when we looked at the big picture, we also recognized that they expanded their office space here, close to headquarters. So there's been a conscious decision to try to be more centralized. But net office space concern, they have not decreased and they add in. The news about Yahoo! laying off 1,700 employees. But what we also saw was the Sony PlayStation entertainment moving to headquarters from Japan to San Mateo and expanding, obviously, the office needs and which will bring in another what we would expect 700 to 800 or hiring 700 to 800 new employees. So [indiscernible].

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Angela, appreciate that. The second question is, you guys -- one of the 1031 properties was Downtown L.A. You guys have been investing in Downtown L.A. for quite some time. So just sort of curious, now that you've had a number of properties there, h
componenttext: Okay, Angela, appreciate that. The second question is, you guys -- one of the 1031 properties was Downtown L.A. You guys have been investing in Downtown L.A. for quite some time. So just sort of curious, now that you've had a number of properties there, how do you view that the properties have been performing relative to your underwriting?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, it's Mike. They performed generally inline with our underwriting. There is a pretty significant amount of supply coming into the Downtown. And from our perspective, that's going to require people that are working in the Downtown, but living somewher
componenttext: Alex, it's Mike. They performed generally inline with our underwriting. There is a pretty significant amount of supply coming into the Downtown. And from our perspective, that's going to require people that are working in the Downtown, but living somewhere else to relocate to the Downtown. And we expect that to be somewhat choppy. But the overall supply/demand of L.A. is incredibly positive to us. Los Angeles County produces somewhere around 0.5% or 0.6% of its stock every year. And it's getting -- demand growth that is well in excess of that, but that supply is focused really on the CBD LA as that transitions from being a sleepy downtown to being a 24-hour city. And we believe that, that is on track, and we believe that the long-haul or long-term potential is fantastic in that marketplace, even though there might be some bumps along the way.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim Sullivan with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim Sullivan with Cowen & Company.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Mike, at the risk of beating this dead horse on the demand forecast, just to make sure I understand, in your prepared comments, I think you mentioned economy.com as the source of, I guess, as the U.S. GDP forecast assumption and the national job growth assumption. For the individual markets, is that data also economy.com? Or is that based on your own research or some other local research source you look at?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you mean the job forecast by market?
componenttext: Do you mean the job forecast by market?

componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Or the economic forecast?
componenttext: Or the economic forecast?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the job forecast by market. And I understood you to say that the economy.com forecast was both job and GDP. Is that now right?
componenttext: Well, the job forecast by market. And I understood you to say that the economy.com forecast was both job and GDP. Is that now right?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really is a -- we use a variety of data vendors. And again, we prepared this forecast last quarter. So the world was a little bit different then. And we can go through the process of changing the forecast dramatically, but the reality is the world is c
componenttext: It really is a -- we use a variety of data vendors. And again, we prepared this forecast last quarter. So the world was a little bit different then. And we can go through the process of changing the forecast dramatically, but the reality is the world is changing so rapidly that you can't change the forecast every month, which would almost be necessary based on the amount of volatility we've had in the marketplace. But what our process is, we use the macro data for the broad macro numbers, which are U.S. GDP growth and U.S. job growth, and then we drive the more specific market forecast based on our own supply/demand analysis. And Angela has come up with a regression analysis that takes into account various different factors, including both supply and demand. It includes wage growth, for example, as one of the key items, affordability. And so the economic rent growth in our market forecast is Essex proprietary, but it's driven by macro numbers that come from data providers. I think 2.8% is the highest of the data providers, as I recall. Looking at the list, there are some that are in the 1.5% range. Again, we could change this on an ongoing basis, but to what point? I think that the forecast looks achievable. If you look at last year, we missed the GDP forecast, but outperformed on the job side. So is this a perfect science? Obviously, it's not. And it seems like we had resilience on the job growth side relative to historical relationships. And again, I think it goes back to that wealth incredible -- wealth creation that we've had on the West Coast that is really driving economic activity that is disconnecting from a lot of the data going back 5 or 10 years. So I think a lot of things are happening. It seems to us that these are achievable numbers. And again, we'll see. We expect the volatile years. I know everyone knows.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. And you mentioned that a few times here. So the bottom line is in terms of the forecast that's contained at the end of -- at the back of the fourth quarter sup, it's basically as it was at the end of the third quarter. And it's -- I take the po
componenttext: Sure, yes. And you mentioned that a few times here. So the bottom line is in terms of the forecast that's contained at the end of -- at the back of the fourth quarter sup, it's basically as it was at the end of the third quarter. And it's -- I take the point, you don't want to be reacting to every zig and zag in the data, and the data has been volatile itself, of course. But the regression analysis that Angela does, presumably that gets updated quarterly? Or is that where you put in a place at the beginning of the year, and if reality turns out to be a little different, you may adjust, but it sounds like you redo the regression every 90 days.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it's impractical to do that. Obviously, the market forecast drives our budgeting process. And it isn't like we're going to change our budgets overnight or every month. So we try to do this in a thoughtful manner, and we debate. This we debate
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's impractical to do that. Obviously, the market forecast drives our budgeting process. And it isn't like we're going to change our budgets overnight or every month. So we try to do this in a thoughtful manner, and we debate. This we debated whether we should reduce the forecast, and no doubt, some people out there think that we should have. But ultimately, we felt comfortable with it. With the caveat that I mentioned in my prepared remarks that there's probably a greater risk to the forecast than there was a quarter ago.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simply because the macro data and the announcements we're hearing from companies is indicating cutbacks in capital spending and other, call it, general moderation across the economy.
componenttext: Simply because the macro data and the announcements we're hearing from companies is indicating cutbacks in capital spending and other, call it, general moderation across the economy.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, given that. But again, you look at what we see out here, which is again these -- the amount of cash and wealth that these companies have. And looking at Alphabet specifically, I think they have the financial worth to do pretty much whatever they want
componenttext: Yes, given that. But again, you look at what we see out here, which is again these -- the amount of cash and wealth that these companies have. And looking at Alphabet specifically, I think they have the financial worth to do pretty much whatever they want to do. And in fact, they're in the whole bunch of different businesses. That I don't think is going to slow down a whole heck of a lot. It doesn't appear to be slowing down a whole lot. And the financial wherewithal to pursue multiple businesses at one time is absolutely assured. So that are part of what we're thinking as well is the ability to continue to push forward with expansion of these various businesses is something that we're counting on continuing going forward.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And just finally for me, if I could. Your supply forecast is presumably something that your team puts together, I guess, based on your knowledge of what's happening in the market. That's obviously a lot less volatile than potentially the demand fore
componenttext: Sure. And just finally for me, if I could. Your supply forecast is presumably something that your team puts together, I guess, based on your knowledge of what's happening in the market. That's obviously a lot less volatile than potentially the demand forecast. But is that the source of that primarily it's your own team's forecast?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we use data providers to give us the list of transactions, and then, inevitably, you have the same project called 3 different things. And so you try to go through and identify just what our team does. We try to go through and we identify wher
componenttext: Well, again, we use data providers to give us the list of transactions, and then, inevitably, you have the same project called 3 different things. And so you try to go through and identify just what our team does. We try to go through and we identify where each project is. And then based on that, we eliminate the duplication in the data. And we think we get a much better forecast as a result of that than a lot of the data providers have. We exclude from this student housing, senior housing and some of the other categories that others include in their data as well, as historically that has not proven that relevant to our overall activity.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Drew Babin from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Babin from Robert W. Baird.

componenttextpreview: Quickly, I was hoping to isolate what you're assuming in terms of ROI from the resource management initiatives implemented already, particularly within the BRE assets and whether increased activity being able to touch more units this year may provide some
componenttext: Quickly, I was hoping to isolate what you're assuming in terms of ROI from the resource management initiatives implemented already, particularly within the BRE assets and whether increased activity being able to touch more units this year may provide some upside to the expense growth guidance that's given.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John speaking. I think we've -- with regard to our expense growth guidance, we've factored things in appropriately. But just big picture for clarity. We have our resource management, and we categorize that separately than the renovation. So o
componenttext: Yes, this is John speaking. I think we've -- with regard to our expense growth guidance, we've factored things in appropriately. But just big picture for clarity. We have our resource management, and we categorize that separately than the renovation. So on the resource management, those initiatives tend to have pretty high IRRs, and they tend to be somewhere between the mid-teens, 15 to 25. And we've found some very good opportunities in the renovations. Those tend to be in the mid-teens or a little bit less, and we're executing those as well. But the guidance reflects what our expectations are.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on San Francisco. Can we fast-forward to the next slowdown? How do you see it playing out? I think it's always viewed as a boom bust market, but you kind of mentioned the well-capitalized companies. It sounds like there might be s
componenttext: I just want to follow up on San Francisco. Can we fast-forward to the next slowdown? How do you see it playing out? I think it's always viewed as a boom bust market, but you kind of mentioned the well-capitalized companies. It sounds like there might be some pent-up demand and some good visibility for office leasing. So your thoughts on the next slow down.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike. It's a great question. Again, let's put this in the unknowable category. And when it comes to the unknowables, I have to go back and may be summarize what I've seen in the last 30 years as it relates to Northern California. And I've seen hug
componenttext: This is Mike. It's a great question. Again, let's put this in the unknowable category. And when it comes to the unknowables, I have to go back and may be summarize what I've seen in the last 30 years as it relates to Northern California. And I've seen huge dislocation and disruption. Obviously, the Internet period was an incredible period in terms of that. And for example, you had, I think price-to-sales ratios were something like 49x in year 2000, and they're more like 7 now. So you had an incredible asset bubble with respect to these tech companies, and that went on for a lot longer than anyone expected it to go one and ultimately had a horrific impact of things. I think that, that really is the exception, though. When you look at 2007-2008 or 2008-2009 recession, actually, the tech world did rather well. It was construction, government, manufacturing, except where they did incredibly quarterly and thank everything. I think that's actually more of my belief with respect to the tech world. It's not necessarily the tech world that tends to be so volatile in terms of employment. It's the broader economy. So I don't have necessarily any great fear about tech itself. I have fear about just generally what's happening in the economy, because, I think, actually, tech, with the one notable exception of the Internet boom and bust period, the tech has actually done reasonably well during economic cycles and the downturns.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on a relative basis, they could hold up the cycle. I think may be -- a period might be a little over 1 at the moment on a relative basis, at least?
componenttext: Okay. So on a relative basis, they could hold up the cycle. I think may be -- a period might be a little over 1 at the moment on a relative basis, at least?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd ask, where else you're going to go? So I mean, I don't know. I mean, what are you going to -- you can pay in cash at 20 basis points or something like that. But I mean, as we look at the industries and what's happening in the world, it seems l
componenttext: I guess I'd ask, where else you're going to go? So I mean, I don't know. I mean, what are you going to -- you can pay in cash at 20 basis points or something like that. But I mean, as we look at the industries and what's happening in the world, it seems like tech is actually pretty well positioned relative to some of the other choices. We know that Southern California, for example, is a more diversified economy and, therefore, will have less dislocation, but again, not the same growth rate either. So if we see significant dislocation in the tech markets, we will obviously try to move more the portfolio southward. There is a small bias toward that, as you saw in the Sharon Green transaction, where we sell Northern California and we reinvest 2/3 Northern California, 1/3 Southern California. I think you will continue to see some of that happen. But again, we're not in a mindset that we need to divest of tech -- the tech market.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich Anderson here. So several years ago, I remember sitting down with Keith and he was complaining about his $100 stock price. And I thought at the time how crazy it was to think that, let alone say that loud. Of course, how do you know your stock would
componenttext: Rich Anderson here. So several years ago, I remember sitting down with Keith and he was complaining about his $100 stock price. And I thought at the time how crazy it was to think that, let alone say that loud. Of course, how do you know your stock would get up to $250 or close to it a few years later, you all would have taken that in a heartbeat. And your execution has been outstanding. But right now, this long list, as Goldfarb pointed out, of things going on, to what extent -- a lot of people are asking what are the signals that you're not seeing in your fundaments yet. But -- with all this in mind, what would you do? What the signal might be? But what would you do? Would there be an idea of selling assets in bulk? Because one thing that you still have is fantastic asset value. You could sell assets today at incredibly low cap rates, may be pay a special dividend, delever further and really honker down. I mean, what kind of action would you take if you do see something pop up in your fundamentals?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Mike. And Keith is still here. I talked to him this morning. He asked what happened to his $240 stock price. Keith is always with us. Again, it goes back to that relationship between asset values and the stock price. And that has been changing
componenttext: Rich, it's Mike. And Keith is still here. I talked to him this morning. He asked what happened to his $240 stock price. Keith is always with us. Again, it goes back to that relationship between asset values and the stock price. And that has been changing seemingly every day, and we sure would like to see some consistency in stock price before we make big strategic decisions. And unfortunately, that's probably not going to happen this year. And so we will look for opportunities, much like Sharon Green, where we think we can sell an asset and either buy the stock back or pay a special dividend. Both of them are potentially attractive to us. And we want to see some meaningful pickup in terms of impact on NAV per share. So today, that is probably there, but it wasn't there last week. And again, the trend -- it takes, what, 60 to 90 days to actually go through the transaction process. And then you have got to work through the reinvestment plan. So we're trying to do the best we can. I will tell you that we will sell more assets this year than we sold for the last several years. And I think that, that will continue to trend. And we'll look for both really 2 different things: one, pairing off the assets that we think will underperform over the longer period, which will probably be in the higher cap rate type of area, but then the more opportunistic, much like Sharon Green asset that traded at a very attractive, very aggressive cap rate that we can redeploy at a positive spread. So we'll be looking at those.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You said that fundamentals tend to give you a month or 2 head start. Is it possible now that when you look at just the craziness of the Bay Area housing market and maybe what's going on as being hidden from you, it's just a different set of circumstances
componenttext: You said that fundamentals tend to give you a month or 2 head start. Is it possible now that when you look at just the craziness of the Bay Area housing market and maybe what's going on as being hidden from you, it's just a different set of circumstances right now? Is that something that keeps you up at night as well that maybe the indicators that we've relied on past cycles may not present themselves the same way this time around?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's always the case. We're always concerned that we're missing something. And I'll say, in the fourth quarter, there were more move-outs to buy homes, and that caused some availability increase. Again, I think a lot of it was tied to the said act
componenttext: Well, that's always the case. We're always concerned that we're missing something. And I'll say, in the fourth quarter, there were more move-outs to buy homes, and that caused some availability increase. Again, I think a lot of it was tied to the said action and the belief that you need to get into a house now as opposed to wait, which turned out to probably be the wrong answer. But that 30-day availability has really been the bedrock of our management of both price and where the market is going. And it's a pretty sensitive variable, and I think it captures appropriately what's going on in the marketplace. So we're going to pay particular attention to that. And then if that moves, then the next position -- next point is, hey, is this a onetime only? Or is it a trend? And so we'll be trying to figure that out right after there's some movement in that area. Again, as John has indicated, January bounced back so nicely that we don't think that what happened in Q4 is anything other than isolated occurrence.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
