componenttext: Mike, at the risk of beating this dead horse on the demand forecast, just to make sure I understand, in your prepared comments, I think you mentioned economy.com as the source of, I guess, as the U.S. GDP forecast assumption and the national job growth assumption. For the individual markets, is that data also economy.com? Or is that based on your own research or some other local research source you look at?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the job forecast by market. And I understood you to say that the economy.com forecast was both job and GDP. Is that not right?
componenttext: Well, the job forecast by market. And I understood you to say that the economy.com forecast was both job and GDP. Is that not right?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really is a -- we use a variety of data vendors. And again, we prepared this forecast last quarter. So the world was a little bit different then. And we can go through the process of changing the forecast dramatically, but the reality is the world is c
componenttext: It really is a -- we use a variety of data vendors. And again, we prepared this forecast last quarter. So the world was a little bit different then. And we can go through the process of changing the forecast dramatically, but the reality is the world is changing so rapidly that you can't change the forecast every month, which would almost be necessary based on the amount of volatility we've had in the marketplace. But what our process is, we use the macro data for the broad macro numbers, which are U.S. GDP growth and U.S. job growth, and then we drive the more specific market forecast based on our own supply/demand analysis. And Angela has come up with a regression analysis that takes into account various different factors, including both supply and demand. It includes wage growth, for example, as one of the key items, affordability. And so the economic rent growth in our market forecast is Essex proprietary, but it's driven by macro numbers that come from data providers. I think 2.8% is the highest of the data providers, as I recall. Looking at the list, there are some that are in the 1.5% range. Again, we could change this on an ongoing basis, but to what point? I think that the forecast looks achievable. If you look at last year, we missed the GDP forecast, but outperformed on the job side. So is this a perfect science? Obviously, it's not. And it seems like we had resilience on the job growth side relative to historical relationships. And again, I think it goes back to that wealth -- incredible wealth creation that we've had on the West Coast that is really driving economic activity that is disconnecting from a lot of the data going back 5 or 10 years. So I think a lot of things are happening. It seems to us that these are achievable numbers. And again, we'll see. We expect a volatile year, as I know everyone knows.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. And you mentioned that a few times here. So the bottom line is in terms of the forecast that's contained at the end of -- at the back of the fourth quarter sup, it's basically as it was at the end of the third quarter. And it's -- I take the po
componenttext: Sure, yes. And you mentioned that a few times here. So the bottom line is in terms of the forecast that's contained at the end of -- at the back of the fourth quarter sup, it's basically as it was at the end of the third quarter. And it's -- I take the point, you don't want to be reacting to every zig and zag in the data, and the data has been volatile itself, of course. But the regression analysis that Angela does, presumably that gets updated quarterly? Or is that where you put it in a place at the beginning of the year, and if reality turns out to be a little different, you may adjust, but its not like you redo the regression every 90 days.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it's impractical to do that. Obviously, the market forecast drives our budgeting process. And it isn't like we're going to change our budgets overnight or every month. So we try to do this in a thoughtful manner, and we debate. This we debate
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's impractical to do that. Obviously, the market forecast drives our budgeting process. And it isn't like we're going to change our budgets overnight or every month. So we try to do this in a thoughtful manner, and we debate. This we debated whether we should reduce the forecast, and no doubt, some people out there think that we should have. But ultimately, we felt comfortable with it. With the caveat that I mentioned in my prepared remarks that there's probably a greater risk to the forecast than there was a quarter ago.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simply because the macro data and the announcements we're hearing from companies is indicating cutbacks in capital spending and other, call it, general moderation across the economy.
componenttext: Simply because the macro data and the announcements we're hearing from companies is indicating cutbacks in capital spending and other, call it, general moderation across the economy.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, given that. But again, you look at what we see out here, which is again these -- the amount of cash and wealth that these companies have. And looking at Alphabet specifically, I think they have the financial worth to do pretty much whatever they want
componenttext: Yes, given that. But again, you look at what we see out here, which is again these -- the amount of cash and wealth that these companies have. And looking at Alphabet specifically, I think they have the financial worth to do pretty much whatever they want to do. And then factor in a whole bunch of different businesses. That I don't think is going to slow down a whole heck of a lot. It doesn't appear to be slowing down a whole lot. And the financial wherewithal to pursue multiple businesses at one time is absolutely assured. So thats part of what we're thinking as well is the ability to continue to push forward with expansion of these various businesses is something that we're counting on continuing going forward.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And just finally for me, if I could. Your supply forecast is presumably something that your team puts together, I guess, based on your knowledge of what's happening in the market. That's obviously a lot less volatile than potentially the demand fore
componenttext: Sure. And just finally for me, if I could. Your supply forecast is presumably something that your team puts together, I guess, based on your knowledge of what's happening in the market. That's obviously a lot less volatile than potentially the demand forecast. But is that the source of that primarily it's your own team's forecast?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we use data providers to give us the list of transactions, and then, inevitably, you have the same project called 3 different things. And so you try to go through and identify. This is what our team does. We try to go through and we identify
componenttext: Well, again, we use data providers to give us the list of transactions, and then, inevitably, you have the same project called 3 different things. And so you try to go through and identify. This is what our team does. We try to go through and we identify where each project is. And then based on that, we eliminate the duplication in the data. And we think we get a much better forecast as a result of that than a lot of the data providers have. We exclude from this student housing, senior housing and some of the other categories that others include in their data as well, as historically that has not proven that relevant to our overall activities.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quickly, I was hoping to isolate what you're assuming in terms of ROI from the resource management initiatives implemented already, particularly within the BRE assets and whether increased activity being able to touch more units this year may provide some
componenttext: Quickly, I was hoping to isolate what you're assuming in terms of ROI from the resource management initiatives implemented already, particularly within the BRE assets and whether increased activity being able to touch more units this year may provide some upside to the expense growth guidance that's given.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John speaking. I think we've -- with regard to our expense growth guidance, we've factored things in appropriately. But just big picture for clarity. We have our resource management, and we categorize that separately than the renovation. So o
componenttext: Yes, this is John speaking. I think we've -- with regard to our expense growth guidance, we've factored things in appropriately. But just big picture for clarity. We have our resource management, and we categorize that separately than the renovation. So on the resource management, those initiatives tend to have pretty high IRRs, and they tend to be somewhere between the mid-teens, 15 to 25. And we've found some very good opportunities in the renovations. Those tend to be in the mid-teens or a little bit less, and we're executing those as well. But the guidance reflects what our expectations are.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wes Golladay with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on San Francisco. Can we fast-forward to the next slowdown? How do you see it playing out? I think it's always viewed as a boom/bust market, but you kind of mentioned the well-capitalized companies. It sounds like there might be s
componenttext: I just want to follow up on San Francisco. Can we fast-forward to the next slowdown? How do you see it playing out? I think it's always viewed as a boom/bust market, but you kind of mentioned the well-capitalized companies. It sounds like there might be some pent-up demand and some good visibility for office leasing. So your thoughts on the next slowdown.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike. It's a great question. Again, let's put this in the unknowable category. And when it comes to the unknowables, I have to go back and maybe summarize what I've seen in the last 30 years as it relates to Northern California. And I've seen huge
componenttext: This is Mike. It's a great question. Again, let's put this in the unknowable category. And when it comes to the unknowables, I have to go back and maybe summarize what I've seen in the last 30 years as it relates to Northern California. And I've seen huge dislocation and disruption. Obviously, the Internet period was an incredible period in terms of that. And for example, you had, I think price-to-sales ratios were something like 49x in year 2000, and they're more like 7 now. So you had an incredible asset bubble with respect to these tech companies, and that went on for a lot longer than anyone expected it to go on and ultimately had a horrific impact of things. I think that, that really is the exception, though. When you look at 2007-2008 or 2008-2009 recession, actually, the tech world did rather well. It was construction, government, manufacturing, except where they did incredibly poorly and tanked everything. I think that that's actually more of my belief with respect to the tech world. It's not necessarily the tech world that tends to be so volatile in terms of employment. It's the broader economy. So I don't have necessarily any great fear about tech itself. I have fear about just generally what's happening in the economy, because, I think, actually, tech, with the one notable exception of the Internet boom and bust period, the tech has actually done reasonably well during the economic cycles and the downturns.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on a relative basis, they could hold up the cycle. I think maybe our fears might be a little overblown at the moment on a relative basis, at least?
componenttext: Okay. So on a relative basis, they could hold up the cycle. I think maybe our fears might be a little overblown at the moment on a relative basis, at least?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd ask, where else you're going to go? So I mean, I don't know. I mean, what are you going to -- you can pay in cash at 20 basis points or something like that. But I mean, as we look at the industries and what's happening in the world, it seems l
componenttext: I guess I'd ask, where else you're going to go? So I mean, I don't know. I mean, what are you going to -- you can pay in cash at 20 basis points or something like that. But I mean, as we look at the industries and what's happening in the world, it seems like tech is actually pretty well positioned relative to some of the other choices. We know that Southern California, for example, is a more diversified economy and, therefore, will have less dislocation, but again, not the same growth rate either. So if we see significant dislocation in the tech markets, we will obviously try to move more of the portfolio southward. There is a small bias toward that, as you saw in the Sharon Green transaction, where we sell Northern California and we reinvest 2/3 Northern California, 1/3 Southern California. I think you will continue to see some of that happen. But again, we're not in a mindset that we need to divest of tech -- the tech market.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich Anderson here. So several years ago, I remember sitting down with Keith and he was complaining about his $100 stock price. And I thought at the time how crazy it was to think that, let alone say that loud. Of course, how do you know your stock would
componenttext: Rich Anderson here. So several years ago, I remember sitting down with Keith and he was complaining about his $100 stock price. And I thought at the time how crazy it was to think that, let alone say that loud. Of course, how do you know your stock would get up to $250 or close to it a few years later, you all would have taken that in a heartbeat. And your execution has been outstanding. But right now, this long list, as Goldfarb pointed out, of things going on, to what extent -- a lot of people are asking what are the signals that you're not seeing in your fundaments yet. But -- with all this in mind, what would you do? Forget about what the signal might be. But what would you do? Would there be an idea of selling assets in bulk? Because one thing that you still have is fantastic asset value. You could sell assets today at incredibly low cap rates, maybe pay a special dividend, delever further and really hunker down. I mean, what kind of action would you take if you do see something pop up in your fundamentals?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Mike. And Keith is still here. I talked to him this morning. He asked us what happened to his $240 stock price. Keith is always with us. Again, it goes back to that relationship between asset values and the stock price. And that has been changi
componenttext: Rich, it's Mike. And Keith is still here. I talked to him this morning. He asked us what happened to his $240 stock price. Keith is always with us. Again, it goes back to that relationship between asset values and the stock price. And that has been changing seemingly every day, and we sure would like to see some consistency in stock price before we make big strategic decisions. And unfortunately, that's probably not going to happen this year. And so -- but we will look for opportunities, much like Sharon Green, where we think we can sell an asset and either buy the stock back or pay a special dividend. Both of them are potentially attractive to us. And we want to see some meaningful pickup in terms of impact on NAV per share. So today, that is probably there, but it wasn't there last week. And again, the trend -- it takes, what, 60 to 90 days to actually go through the transaction process. And then you have got to work through the reinvestment plan. So we're trying to do the best we can. I will tell you that we will sell more assets this year than we sold for the last several years. And I think that, that will continue to trend. And we'll look for both really 2 different things: one, pairing off the assets that we think will underperform over the longer period, which will probably be in the higher cap rate type of area, but then the more opportunistic, much like Sharon Green asset that traded at a very attractive, very aggressive cap rate that we can redeploy at a positive spread. So we'll be looking at those.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You said that fundamentals tend to give you a month or 2 head start. Is it possible now that when you look at just the craziness of the Bay Areas housing market that maybe what's going on is being hidden from you, it's just a different set of circumsta
componenttext: You said that fundamentals tend to give you a month or 2 head start. Is it possible now that when you look at just the craziness of the Bay Areas housing market that maybe what's going on is being hidden from you, it's just a different set of circumstances right now? Is that something that keeps you up at night as well that maybe the indicators that we've relied on in past cycles may not present themselves the same way this time around?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's always the case. We're always concerned that we're missing something. And I'll say, in the fourth quarter, there were more move-outs to buy homes, and that caused some availability increase. Again, I think a lot of it was tied to the Fed acti
componenttext: Well, that's always the case. We're always concerned that we're missing something. And I'll say, in the fourth quarter, there were more move-outs to buy homes, and that caused some availability increase. Again, I think a lot of it was tied to the Fed action and the belief that you need to get into a house now as opposed to wait, which turned out to probably be the wrong answer. But that 30-day availability has really been the bedrock of our management of both price and where the market is going. And it's a pretty sensitive variable, and I think it captures appropriately what's going on in the marketplace. So we're going to pay particular attention to that. And then if that moves, then the next position -- next point is, hey, is this a onetime only? Or is it a trend? And so we'll be trying to figure that out right after there's some movement in that area. Again, as John has indicated, January bounced back so nicely that we don't think that what happened in Q4 is anything other than an isolated occurrence.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you've discussed on the call, Mike, I think that Essex has earned a reputation as one that will adjust as needed to the change in cost of capital. But just have a couple of questions on specific things that I'd like to understand how you think about co
componenttext: As you've discussed on the call, Mike, I think that Essex has earned a reputation as one that will adjust as needed to the change in cost of capital. But just have a couple of questions on specific things that I'd like to understand how you think about couple of specific things. The first is, I think that you suggested that if the stock price is unfavorable, you would shift away from wholly owned acquisitions and more towards a co-investment. But how do you think about co-investments relative to just making no acquisitions at all?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, we have to be able to add per-share growth, NAV and cash flow to the portfolio. And I don't know if we've shared with you, but we have an accretion model that we run for every deal that tries to measure those against the portfolio. And again, we're t
componenttext: Hey, we have to be able to add per-share growth, NAV and cash flow to the portfolio. And I don't know if we've shared with you, but we have an accretion model that we run for every deal that tries to measure those against the portfolio. And again, we're trying to add value to the stock, not subtract value from the stock. And our process is really designed around that. And so we do not feel compelled to do transactions just for the sake of doing transactions. And we certainly don't feel compelled to do transactions for "strategic reasons." We want to make deals that make sense and that are additive to shareholder value over the long haul. And that's -- we started -- I go back all the way back to 1995, 1996. We talked about what our long-term goals were, and they are as relevant today as they were back then. And we said basically, "Hey, if we can grow effectively what's core FFO, was just FFO back then, at somewhere around 8% or 9% a year and pay a dividend that's in the 4% or 5% range, that's going to be a really great thing for shareholders." And we've stayed true to that, and we've added a little bit of NAV sensitivity to it as well. But that's what makes these entities do well over the long haul. And as you know, it's worked out pretty well for shareholders and us.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Second question, it just relates to the logistics of hypothetically selling assets and buying back stock. Would you -- if you were to tee up assets for sale and you have maybe some confidence in the private market, would you take that private marke
componenttext: Great. Second question, it just relates to the logistics of hypothetically selling assets and buying back stock. Would you -- if you were to tee up assets for sale and you have maybe some confidence in the private market, would you take that private market risk and buy back stock immediately? Or would you wait the 60-ish days that it takes to close, have the cash in hand and then buy back the stock? How do you think about those decisions?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't like them, Dave, to answer your question, because the transaction markets, again, they're all over the place. And the ability to close, with all the variables are make it risky. But then again, we've seen this with the Sharon Green transaction, w
componenttext: We don't like them, Dave, to answer your question, because the transaction markets, again, they're all over the place. And the ability to close, with all the variables are make it risky. But then again, we've seen this with the Sharon Green transaction, where roughly 2/3 we were going to exchange and we're going to pull a dividend forward and do -- buy some stock back if we saw some weakness there. And that was on the table for about 10 seconds and then off the table. So it's really incredibly challenging thing to do to match this, match these off in a way that is additive to the shareholders. Fortunately, I have Angela and it's her job to make that happen. So Angela, you want to add anything to that? Hey, it's challenging. One of the most difficult things, I think, we have to do this year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the only thing that I would add is, yes, I agree that this it is challenging. But we can't move generally pretty quickly and we do have a very flexible balance sheet. And so we have a track record of doing the right thing and we're going to
componenttext: Well, I think the only thing that I would add is, yes, I agree that this it is challenging. But we can't move generally pretty quickly and we do have a very flexible balance sheet. And so we have a track record of doing the right thing and we're going to continue to do that.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, but on that specific point, it sounds like it's fluid. You don't have a hard fast rule that you have to wait, get the cash in the door before you go buy back the stock. You evaluate it on a case-by-case basis.
componenttext: Understood, but on that specific point, it sounds like it's fluid. You don't have a hard fast rule that you have to wait, get the cash in the door before you go buy back the stock. You evaluate it on a case-by-case basis.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's magnitude, right, Dave? I mean, if cap rates go up 100 basis points and the stock goes down, then you're compelled to do it. And you feel like, hey, under any scenario, we're going to be able to capture that difference in valuation. If the magnitud
componenttext: That's magnitude, right, Dave? I mean, if cap rates go up 100 basis points and the stock goes down, then you're compelled to do it. And you feel like, hey, under any scenario, we're going to be able to capture that difference in valuation. If the magnitudes are relatively thin, then why would you take the risk? The risk becomes more apparent. So it's a question that really doesn't have an answer. We do not have any preset biases. As you know, we try to be pretty thoughtful about looking at things and keeping risk in mind and not do things just because the common wisdom is to do them, but rather do things because we can add value doing them. And so again, it's going to be case-by-case. It will be an interesting year. And I hope the stock does well, but if it doesn't, we'll come up with another plan. I can assure you that.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Forward-looking statements are made based on current expectations, assumptions and beliefs as well as information available to the company at this time. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Further information about these risks can be found in the company's filings with the SEC. [Operator Instructions]   
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Michael Schall, President and Chief Executive Officer for Essex Property Trust. Thank you, Mr. Schall. You may begin.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. I'll cover the following topics on the call: first, comments on our Q
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. 
I'll cover the following topics on the call: first, comments on our Q1 results and market conditions; second, investment activities; and finally, an update on rent control proposals. 
Yesterday, we were pleased to report continued strong operating results for the first quarter of 2016. For the past several years, one of our primary operating goals has been to grow core FFO per share. I congratulate the Essex team for accomplishing that goal, with over 100% increase in core FFO per share since Q1 2011.
Generally speaking, the West Coast economy continues to perform well, and we are on track to achieve our 2016 market rent forecast shown on Page S-16 of the supplement. Recent job reports have generally equaled or exceeding our expectations.
In Southern California, we have modestly increased our market rent growth expectations from 5.2% to 5.5%, again mostly related to better-than-expected jobs, representing more evidence that our thesis for slow and steady growth continues. 
For Northern California, we are lowering our economic rent growth forecast from 7.5% to 6.5%. 
As noted on our last call, supply deliveries during the typically weak fourth quarter caused lower rent growth in Northern California, mostly focused on 3 submarkets: Delta [ph] market in San Francisco; the Peninsula, South of San Francisco and/or San Jose, which, combined, account for approximately 7% of our same-store NOI. 
As reflected in our Q1 results, we experienced a choppy but nice rebound from Q4. March and April have brought renewed pricing pressure focused on these 3 submarkets in the form of greater concessions often equal to 6 to 8 weeks of rent, as newly delivered apartments is pushed rapid absorption in a competitive market. The greater concessions provide enough incentive to draw people out of nearby properties, pressuring price for stabilized communities. 
Apartment supply deliveries and hiring are inherently lumpy, and much like Q4 '15 and the past couple of months, conditions can change quickly. John Burkart will elaborate further in his comments.
Turning to Seattle. We have significantly increased the economic rent forecast for Seattle from 4.9% to 6.1%, as its great job growth and strong economy has provided the demand to absorb Seattle significant new apartment pipeline at higher-than-expected rents. 
On to the second topic, investments. During the quarter, we originated a preferred equity investment on an apartment development consisting of 494 apartment homes located in Glendale, California. The investment provides a 12% preferred return on outstanding principal, with a total commitment of $47 million. We are working on other preferred equity transactions, as developers are finding themselves in need of additional equity, given construction cost increases, more conservative construction lending standards and more challenging and expensive entitlement processes.
Market clearing cap rates for development deals typically generate around a 4.5% to 4.75% untrended cap rate, which is below our yield threshold. We continue to look for development opportunities that meet our underwriting criteria, and we are not likely to lower our targets in the near term.
There has been widespread discussion of increasing cap rates in the West Coast markets. 2 of the recent acquisitions, Mio and Enso, both in San Jose, were cited by brokers as examples of cap rates that are higher than comparable properties trading a few months earlier. We take this as a complement that we acquired property at a better-than-market cap rate. However, in our evaluation of many deals we have recently underwritten, the value of Mio and Enso did not much change in the past several quarters. In our experience, cap rates change slowly, primarily because buyers and sellers don't change their pricing expectations quickly or easily. Rather, buyers and sellers need to be convinced that the market conditions have permanently changed.
Financial distress often shortens this process for changing cap rates, but currently, there is almost no distress in well-located apartments. To the contrary, the amount of positive leverage available to buyers at existing cap rates represents a compelling opportunity in this yield-starved environment. 
During the quarter and is outlined in the press release, we acquired 2 properties to facilitate 1031 exchanges and sold 2 properties as part of the portfolio call-in [ph] process. 
Similar to last quarter, A-quality property and locations traded around a 4.25 [ph] cap rate used in Essex methodology, but from time to time, more aggressive buyers will pay sub-4 cap rates. 
B-quality properties and locations typically have cap rates 25 to 50 basis points higher than A-quality property. 
And on my third topic, which is rent control. There have been several new developments with respect to rent control in various California cities, mostly in Northern California. Most notable, the City Council in San Jose has amended the existing rent stabilization ordinance to lower the maximum rent increase on renewals to 5% from 8% previously. The amended San Jose ordinance also contains a provision to bank or accumulate up to 8% of potential rent increases to be used during periods that market rent increases are below the 5% maximum. 
Finally, the San Jose ordinance is applicable only to properties built before 1979.
Oakland, which also has an existing rent stabilization ordinance, recently passed an emergency 90-day moratorium on rent increases, applicable only to properties built before 1983. 
In addition to the specific actions in San Jose and Oakland, we believe that tenants rights groups will adapt to win for approval of referendums that will oppose rent control in several cities.
It is important to note that all local ordinances, including the activity just described, must comply with state law, which mandates, among other things, that vacant apartments are prohibited from rent control, and rent control can only be applied to property built before 1996. 
We believe that these various ordinances will have limited impact on Essex, primarily because the vast majority of our properties are newer than the rent control cutoff dates in the various stabilization ordinances. 
In addition, because rent control limits renewal rent increases, residents stay longer, which reduces turnover at rent control property. 
Reduced turnover means that fewer apartments are available to rent for people moving into the area, which likely pushes rents upward on the available apartment inventory. 
Thus, renewals will often occur at below-market rates, but this impact is partially mitigated by higher rents on new leases, reflecting the unintended secondary effects of rent control.
I'm incredibly grateful for John Eudy and many Essex team members for attending and advocating on behalf of the company and the industry at several city council meetings. The meetings contain a lot of emotion and often end well past midnight. 
That concludes my comments. Thank you for joining the call today. I will now turn the call over to John Burkart.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. We had a good quarter, delivering total same-store revenue growth of 7.3% and NOI growth of 8.8%. Our renovation team got off to a great start in 2016. We increased the number of units renovated in the same-store portfolio 229%, from 24
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. We had a good quarter, delivering total same-store revenue growth of 7.3% and NOI growth of 8.8%. 
Our renovation team got off to a great start in 2016. We increased the number of units renovated in the same-store portfolio 229%, from 247 units in the first quarter of 2015 to 813 units in the first quarter of 2016. The increased unit turn negatively impacted our vacancy rate by about 5 basis points for the quarter in the same-store portfolio compared to the prior year. 
Now I will share some highlights for each region.
Strong demand in the Seattle market, fueled by employment growth of 3.3% in March, which is above our expectations, enabled the market to absorb the new supply and continue to grow revenues. Our Seattle portfolio grew revenues 7% in the first quarter of 2016 compared to the first quarter of 2015. We made a strategic decision due to the market strength in the first quarter to emphasize achieved rental rates over occupancy, and we've continued to do so as we entered the spring leasing season. That position is paying off well with better-than-expected performance, and it will position us well going forward.
Submarkets performed similar to last year, with the CBD growing rental revenue about 4% in the first quarter of 2016 compared to the comparable quarter. And the East, North Eastside, North and South submarkets are all growing between 7.5% and 9% for the first quarter of 2016 compared to their comparable quarter. 
In the Bay Area, as I mentioned previously, our expectations for the first quarter were that the market would be choppy, and then it would be followed by the normal seasonal pattern. However, the market is currently softer than expected. Our same-store achieved rents in March of 2016 were about 6% over achieved rents in March 2015.
And the achieved rents in April of 2016 are roughly 4% over the comparable month due to the difficult comps. 
The BLS surveys continue to show strong employment growth in the Bay Area. We just recently reported March 2016 employment growth rates of 4%, 2.4% and 3.8% for San Francisco, Oakland and San Jose MDs, respectively, which are above our expectations. The household survey reported unemployment decline at average of 60 basis points in each MD year-over-year, which is consistent with strong job growth. 
Both reports indicate strong employment market, which is able to absorb the total supply multi-family and single-family units and continue to grow rent.
It appears that in addition to the lumpiness of the multi-family supply deliveries during the low-demand period, other factors are currently impacting the demand in the Bay Area market, such as doubling up and increased inventories choosing to rent single-family homes, which enables more roommates to share the rent; onetime impact of the crackdown of the student visa program, which has reduced demand from outside the country; and an increase in the flexibility work arrangement, enabling employees to telecommute from outside the normal commute zone. 
We have noted a slight change in the geographic location of the open position listed by the major tech companies. There's a slight increase in total open positions between Washington and California. However, California open positions have declined slightly, while the Washington open positions have increased slightly. This shift may be the product of the tight labor market and housing market that we have in the Bay Area.
Southern California region continues to perform, driven by strong job growth exceeding our expectations. As expected, the momentum we saw in 2015 continued into 2016, enabling us to achieve a revenue growth of 6.1% in the first quarter of 2016 compared to the comparable quarter. 
In the L.A. MSA, L.A. CBD, which is impacted by positive supply, grew rental revenue 4.9% in the first quarter of 2016 compared to the first quarter of 2015. And the Woodland Hills submarket, which had the greatest positive impact from Porter Ranch relocation, performed at the top end of the MSA, with an increase in rental revenues at 8.6% for the first quarter of 2016 compared to the comparable quarter.
We estimate that the increased demand for short-term rentals related to the Porter Ranch leases increased the year-over-year growth rate for the L.A. MSA portfolio by about 30 basis points during the first quarter of 2016.
Currently, our portfolio occupancy is at 95.8%, and our availability 30 days out is at 5.4%. Considering the underperformance in the Northern California portfolio, we are cautiously optimistic about the spring leasing season. 
Thank you, and I will now turn the call over to Angela Kleiman.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'll start with our first quarter results then provide an update on recent capital markets activities. I'm pleased to report that our core FFO for the first quarter exceeded the mid-point of our guidance by $0.08 per share. Although $0.04
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I'll start with our first quarter results then provide an update on recent capital markets activities. 
I'm pleased to report that our core FFO for the first quarter exceeded the mid-point of our guidance by $0.08 per share. Although $0.04 was related to timing of expenses, the remaining $0.04 was primarily driven by stronger-than-anticipated operations, which led to another quarter of solid operating results. 
Also in the first quarter, we declared a quarterly common dividend of $1.60 per share, which is an 11% year-over-year increase and represents our 20th year of consecutive dividend growth. 
Moving on to recent capital markets activities. In April, we issued $450 million of 10-year [ph] senior unsecured notes at a rate of 3.375% per annum. The net proceeds from the offering were used to pay off the balance on our line of credit, redeem the Series H Preferred Stock and fund other corporate activities. While there is a temporary mismatch on the timing of the use for some portion of the proceeds, we believe it was an opportune time to enter into that market.
Our only remaining maturity this year is $200 million term loan, which comes due in November. With 0 outstanding on our $1 billion line of credit and limited near-term debt maturities, our balance sheet is well-positioned to be opportunistic, as we evaluate future investment or refinancing strategies.
For the full year, we are reaffirming our guidance on same-property revenue, expense and NOI growth and the mid-point of our core FFO per share of $10.92. Lastly, I would like to highlight a new page, S-12.1 in our supplemental, which provides additional disclosures on the revenue-generating and nonrevenue-generating CapEx spending. We hope these enhanced disclosures will be beneficial to the investment community. 
I will now turn the call back to the operator for questions.

componenttext: Yes. Again, it's Mike Schall, and John Eudy is here. He may have a comment on this as well. It seems like all the forces are working against that. Number one, the entitlement process is just very challenging. If anything, there are some cities like San Francisco that would like to bump up the number of units that are dedicated to below market rate units. And construction costs are going at double-digit rates. So it would be difficult to see, especially with rents moderating, a lot of momentum toward more apartment development going forward at this point in time.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Schall. I think John Burkart's comments covered that, to some extent. It was that slowdown from month-to-month, actually, through the first quarter and into April that was concerning us. And there was a couple of other pieces, too. One is that o
componenttext: It's Mike Schall. I think John Burkart's comments covered that, to some extent. It was that slowdown from month-to-month, actually, through the first quarter and into April that was concerning us. And there was a couple of other pieces, too. One is that our evaluation of apartment supply indicates further lumpiness in Q2 and Q3. So roughly, in the San Francisco MSA, 3,600 units get delivered in Q2 and 2,700 in Q3. So roughly 70% of the expected annual deliveries will happen in Q2 or Q3. So we're concerned about that. And the significance since we turn or renew or turn around 50% of the leases in these next several months, that has a pretty significant impact on the overall results. So I guess, perhaps we're being overly cautious, but those were the factors that led us to do that. And actually, let me add one more factor, and that is overall supply and demand, as you look at the numbers, appears to be disconnecting in some way. As an example or to go through the numbers, the Bay Area is expected to produce about 93,000 jobs in 2016. That would ordinarily, at a 2:1 look at all housing and not just apartments, would give you 46,000 units of demand against about 20,000 apartments and homes being delivered into the marketplace. So about a 2 for 1 relationship. So there should be sufficient demand to absorb the supply as it comes on board. Yet, what we're seeing on the marketplace is that there is more concessions, and the supply is not being absorbed as easily as we otherwise would expect. So that supply-demand disconnect is a concern to us. Could be indicative of perhaps employment is slowing, but it hasn't really hit the numbers yet, in the last many years that I've been here. It seems that sometimes, we see changes in the marketplace before they actually get reported in the numbers. So those would be a little bit of background on why we decided not to change guidance.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color. And then the spread in terms of the same-store revenue growth between Northern California and Southern California continues to contract for the reasons you've discussed. Do you expect at any point this year for Southern California
componenttext: I appreciate the color. And then the spread in terms of the same-store revenue growth between Northern California and Southern California continues to contract for the reasons you've discussed. Do you expect at any point this year for Southern California to actually outperform Northern California?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. It's hard to tell, right, what we right now are expecting that the NorCal will follow seasonal patterns. As Mike laid out, there's a lot of strength if you look at the jobs versus the supply. But honestly, it's not necessarily working o
componenttext: Yes. This is John. It's hard to tell, right, what we right now are expecting that the NorCal will follow seasonal patterns. As Mike laid out, there's a lot of strength if you look at the jobs versus the supply. But honestly, it's not necessarily working out that way. So yes, there's a year that it happens. This year is Southern Cal is stronger than expected, and it's doing very well. It might happen somewhere down the line this year or into '17.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Rob Stevenson from Janney.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Rob Stevenson from Janney.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about L.A. County results? I mean, was it strong across the board? Or were there pockets of relative strength, relative weakness in the quarter? I mean, obviously, it's 7% plus. Relative weakness is probably a strong statement, b
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about L.A. County results? I mean, was it strong across the board? Or were there pockets of relative strength, relative weakness in the quarter? I mean, obviously, it's 7% plus. Relative weakness is probably a strong statement, but I mean, where, within the portfolio, was the best performance in L.A. County? And was it noticeable between some of the submarkets?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, overall, the submarkets were fairly consistent. However, if we're really breaking it down clearly, the Woodland Hills area got some benefit from Porter Ranch. And so that moves it up. It doesn't really move needle so much as it relates to Essex,
componenttext: Yes. No, overall, the submarkets were fairly consistent. However, if we're really breaking it down clearly, the Woodland Hills area got some benefit from Porter Ranch. And so that moves it up. It doesn't really move needle so much as it relates to Essex, but that enabled that submarkets to move up a little bit. You might see it in some of the AXIO numbers. And then, of course, the downtown area is a little bit on the low side. Again, we have supply going in in that market, but it's still doing strong. Overall, SoCal, a big picture, is doing well, as is L.A. County. Really, it's interesting, there wasn't a lot of changes. If you look at like the Bay Area, it's a little different. The Bay Area you clearly have San Francisco is underperforming, and then you have other markets, other submarkets in the Bay Area doing stronger. SoCal was much more consistent.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of sort of the Shadow development pipeline, I mean, how much -- how many units are you sort of working through entitlement process through -- could start in the next year, 1.5 years or so out there versus basically exhausting your
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of sort of the Shadow development pipeline, I mean, how much -- how many units are you sort of working through entitlement process through -- could start in the next year, 1.5 years or so out there versus basically exhausting your land supply at this point?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Mike. And again, John Eudy may want to add to this. Our view is that we are more aggressive on development at the bottom of the cycle, and we scale off as we go to the top of the cycle. And so we do not have a significant land inventory or la
componenttext: Yes. This is Mike. And again, John Eudy may want to add to this. Our view is that we are more aggressive on development at the bottom of the cycle, and we scale off as we go to the top of the cycle. And so we do not have a significant land inventory or land bank at this point in time. In terms of dealmaking, I know John is looking at deals that are fully entitled, ready to go. We're not taking any cost risk because again, construction costs are moving so rapidly that we're concerned about committing and being naked with respect to when we commit to a deal and when it starts. So we have turned to become more conservative. And again, that really provides the opportunity within or for the preferred equity transactions where we can come in between the somewhere around the 60% loan-to-cost to about 85% loan-to-cost and earn a 12% return there. We fundamentally like that business, and we think it's a great time to do that relative to the opportunities in the marketplace.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you looking at that business as a path to ownership or just basically 12% investment at this point?
componenttext: Are you looking at that business as a path to ownership or just basically 12% investment at this point?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we would love to negotiate an option to buy at the end of that, but we've not really been able to do that. I mean, we could do it if we were willing to give up a significant amount of current return. We haven't made that choice at this point in time
componenttext: Well, we would love to negotiate an option to buy at the end of that, but we've not really been able to do that. I mean, we could do it if we were willing to give up a significant amount of current return. We haven't made that choice at this point in time. So at this point in time, we're happy to earn that fixed return and get repaid. And if there are some bumps down the road somewhere, perhaps, we're in a position to buy out our partner.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk a little bit about the financing environment with respect to availability for financing for construction lending and just land development and, if anything, if we should be modeling more considerably as the cost is increasing, giving s
componenttext: Could you just talk a little bit about the financing environment with respect to availability for financing for construction lending and just land development and, if anything, if we should be modeling more considerably as the cost is increasing, giving some, I guess, less desire from the banks? Or are you guys not seeing that?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's exactly what we're seeing. A number of our preferred equity transactions over the last several months have really come together because the construction lender is cutting back at their construction loan commitment and become more conservative.
componenttext: No, that's exactly what we're seeing. A number of our preferred equity transactions over the last several months have really come together because the construction lender is cutting back at their construction loan commitment and become more conservative. In one case, the construction lender was at the 65% to 68% loan-to-cost. They cut it back to about 60%. And actually, in that deal, we went from -- essentially, there wasn't a place for us in the transaction they could finance it themselves, to creating this -- the tranche that we ultimately invest in between the 60 and 85th [ph] percentile loan-to-cost. So we've seen a pretty significant change not just in 1 or 2 lenders but really across-the-board, as construction lenders have become more conservative.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's really helpful. And then just secondly, I think you were -- Mike Schall was sizing numbers on expected deliveries, and I really compliment you guys on being conservative with respect to the outlook. I think that's prudent. When you think ab
componenttext: Got it. That's really helpful. And then just secondly, I think you were -- Mike Schall was sizing numbers on expected deliveries, and I really compliment you guys on being conservative with respect to the outlook. I think that's prudent. When you think about -- when you talk about those deliveries in 2 and 3Q, Mike, were you talking about deliveries in the Bay Area for all of multi-family? Or was it just the rental portion?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ivy. There's a couple of nuances there. We do not include student housing, and we essentially ignore under 100 units, and that's part of it. But -- and I was referring to San Francisco directly went I gave out those numbers. San Francisco, we have, a
componenttext: Yes, Ivy. There's a couple of nuances there. We do not include student housing, and we essentially ignore under 100 units, and that's part of it. But -- and I was referring to San Francisco directly went I gave out those numbers. San Francisco, we have, again, 3,600 units in Q2 and 2,700 units in Q3. San Jose also has pretty significant deliveries in Q2 and Q3, as is Los Angeles. So again, relative to the total, we see Q2 and Q3 is creating potentially more lumpiness, similar to what we saw in the fourth quarter and, again, in March, April.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just keeping with the prudent, more conservative guide. When you think about deliveries that are coming from condos and recognizing that many of those condos are being brought by investors that might want a cash flow and rent out those units, is there
componenttext: And just keeping with the prudent, more conservative guide. When you think about deliveries that are coming from condos and recognizing that many of those condos are being brought by investors that might want a cash flow and rent out those units, is there a potential risk that, that could put more pressure relative to market? Because I know we're hearing about that. Equity residential mentioned they had some [indiscernible] come in below market, I guess, against their rents by like $800, [indiscernible] cash flow. So how do you guys think about that as a risk to your guidance?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of how we approach it, we try to lump all housing together because we know that people move out of apartments and buy condos or homes. And some will actually go the other direction as well. So our basic analysis is to look at all the jobs, t
componenttext: Yes. In terms of how we approach it, we try to lump all housing together because we know that people move out of apartments and buy condos or homes. And some will actually go the other direction as well. So our basic analysis is to look at all the jobs, try to determine what the total households are and really not distinguish between what's a rental home and what is a for-sale home. Having said that, the other thing we pay attention to is affordability of rentals versus homeownership. And in every one of our markets, and Ivy, you know this better than anyone, the cost of these homes is pretty significant. I think the median-priced home in San Francisco is over $1 million. And so that transition from a renter to a homeowner is really important to us, and it's obviously very difficult in this marketplace. But in order to avoid this issue of, okay, how many of these demand units are going to go to for-sale versus for-rent, we just look at the whole thing.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, and I appreciate that. I'm sorry, I may have miscommunicated the question right. What we're hearing is that the condo that are coming to being delivered, those that are purchased as a for-sale unit, they may be an investor whether they are from ou
componenttext: No, no, and I appreciate that. I'm sorry, I may have miscommunicated the question right. What we're hearing is that the condo that are coming to being delivered, those that are purchased as a for-sale unit, they may be an investor whether they are from outside the U.S., foreign buyer, that wants to now rent it out. Is that a risk that you've incorporated into your outlook, that they will be competitive now in the rental? And I guess, you're saying that you just look at it overall and shelter, redelivery of the unit competitive risk?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. Exactly, the household. We don't care -- well, we care but it should not affect us.
componenttext: Exactly. Exactly, the household. We don't care -- well, we care but it should not affect us.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Lesnick from Capital One.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple of ones on developments. I saw your new start this quarter went into the consolidated bucket, 100% ownership. Can you talk a little bit about how you make the risk allocation decision between placing development into a JV or keeping it on balance sheet?

componenttextpreview: This is John Eudy. That was a deal that we basically bought out of bankruptcy about 4 years ago. As you know, it was an operating property [indiscernible] entitlements and have a substantial low land base of a little over 30,000 and lower. We're able to g
componenttext: This is John Eudy. That was a deal that we basically bought out of bankruptcy about 4 years ago. As you know, it was an operating property [indiscernible] entitlements and have a substantial low land base of a little over 30,000 and lower. We're able to get the entitlements without any increased extractions or inclusionary requirements. So the yield is very attractive and not replaceable in today's market, which, the short story, is we're probably going to leave that on the balance sheet.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I appreciate that color. And then one other quick one. Obviously, with the Agoura close to initial occupancy and that being a condo-finish project, are you guys contemplating any other condo-finish developments at this point in time?
componenttext: Got it. I appreciate that color. And then one other quick one. Obviously, with the Agoura close to initial occupancy and that being a condo-finish project, are you guys contemplating any other condo-finish developments at this point in time?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We math everything we can, just so you know. We're just a majority of our deals. But by your question, it sounds like do we plan on going to a condo program out of the chute? No.
componenttext: We math everything we can, just so you know. We're just a majority of our deals. But by your question, it sounds like do we plan on going to a condo program out of the chute? No.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey. Just a few quick questions for you guys. There was a lot in the upfront about, I guess, increase in rental homes and people doubling up in the Bay Area. So a two-part on that. One, are you seeing any dynamic at the super -- I guess, where are these p
componenttext: Hey. Just a few quick questions for you guys. There was a lot in the upfront about, I guess, increase in rental homes and people doubling up in the Bay Area. So a two-part on that. One, are you seeing any dynamic at the super -- I guess, where are these people coming from? Are they like super high-end renters who just got tired of it and said, "It's cheaper to rent otherwise"? Or these are sort of entry-level people who just can't make anything else work, and therefore, they're defaulting to this? So one, are you seeing more pressure at the high-end rental or at the low-end price point? And then I'll ask a follow-up after that.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me kind of answer it a little bit broad here, Alex. First off, with the supply coming in, and they're trying to get the units absorbed, they're naturally offering concessions, and those have been increased. And they are in the start of the process as
componenttext: Let me kind of answer it a little bit broad here, Alex. First off, with the supply coming in, and they're trying to get the units absorbed, they're naturally offering concessions, and those have been increased. And they are in the start of the process as it relates to some of the concessionary activity, and then, of course, others, consumer, the empowered consumer and with the information you have some concession jumpers. And so people are moving around, and that causes some pressure then on the next level on the apartments. As it relates to the doubling up, it's really happening at various levels within the apartment zone. And you have people that are doubling up into 2s, people doubling up into 1s, just various things going on. And It's all incremental, right? But that incremental takes a hair off the demand that's out there and ultimately reduces demand. And so that's that you see it all over. The feedback that we get anecdotally is that the single-family market is very, very high occupancy right now. And that, again, would have taken up some of the demand, and it makes sense if you think about it for a larger unit in effect, and you can put a couple of 2, 3, 4 people in income earners and have a nice space. So I think people are finding ways to deal with the higher rents, and some of those again, mean doubling up.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say that it's more -- it's not the high price point rents aren't the issue, it's more the lower price point renter is more the pressure point, not the high-end renter?
componenttext: Is it fair to say that it's more -- it's not the high price point rents aren't the issue, it's more the lower price point renter is more the pressure point, not the high-end renter?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's across the whole zone.
componenttext: I think it's across the whole zone.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then Mike Schall, you had mentioned previously that Seattle and San Francisco sort of coexist on the tech side, and that don't have a disconnect. Do you think that, that's still holds true? Or do you think that maybe the affordability issu
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then Mike Schall, you had mentioned previously that Seattle and San Francisco sort of coexist on the tech side, and that don't have a disconnect. Do you think that, that's still holds true? Or do you think that maybe the affordability issues in San Francisco, coupled with the supply, means that the 2 markets could sort of disconnect on the fundamental side?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex. Just to be clear, those comments, I think, I made in connection with Q4, and the point I was tried to make is that it did not appear to be a tech hiring issue. It appeared to be a supply issue, a supply lumpiness issue. I think I'd commented th
componenttext: Yes, Alex. Just to be clear, those comments, I think, I made in connection with Q4, and the point I was tried to make is that it did not appear to be a tech hiring issue. It appeared to be a supply issue, a supply lumpiness issue. I think I'd commented that around 40%, 40-plus percent of the supply in Northern California hit the fourth quarter during the seasonally weakest time. So -- but again, to the point, it appears that Seattle and San Francisco, i.e. both being tech markets, are performing very well on the job side. And therefore, we look at the supply side of, the lumpiness of the supply is being a contributing factor or a driver of this disconnect. As we go forward, it's going to be interesting to see because again, if you look at the overall numbers, going from jobs and job growth to household formation to supply, it would not indicate that we should have weakness in the apartment area. And the concessions seem to be going from roughly a month to 6 to 8 weeks. That would not be indicated, given the overall supply-demand numbers. But yet here we are. And so we are trying to make sense out of why that is occurring. We don't have anything at this point.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just finally, you made some comments in the opening MD&A about cap rates maybe softening a bit. Was that just sort of normal cap rate volatility? Or were you indicating that cap rates are, in fact, backing up on the West Coast?
componenttext: Okay. And then just finally, you made some comments in the opening MD&A about cap rates maybe softening a bit. Was that just sort of normal cap rate volatility? Or were you indicating that cap rates are, in fact, backing up on the West Coast?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex. The comment I made was that there were comments in the marketplace from brokers. There was a couple of articles that I read, where brokers in the marketplace were suggesting that cap rates were increasing. We have not seen that. And as I -- the
componenttext: Yes, Alex. The comment I made was that there were comments in the marketplace from brokers. There was a couple of articles that I read, where brokers in the marketplace were suggesting that cap rates were increasing. We have not seen that. And as I -- the point I was trying to make is the underwrite a lot of deals, that we're always in the market. And so we have a very good sense of what's happening in the marketplace. And so we disagree with those brokers. So if that didn't come clear, I apologize.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Wes Golladay from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at this dynamic, it appears to be favorable supply and demand market. Yet you kind of have a [indiscernible] supply in certain submarkets. Is that what it is, weighing on it? And once we get through this, what then could you get the more normal pa
componenttext: Looking at this dynamic, it appears to be favorable supply and demand market. Yet you kind of have a [indiscernible] supply in certain submarkets. Is that what it is, weighing on it? And once we get through this, what then could you get the more normal patterns on the rental growth?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wes, it's Mike, and John may have comments on this as well. Again, we're not quite. I mean, if you look at these overall supply-demand ratios up and down the coast, it would indicate that we would continue to have pricing power. And again, we're seeing co
componenttext: Wes, it's Mike, and John may have comments on this as well. Again, we're not quite. I mean, if you look at these overall supply-demand ratios up and down the coast, it would indicate that we would continue to have pricing power. And again, we're seeing concessions on the newly delivered product, increasing from a month to 6 to 8 weeks. And I think it's lumpiness, but we're going to let this next quarter go by, and then we'll reevaluate guidance and results at that point in time. So essentially, we didn't -- as a general rule, revising guidance at the end of the first quarter is something that I think is generally not what you want to do because it's only 1 quarter. So we'd rather be able bit cautious, and hopefully, we blow right through this period and absorb the units. And we're back into a very strong pricing power type of mode come the end of summer. But we'll have to wait and see.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it sounds like the velocity is actually going pretty nicely on those new units, given lower price point.
componenttext: Okay. So it sounds like the velocity is actually going pretty nicely on those new units, given lower price point.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. But keep in mind that an extra month of concession is an 8% reduction in price. And when you look at it that way, people that otherwise wouldn't move might say, "Oh, gee, at that price, I'm willing to make a change and move  to a brand-new apartment
componenttext: Yes. But keep in mind that an extra month of concession is an 8% reduction in price. And when you look at it that way, people that otherwise wouldn't move might say, "Oh, gee, at that price, I'm willing to make a change and move  to a brand-new apartment unit." And so that's the effect of concessions. And it seems to me that concessions are prevalent in the marketplace, and it increased. And again, that's what's causing the softness. Again, I believe that the concessions can abate, much like they did in January, February quickly, but we just don't know exactly how that's going to happen. It's a function of how many units do you have, how aggressive the owners are. Obviously, if you deliver a new building, you have $0 coming in on your vacant units. And so you're highly motivated to rent them. And many of those owners are saying, "Hey, rather than leaving it vacant, I'll try to hit really high absorption numbers and increase my cash flow." Again, they are incented -- they have a different financial objective or a different financial view relative to stabilized apartments. And so -- but they have a dramatic effect on stabilized apartments. So that process is going to play out, and so we're going to be clearly a bit more pressure than we have over the last couple of years. And we'll have to see how that ultimately turns out.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow-up. So is it the concession enough to pull people in maybe from the East Bay into the soma market? Or do you think people are still staying in the submarket?
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow-up. So is it the concession enough to pull people in maybe from the East Bay into the soma market? Or do you think people are still staying in the submarket?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think everything will happen. People are looking for opportunity. It happened in this business a long time, as you know, Wes. And people are smart. They figure the opportunities in the marketplace, and they go after them. Many of the renters just do
componenttext: No, I think everything will happen. People are looking for opportunity. It happened in this business a long time, as you know, Wes. And people are smart. They figure the opportunities in the marketplace, and they go after them. Many of the renters just don't have that much furniture, and so moving is not that big a deal. And so if you give them another 8% off their rent in the form of a concession, they are all over it. And so it's a very fluid marketplace. And what I suspect will happen is we will go through this period of time, and we'll absorb the units. We'll get back into Q4 in San Francisco, where we think roughly 1,300 units will be delivered. And we'll have much more pricing power. So it'll will be a temporary dislocation in the market is what I suspect.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Drew Babin from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
