headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded.Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forwar
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded.
Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Forward-looking statements are made based on current expectations, assumptions and beliefs as well as other information available to the company at this time. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Further information about these risks can be found in the company's filings with the SEC. [Operator Instructions] 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Michael Schall, President and Chief Executive Officer for Essex Property Trust. Thank you, Mr. Schall. You may begin.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and thank you for joining us today. And welcome to our second quarter earnings conference call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. I'll cover the following topics on the call:
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and thank you for joining us today. And welcome to our second quarter earnings conference call. John Burkart and Angela Kleiman will follow me with comments, and John Eudy is here for Q&A. I'll cover the following topics on the call: first, our commentary on quarterly results and market conditions; second, an investment market update; and finally, the latest on rent control proposals in California.
So on to the first topic. The second quarter was challenging operationally, as job growth was weaker than expected in several key markets, often coinciding with peaking apartment supply deliveries. With that said, we're pleased that we exceeded our core FFO per share guidance for the quarter and are increasing our 2016 core FFO guidance by $0.06 at the midpoint. We are also tightening the revenue guidance range, leaving the midpoint of our revenue guidance slightly lower, largely attributable to reduced rent growth expectations in Northern California. Once again, I thank the Essex team for their focus and effort in driving bottom line growth in a demanding and changing environment.
Generally speaking, the West Coast economy continues to outpace the slow growth national economy, which we now estimate will produce 2016 job growth of 1.8%, down from our prior estimate of 2%. Throughout our California markets, we have pockets of strength and weakness coinciding with the quantity of new apartment deliveries and the level of concessions being offered by landlords. In response to these conditions, we have lowered our 2016 market rent forecast by 50 basis points to 5.5% on Page S-16 of our supplemental package. Generally, B-quality apartments and locations continue to perform better than As, as lower price points become more important to renters as affordability pressures increase.
In my 30 years at Essex, I have not seen the divergence in performance between Seattle and Northern California that we're currently experiencing, and our Seattle results have been a huge positive surprise. The economies of Seattle and Northern California have a large tech component and thus unusual -- and thus usually follow a similar path in terms of rent growth. Seattle generates more housing supply, measured as a percentage of stock, which has historically moderated as long-term rent growth, again, relative to Northern California. The cost of this divergence is largely on the demand side, driven by job growth. To demonstrate this, I'm going to refer to nonseasonally adjusted job growth from January to June, primarily because the year-over-year job numbers are significantly influenced by the strong second half of 2015.
Seattle had the strongest job growth for the first half of 2016 compared to each of the past 6 years, and the margin of outperformance is notable. In 2015, which you likely will recall was a very good year, Seattle increased total jobs for the first half of the year by 30,000. The comparable job growth for 2016 was 43,400 or 44% more jobs added relative to 2015. To contrast this with Northern California, in January through June 2016, we added 27,000 jobs, down from 44,100 in the comparable period of 2015. Based on this activity, we are changing our 2016 forecast on Page S-16 of the supplement as follows.
In Seattle, job growth increase is 15% to 55,800 jobs, and our 2016 market rent forecast increases to 8.5% from 6.1%. In Northern California, job growth is reduced from 93,100 to 74,200, and our 2016 market rent forecast goes from 6.5% to 3.8%. We still believe that our apartments located in the centers of technology and innovation will deliver above-average rent growth. This belief is supported by the integration of technology into virtually every part of our lives, resulting in high growth expectation, higher income levels and better wage growth.
Southern California remains on track to achieve our targets for 2016. There are, however, pockets of supply that impact price in certain submarkets. Overall, we had solid results through the Southland, especially in L.A. and San Diego. As a result, we're leaving our 2016 rent growth expectations unchanged. As noted on our last call, apartment supply deliveries are inherently lumpy, which affects market rents based on the concession level and other pricing considerations. Last quarter, we estimated that approximately 70% of the 2016 supply will occur in the second and third quarter of -- in San Francisco, San Jose and Los Angeles. In San Francisco and San Jose, we expect apartment supply to begin to moderate in the fourth quarter of 2016, and we expect new deliveries of apartments in 2017 will fall about 20% to 30% in San Francisco and 30% to 40% in San Jose.
Second topic, investment markets. Our 2016 guidance called for $400 million to $600 million in acquisitions and $200 million to $300 million in dispositions. Through the second quarter, we've acquired around $150 million and disposed of about $110 million, including our pro-rata share of co-investments. We've also added approximately $67 million to the outstanding balance of our preferred equity investments.
We are working on several acquisition deals that we expect to be largely funded through dispositions. With this activity, we should be in the range of our guidance assumptions for acquisitions and at the high end of the range for dispositions. We also have about $50 million in potential preferred equity transactions that are being underwritten.
During the quarter, the stock traded at or marginally below net asset value, making accretive acquisitions and dispositions challenging to execute. We continue to wait for market conditions that allow accretive transactions, strongly preferring that to acquisitions or dispositions that accomplish little with respect to growth in NAV and core FFO per share. We will also continue to selectively cull the portfolio, reinvest it in lower-risk or higher growth opportunities. 
Cap rates have been stable for the last quarter, with A-quality property and locations trading around a 4 to 4.25 cap rate using the Essex methodology. And from time to time, more aggressive buyers will pay sub-4 cap rates. B-quality property and locations typically have cap rates 25 to 50 basis points higher than A-quality property.
While rental growth rates are moderating, so is the cost of debt, such that the percentage of positive leverage on real estate deals is approaching record highs. We continue to see fewer redevelopment starts in Northern California, largely attributable to increased cost of construction and discipline shown by lenders. We expect a small increase in apartment supply in Seattle and Southern California in 2017. 
Market clearing cap rates for development deals typically generate a 4.5% to 4.75% untrended cap rate, which is below our yield threshold. We continue to look for development opportunities that meet our underwriting criteria, and we are not likely to lower targets in the near term.
And then finally, third topic, rent control. Generally, there appears to be less urgency related to rent control now that rents have moderated in Northern California. However, the process started by tenant rights groups in several Northern California cities has led to several ballot initiatives. So far, qualified initiatives exist for the ballot in Northern California cities of Mountain View, Richmond, San Mateo and Alameda. Burlingame remains in the qualification process. Generally, these proposals provide for a CPI-based rent increases on renewals only, subject to a cap. These are in addition to changes to the rent control ordinance in San Jose that I discussed on last quarter's call. 
It is important to note that all local rent control ordinances must comply with state law, which mandates, among other things, that vacant apartments are prohibited from rent control. We believe that these various ordinances will have limited impact on Essex, primarily because of the vast majority of our properties are newer than the rent control cutoff dates and the various stabilization ordinances or state law, whichever applies.
Finally, in our experience, rent control ordinances generally shift the pricing burden from the renewing renter to the new resident. In other words, while rent control reduces renewal rent increases, it also reduces turnover in all rent control property, which means that fewer apartments are available to rent for people looking for a new apartment, which likely pushes rents upward on the vacant and available apartment inventory. Thus, while renewals will often occur at below-market rates, this impact is partially mitigated by higher rents on new leases, reflecting the unintended secondary effect of rent control.
That concludes my comments. Thank you again for joining the call. I'll now turn the call over to John Burkart.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. We had another good quarter, delivering total same-store revenue growth of 6.9% and NOI growth of 8.2% relative to the comparable quarter. As Northern California has slowed down due to the factors that Mike mentioned, Seattle has strength
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. We had another good quarter, delivering total same-store revenue growth of 6.9% and NOI growth of 8.2% relative to the comparable quarter. As Northern California has slowed down due to the factors that Mike mentioned, Seattle has strengthened and Southern California continues to perform.
Now I will share some highlights for each region. The strong demand in Seattle, fueled by the surge in employment for the first half of this year, which is above our expectations, enabled the market to absorb the new supply and continue to grow revenues. Our Seattle portfolio grew revenues 7.5% in the second quarter of 2016 relative to the comparable quarter.
The submarkets performed similar to last year, with the CBD growing revenue about 5.4% and the East side, North and South submarkets, where over 80% of our portfolio is located, growing revenues between 7.7% and 9% for the second quarter of 2016 relative to the comparable quarter.
In the Bay Area, the market has strengthened from the first quarter. July rents are up about 5% from the beginning of the year. However, due to the tough comps from last year, net effective rents are up only about 1/2 percent from last year's rent at this time.
San Francisco and San Jose continue to absorb the supply at a rate of approximately 19 units per month for lease-up and 30 units per month for lease-up, respectively, for AXIO. Concessions have decreased from 6 to 8 weeks, down from 4 to 6 weeks. East Bay has been stronger, however, as the toughest comps for the peak leasing season.
Our 2 lease-ups in the East Bay, The Galloway and Agora, are leasing up as planned, with The Galloway absorbing about 30 units per month and the 49-unit Agora leasing about 15 units per month.
The Bay Area economy continues to be a vibrant economy, benefiting from the ongoing expansion of technology into traditional industries. Numerous corporations have created innovation outposts in the Bay Area such as General Electric, Walmart, BMW, Nissan and General Motors. According to a recent study, there are over 50 corporate innovation outposts located in the Bay Area. The next largest concentration is in London with only 10. 
Office absorption was positive in all 3 Bay Area MSAs, from 321,000 square feet in Oakland MSA to 790,000 square feet in the San Jose MSA. There were numerous leases signed in the Bay Area recently by companies such as Fitbit, Lyft, Stripes, LifeLock, Delta, Uber, and Twitch, a video gaming division of Amazon, all combined, leasing over 1 million square feet of space in the quarter.
Currently, there's approximately 10.8 million square feet of office space under construction in the Bay Area, of which 46% is preleased.
LeEco, the Chinese electronics maker, just purchased nearly 50 acres of land that belonged to Yahoo! near Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California. The acquisition adds 3 million square feet of space for LeEco's operations, which spans smartphones, bicycles, virtual reality headsets and, eventually, electric cars and is enough for about 12,000 workers.
Finally, the city of Santa Clarita recently approved related $6.5 billion major project just north of Levi's Stadium, the largest private development in Silicon Valley history. The project includes 5.7 million square feet of office space, 1.1 million square feet of retail space, 1,360 apartment homes, 700 hotel rooms and 450,000 square feet of restaurant and entertainment space. Construction is expected to start in late 2017.
The Southern California region continues to be a solid performer overall. In the L.A. MSA, the CBD grew revenues 3.8% in the second quarter of 2016 compared to the prior year's quarter, as it continues to absorb new supply. The Woodland Hills and Tri-Cities submarkets were the strongest in the L.A. MSA, growing revenues over 7% for the second quarter of 2016 relative to the comparable quarter.
Silicon Beach continues to see new investment from technology companies. Google is outgrowing its 100,000 square feet space in Venice and is expanding to the 319,000-square-foot hangar where Howard Hughes assembled a giant wooden seaplane called the Spruce Goose. Google purchased the adjacent 12 acres of empty land, next to the hangar, a couple of years ago.
In the Orange County, in North Orange submarkets -- in Orange County, the North Orange submarket outperformed South Orange submarket in the second quarter of 2016, with revenues growing 5.9% and 3.1%, respectively, over the prior year's quarter. Revenue increased 7.4% in San Diego's MSA, with the Northern submarkets outperforming the CBD and Southern some markets relative to the comparable quarter. Recently, Google signed a 60,000-square-foot office lease in Northern San Diego's tech-heavy Sorrento Mesa area, expanding its Southern California footprint into San Diego for the first time.
Currently, our portfolio is at 96.2%, and our availability 30 days out is at 5.2%. Our renewals are being sent out in the 5% to 6% range in both Northern and Southern California and in the 6 to 8% range in the Pacific Northwest for the third quarter. We are positioned well for the second half of this year, and we look forward to 2017 when we expect the supply to decrease in Northern California.
Thank you, and I will now turn the call over to Angela Kleiman.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Today, I will comment on our second quarter results, the state of our balance sheet and the updated full year guidance.Once again, our core FFO per share for the quarter exceeded the midpoint of our guidance by $0.08. Although $0.04 of the
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Today, I will comment on our second quarter results, the state of our balance sheet and the updated full year guidance.
Once again, our core FFO per share for the quarter exceeded the midpoint of our guidance by $0.08. Although $0.04 of the outperformance primarily related to property tax refunds and timing of expenses, the remaining $0.04 was driven by stronger-than-anticipated operations, capital and investment decisions, which benefited the bottom line.
In addition, our total FFO for the quarter was actually higher than core FFO per share by $0.07. This was primarily attributed to successful insurance recoveries for lost rents due to the MB360 fire, which occurred prior to the BRE merger. 
As for our balance sheet, during the quarter, we issued $450 million of 10-year unsecured bonds at a coupon of 3 3/8 and retired our Series H Preferred Stock. Our only remaining debt maturity this year is a $200 million term loan due in November, which we plan to refinance with a new 5-year unsecured term loan. And we expect to retain a more attractive pricing than the current 2.4%.
 
So far, this year, we have funded our development equity needs with disposition proceeds and have not issued any common equity.
Currently, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio is inside of our target range, and we are comfortable with this ratio resting in the high-5s, as this range has proven to have successfully weathered the Great Recession.
With our $1 billion revolver undrawn, a strong balance sheet and numerous sources of equity and debt capital, we continue to be well positioned to -- for future growth.
Turning to our revised guidance for the full year. As Mike commented, even though Northern California is facing headwinds this year, we still expect the region to perform well relative to the nation and produce over 7% same-property revenue growth. However, the lumpiness of supply deliveries in Northern California, coupled with lower job growth in the region, will impact our full year same-store rent growth. Therefore, we have tightened our range and lowered the midpoint.
Our expense growth assumptions remain unchanged at 3.8%. The resulting expected NOI growth is now 8.1% at the midpoint, which remains within the guidance range provided at the beginning of 2016.
From an FFO perspective, the projected reduction to same-property growth rate is approximately $0.05 per share to the full year core FFO. But due to favorable year-to-date results, which have exceeded our original forecast and accretive capital markets and investment transactions completed so far, we are able to raise our full year core FFO midpoint by $0.06 per share to $10.98.
For 2016, we are projecting core FFO growth of 12%, which represents our sixth consecutive year of double-digit growth.
Thank you, and I will now turn the call back to the operator for questions.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. I was just curious if your guidance in Northern California assumes steady-state rent growth or what you've achieved, I guess, in 2Q or July in the back half of the year. Or would you expect there to be a reacceleration since we've surpassed peak supply now, and it sounds like concessions are abating a bit?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John Burkart. We're not necessarily expecting acceleration up in rents, but we are starting to have a better fourth quarter than last year. So our guidance assumes that the rents don't fall off as much as they do normally seasonally, that we
componenttext: Yes. This is John Burkart. We're not necessarily expecting acceleration up in rents, but we are starting to have a better fourth quarter than last year. So our guidance assumes that the rents don't fall off as much as they do normally seasonally, that we maintain rental a bit better than we have in the past, that we take advantage of increasing occupancy a little bit and that we continue to achieve our -- what we've been achieving on our renewals around 5% to 6%.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just switching over to Seattle. You mentioned increased supply in Seattle in 2017. Is there any concern that Seattle could see some similar headwinds that's been seen in Northern California next year?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just switching over to Seattle. You mentioned increased supply in Seattle in 2017. Is there any concern that Seattle could see some similar headwinds that's been seen in Northern California next year?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Austin, it's Mike. It's interesting, when we talk about how unusual this has played out this year, it almost means that we have to determine whether it's a onetime occurrence or it is a part of trends going either direction, both in Northern California an
componenttext: Austin, it's Mike. It's interesting, when we talk about how unusual this has played out this year, it almost means that we have to determine whether it's a onetime occurrence or it is a part of trends going either direction, both in Northern California and Seattle. And the answer to that is it's, I think, unknowable. And it becomes one of the things we're very focused on trying to figure out. But I think the expectation would be, well, let's go back to where we started the year. We started the year with the expectation that Seattle would have continued good job growth. And because of the supply, there would be pressure on rents. I think we started the year with a rent growth expectation of around 4.9%. So what happened is we got the supply, but we just dramatically exceeded the job growth, as noted in my comments. I suspect that some of those conditions will even out, that, again, I've been here for 30 years, just had my 30th anniversary and here at Essex, and I've never seen this divergence. And so I would say 2 things. One, we don't know. Two, we suspect that we will see a more normal balance, more consistent with 29 of the 30 years I've been here. And number three, we're going to be studying it to try and determine what we think the longer-term trends might be. Does that make sense? So the answer is [indiscernible].

componenttext: Yes. Northern California, part of the issue was that 70% of the supply in San Jose and San Francisco hit in Q2 and Q3. So we've had some slowdown in jobs. Again, I suspect that, that will work itself out. The supply picture is declining, fortunately, next year. So I think we start seeing a little bit better pricing environment beginning in the fourth quarter of this year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on investment. I think you talked about cap rates for As and Bs. But I was wondering if you would comment on any changes that you have seen in cap rates in Northern California, given the slowdown there.
componenttext: A couple of questions on investment. I think you talked about cap rates for As and Bs. But I was wondering if you would comment on any changes that you have seen in cap rates in Northern California, given the slowdown there.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Mike. We have not seen changes in cap rates, and I think you've got -- and as I tried to comment in my prepared remarks, you have 2 forces. I think, on the one hand, you have lower growth rates, although, to put that in perspective, the growt
componenttext: Yes. This is Mike. We have not seen changes in cap rates, and I think you've got -- and as I tried to comment in my prepared remarks, you have 2 forces. I think, on the one hand, you have lower growth rates, although, to put that in perspective, the growth rates that we saw over the last 4, 5 years are extraordinary in Northern California. So I don't think that most of the private investors that were buying property in Northern California had the expectation of the rent growth that they got over the last several years. So I think the growth that we got is -- for over the last several years was an anomaly, not a normal thing. And I don't think, again, that most buyers have that expectation. Having said that, as it relates to the longer-term picture, the private markets tend to be long-term oriented in terms of making these investments. And I think they still see Northern California as one of the strongest long-term CAGRs of rent growth generators that there is in the United States. And so they know that, and they play a long-term game. And so I don't think that the attractiveness in the investment markets of property Northern California has changed very much. And then finally, the third factor is you have debt costs that are lower now. And so the amount of positive leverage you have on apartment properties is pretty extraordinary. And we're 26% levered. A lot of investors out there are 60% or 70% levered. And obviously, that makes a huge difference. So I don't see anything in the near term where you can buy a property that yields somewhere around 4.5%, finance it with a lot of positive leverage with some growth over time. I think, in this environment, that looks like a winner more broadly. And so I wouldn't expect cap rates or evaluations to change very significantly at all.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up on the preferred equity transactions side. Are you seeing more product, and what's your appetite to grow that platform?
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up on the preferred equity transactions side. Are you seeing more product, and what's your appetite to grow that platform?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are seeing more because of some of the conditions that we talked about earlier. The increase in construction costs and lenders cutting back loan-to-cost ratios on construction loans, how both have the effect of property owners or developers that n
componenttext: Yes. We are seeing more because of some of the conditions that we talked about earlier. The increase in construction costs and lenders cutting back loan-to-cost ratios on construction loans, how both have the effect of property owners or developers that need more equity. And this is a targeted program on property that we would like to -- that we could own. It was consistent with our portfolio and -- but it's a unique opportunity in the marketplace. In terms of our appetite for it, I would say that it probably is in the $300 million to $400 million range total outstanding, probably not more than that. Again, it's limited because we're not going to deviate outside of our markets, and we're going to continue to look at properties that we could own if things don't end well.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line from Ryan Meliker with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about -- a little bit about the big picture topic, and it's one that we probably haven't talked about too much over the past year or so. But that's Airbnb. I'm wondering if you guys have given any thought to the new regulation in San Fran
componenttext: I wanted to talk about -- a little bit about the big picture topic, and it's one that we probably haven't talked about too much over the past year or so. But that's Airbnb. I'm wondering if you guys have given any thought to the new regulation in San Francisco and Anaheim. It sounds like things are in the works in Seattle. And whether that's going to have an impact on overall market fundamentals if there's a lot of long-term -- I guess, a lot of short-term rentals now entering the long-term rental pool. Do you think that's had -- been a tailwind for you guys over the past couple of years? And are you -- do you have any expectation for it to be a headwind as some of these regulations take shape over the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mike. It remains to be seen. Obviously, any product that enters the market for rental is -- incrementally puts more pressure on the markets and provides more availability or more supply. So that is a given. It's hard to extract or to focus on
componenttext: Yes, this is Mike. It remains to be seen. Obviously, any product that enters the market for rental is -- incrementally puts more pressure on the markets and provides more availability or more supply. So that is a given. It's hard to extract or to focus on that component and determine what impact it is having, other than that general statement that I just made. We continue to study Airbnb, and we have some experience in the area as a pilot program type of thing. And I think that there's so much noise that -- and so many issues as it relates to an apartment community, where if you people shown up with their roller boards day in and day out, it's generally not a good thing. So we continue to evaluate Airbnb. We realize that, again, as you point out, long term, more -- rental is going -- has a pricing impact ultimately on the marketplace. But I think it's fairly minimal. And it's going to be something that going to -- we're going to continue to evaluate. And over the next several years, we'll make some decisions about to what extent we want to participate in that area.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I guess I'm coming out of the perspective of -- there are some reports that there are over 12% of Seattle's stock has been pulled out of long-term rentals in favor of using Airbnb for short-term rentals. People are running businesses, rent
componenttext: That's helpful. I guess I'm coming out of the perspective of -- there are some reports that there are over 12% of Seattle's stock has been pulled out of long-term rentals in favor of using Airbnb for short-term rentals. People are running businesses, renting out apartments. And so long term competing with you, short term competing with hotels. And in San Francisco, we've heard something like 9,500 apartments that don't have registrations. And with all the regulation, have you guys looked into trying to figure out what the number of -- the amount of supply that really would be competitive with you guys is out there that's working in the short-term rentals? Or is that something you haven't focused on yet?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It falls within the area of supply/demand analysis. There's always going to be factors you have trouble quantifying, and you will -- you're going to make some broader assumptions surrounding. And as you point out, I agree with you on Airbnb to the extent
componenttext: It falls within the area of supply/demand analysis. There's always going to be factors you have trouble quantifying, and you will -- you're going to make some broader assumptions surrounding. And as you point out, I agree with you on Airbnb to the extent you have more apartment units that are pulled out for a hoteling type of use. Obviously, that helps us in the flip in San Francisco, for example, where you're going to start regulating them and they're going to put that the other way. It's going to hurt you. So we have not tried to do that, but again, I think there are other factors that are similar to that, to the extent people are doubling up, to the extent that employers are allowing people to work from home x days a week so that they can commute longer distances and/or connect by telecommunication devices, et cetera, and not coming to the office at all. So there's a whole cadre of things we try to capture in our relationship between job growth and demand or households. And so to the extent that Airbnb or any of these other factors might enter into the equation, we would alter our -- it's generally 2:1 relationship. So 2 jobs equal 1 household, and that 1 household covers both the for sale and the rental stocks. So we would start changing that ratio if we thought that any one of these factors became more significant.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it sounds like that's not a -- that's not something that you guys have looked into making any changes to yet [indiscernible]
componenttext: But it sounds like that's not a -- that's not something that you guys have looked into making any changes to yet [indiscernible]

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, that's not the right answer. In fact, right now, we're -- as I mentioned on last call that -- if based on the job growth in various submarkets, we could not explain why x amount of job growth, well, let's take L.A., for example, 176,000 jobs and
componenttext: Yes, no, that's not the right answer. In fact, right now, we're -- as I mentioned on last call that -- if based on the job growth in various submarkets, we could not explain why x amount of job growth, well, let's take L.A., for example, 176,000 jobs and given what I just said, should give us somewhere around 80,000, 85,000 households, and they're producing 32,000 units of total supply. So there should not be an issue there. And having said that, that's a 2:1 ratio. So our tendency is actually starting to push the 2:1 up to a higher ratio and actually doing that in connection with affordability as well, because people make different decisions based on relative affordability of apartments within marketplace. So it's all part of a discussion, but it's a larger discussion than Airbnb is my point.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Nick Joseph with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Nick Joseph with Citigroup.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, sticking with affordability. Can you talk about how rent-to-income metrics or any other ways that you measure affordability have changed over the last year?
componenttext: I guess, sticking with affordability. Can you talk about how rent-to-income metrics or any other ways that you measure affordability have changed over the last year?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick. They are -- they're increasing and have increased. This is Mike Schall, again. And again, going back to Northern California, last year, for example, where we had an incredible surge in rents, it pushed the affordability in San Francisco to abou
componenttext: Yes, Nick. They are -- they're increasing and have increased. This is Mike Schall, again. And again, going back to Northern California, last year, for example, where we had an incredible surge in rents, it pushed the affordability in San Francisco to about -- where we've been. It's well over the long-term high. So we have added almost 29%. And the long-term average is 26.5%, and the high is 33.1%. So we're starting to push beyond that range that people can afford. And our view is that affordability, basically, is a constraint. It doesn't mean that if it's super cheap, then that's good. It's just having a very low ratio can mean -- just have too much housing in the marketplace. That's obviously not a good thing either. But there are couple of markets in San Francisco and the Bay Area that are pushing that ratio to a level that we haven't seen in several -- in a couple of decades. So that is an area of concern. Having said that, with rents moderating this year and personal incomes increasing, it helps take pressure off of that ratio. So again, my view is that last year, we got, let's say, 2 years of rent growth in Northern California. And there's a little bit of a breather, part of that is caused by affordability, and part of that is pushing renters into the other markets, the East Bay, for example, where -- which is where we're getting the best rent growth this year. So it's part of the equation that we consider, again, when we start pushing up into the mid-20s. When people are paying 25%, let's say, or higher of the median income in rent or in their rent, then it starts becoming an issue.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: When was 33.1%? What year was that?
componenttext: When was 33.1%? What year was that?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was in -- I don't have the year. Was it 2000?
componenttext: That was in -- I don't have the year. Was it 2000?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was the dot-com.
componenttext: That was the dot-com.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that was the dot-com boom. But again, it's interesting because I've heard that comment made that Southern California -- actually, there's an AXIO chart that has this, but... Southern California, CAGRs of rent growth is the same in Northern -- as Nort
componenttext: Yes, that was the dot-com boom. But again, it's interesting because I've heard that comment made that Southern California -- actually, there's an AXIO chart that has this, but... Southern California, CAGRs of rent growth is the same in Northern -- as Northern California over the last 15 years. And -- but it misses the fact that rents in Northern California went up 40% in 2 years to establish this 33% ratio that I just referenced. So -- and the 15 year period misses that. It picks up the decline of rents over that period, but before that, in 2 years, rents went up about 40% in Northern California. So again, these things, they have to all be considered. These are just facts, and they have to be explained in context in order to be meaningful.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just quickly on the transaction market. Have you seen any changes in the buyer pool, either in terms of the number of bidders or the composition of those bidders?
componenttext: And just quickly on the transaction market. Have you seen any changes in the buyer pool, either in terms of the number of bidders or the composition of those bidders?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have. I mean, in general, there are fewer bidders, but there are certainly plenty of bids out there, and it's still an active marketplace. Again, I would characterize it as going from a marketplace where you have many bidders, several rounds of best an
componenttext: We have. I mean, in general, there are fewer bidders, but there are certainly plenty of bids out there, and it's still an active marketplace. Again, I would characterize it as going from a marketplace where you have many bidders, several rounds of best and finals, et cetera, to a marketplace that has fewer bidders, still pretty aggressive, still looking for product. Still see a number of the institutions involved in transactions. Some have talked about foreign buyers and investors being active in the marketplace. I think the REITs have generally taken a step back here.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Kim with BMO.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Kim with BMO.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on your commentary on Seattle, Mike. This period, you took up your market rent forecast by 240 basis points. But it sounds like you're a little bit cautious on the potential impact of supply in an answer to a prior question. Is
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on your commentary on Seattle, Mike. This period, you took up your market rent forecast by 240 basis points. But it sounds like you're a little bit cautious on the potential impact of supply in an answer to a prior question. Is this because this is very sensitive to employment growth? And can also talk about the rent-to-income ratio in Seattle versus San Francisco?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And maybe John or someone can help me out with this question. In general, so going back to the beginning of the year, we had Seattle as our weakest market. And it wasn't because we thought that there was some implosion intact or even a problem intac
componenttext: Sure. And maybe John or someone can help me out with this question. In general, so going back to the beginning of the year, we had Seattle as our weakest market. And it wasn't because we thought that there was some implosion intact or even a problem intact. It was just simply -- if you just look at the ratio of supply and demand, it looked like it was more exposed than either Northern California or Southern California. So that's what caused that. Again, we do this based on experience, history and judgment, and sometimes, we're wrong. And so certainly, that's the case in Seattle at this point in time. As to going forward, are we going to continue at 3.5% job growth in Seattle, which will take care of whatever supply the market can produce? I would guess that it's going to continue to be better than we think, but I don't know we can sustain 3.5%. I would -- I still rank our markets as -- in terms of desirability as Northern, Southern California, obviously, those big geography, but Northern and Southern California as being more desirable than Seattle because we've seen supply really get out of whack in Seattle in prior cycles, and so that's how we would judge it. California has all these various other elements where they're trying to convert from a suburban type housing profile to more of an urban high-rise residential around transit. That's going to be a long-term difficult thing to do, and I think it will have the overall impact of muting supply deliveries. So I guess, that's why we give California the urban core coastal California markets a little bit of a positive relative to Seattle. As it relates to the rent-to-median income, Seattle's current ratio is around 21%. The long-term average is around 18%. So this is a good example of the long-term average not being all that meaningful. You might say, "Yes, there's plenty of room for rents to grow there because it's only 18%." The problem is it's 18% because there's too much affordable housing in the marketplace. So the lower that ratio gets, the less pricing power you generally have in the marketplace. So that's why I say that rent-to-income acts mainly as a constraint not a sort of a driving force. So there's plenty of room for pricing, though Seattle has very high median household income levels in the $80,000 to $90,000 range, and the rents are pretty attractively priced. So I don't see that as a constraint.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And sticking to Seattle. It's not part of your development pipeline. So is your preferred method to increase any exposure, if you'd like to, through the preferred equity investment and through selective acquisition?
componenttext: Okay. And sticking to Seattle. It's not part of your development pipeline. So is your preferred method to increase any exposure, if you'd like to, through the preferred equity investment and through selective acquisition?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we would look to trade assets in Seattle. And actually, we're looking at the same strategy up and down the coast, not necessarily, for example, trading out of Northern California and into Southern California, which we have done in the past. W
componenttext: Yes. I think we would look to trade assets in Seattle. And actually, we're looking at the same strategy up and down the coast, not necessarily, for example, trading out of Northern California and into Southern California, which we have done in the past. We don't think we're at the point -- at that point in time. Again, the thing that makes us more cautious in Seattle in the long term is its ability to produce a lot of housing. And so it's going to probably remain our third choice, looking at things very big picture, relative to the 3 markets: Northern and Southern California and Seattle.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tom Lesnick with Capital One.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tom Lesnick with Capital One.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, it looks like a lot of the supply is concentrated in San Francisco proper and San Jose. What are the necessary conditions for that oversupply issue to begin to spread outside of San Jose and San Francisco in the Bay Area? And what is the m
componenttext: I guess, first, it looks like a lot of the supply is concentrated in San Francisco proper and San Jose. What are the necessary conditions for that oversupply issue to begin to spread outside of San Jose and San Francisco in the Bay Area? And what is the most likely scenario for further slowing in quality of jobs?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mike again. And John Eudy, who heads development and is Chief Investment Officer, along with Craig Zimmerman, can maybe comment on this as well. I think it's just rents and cost to build. So you need really high rents, and in order to pencil
componenttext: Yes, this is Mike again. And John Eudy, who heads development and is Chief Investment Officer, along with Craig Zimmerman, can maybe comment on this as well. I think it's just rents and cost to build. So you need really high rents, and in order to pencil a development deal, and where do you find those really high rents? You find them in San Francisco proper and on the Peninsula and in San Jose, and to some extent, in various parts of L.A., which, again, it has more supply than it's had over the last several years. So that's what moderates construction outside of the core areas. The rents aren't quite as high, and construction costs are pretty darn similar. And I guess, the issue that this brings up is how deep is the, A, tranche of the rental market because now we've had several years of delivering the As into the -- that top tier, how deep is that? How long can you continue to get those, achieve those rents before you're really dipping down into the B part of the renter pool, and you're making some of that top-level of the Bs. You're pushing them into the A product, which is, I think, part of the problem here. So again, we're watching that. I think there's a certain level at which we -- what California needs is more affordable housing. And the current solutions to this situation are to produce more, very high-end luxury housing. And so there's an obvious disconnect that needs to play out. Do you have any comments to that one, Mr. Eudy?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only other add, it would be the exactions of cities are getting now on the entitlement side add the burden of the cost. And then with construction lenders pulling back, as Mike mentioned earlier, you add all that up, and that speaks to why we're seein
componenttext: The only other add, it would be the exactions of cities are getting now on the entitlement side add the burden of the cost. And then with construction lenders pulling back, as Mike mentioned earlier, you add all that up, and that speaks to why we're seeing muted supplies next year and the following compared to what we've seen this year and the prior. And there's a lot of pressure to try to put deals together, but at the end of the day, the 4.5 cap development transactions, a lot of them aren't going to come to fruition that may be being bantered about, but have to be executed on. So we'll see.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that. And then my second question, having to do with the income mix. I mean, you guys are clearly doing demand forecast. But for those incremental jobs, what is the income mix of those jobs? And if so, how has that shifted over the last few qua
componenttext: Appreciate that. And then my second question, having to do with the income mix. I mean, you guys are clearly doing demand forecast. But for those incremental jobs, what is the income mix of those jobs? And if so, how has that shifted over the last few quarters, and how does that affect your future outlook?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Mike. We don't have perfect information there. I think the comment we would make is that there's some indication that the quality of jobs in Northern California has deteriorated somewhat. In other words, we have a ranking of all the different in
componenttext: Yes, it's Mike. We don't have perfect information there. I think the comment we would make is that there's some indication that the quality of jobs in Northern California has deteriorated somewhat. In other words, we have a ranking of all the different industries and what the average wages are within the industries. And so there's more, for example, in Northern California, more leisure hospitality jobs than there had been, typically, technology jobs, but again, in the short term, lots of things can happen. Actually, the flip is also true in Seattle. But in the short term, lots of things can happen. And if I've learned anything in this business, it's don't take a couple of bullet points or data points and start creating a trend line because you're going to often be wrong. I realize that human beings, in making decisions, have a number of biases, and then we try to work through those biases as thoughtful as we can. But I would hate to take some very short-term information, and then try to extrapolate what it means. And that's all we have at this point in time, and I don't think that any of it is conclusive. But I can say we're looking at it, and trying if we -- trying to see if we can determine what the longer-term implications of this divergence that I talked about in my opening remarks, which includes what you're talking about now. So we just don't know at this point.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question come from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question come from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, Mike, just a few questions here for you. First, Mike, just going back to Seattle, historically, the Seattle, San Francisco is sort linked as far as health of tech, but it sounds like those trends may have disconnected a bit. So is your view that
componenttext: So John, Mike, just a few questions here for you. First, Mike, just going back to Seattle, historically, the Seattle, San Francisco is sort linked as far as health of tech, but it sounds like those trends may have disconnected a bit. So is your view that the markets have disconnected or there's just, again, to your earlier point about don't take a data series -- or a data point and make a trend? Or is it just there's a little bit of nuance here, and therefore, the markets are still linked over time to tech, but right now, there's just a little bit of decoupling?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, I get to celebrate my 30th here, and Mr. Eudy has been here for 30 years, too, and he's been an amazing partner, and Mr. Burkart, for 20 years. We haven't -- we've seen this one time in 30 years. So now we're going to pay attention to this one d
componenttext: So again, I get to celebrate my 30th here, and Mr. Eudy has been here for 30 years, too, and he's been an amazing partner, and Mr. Burkart, for 20 years. We haven't -- we've seen this one time in 30 years. So now we're going to pay attention to this one divergence and ignore the last 30 years? I mean, that's essentially the dilemma that we're talking about. I mean, tech is tech. It's -- businesses are going to make decisions. People are going to make decisions based on the opportunity before them. They're going to live where they can afford to live in a good place, high quality of life, et cetera, and where would that opportunity present itself, they will find that. People are smart. They're smart when it comes to making rental decisions. They're smart when it comes to making career decisions for the most part. And so I wouldn't see any divergence at all. I think it's -- the market is fluid and things change. I think that you could have some tech companies opening more office space based on where their people want to work. That's a possibility. Having said that, as John said, there's millions of square feet being -- of commercial space being delivered here. And you have these tech giants, which have enormous amounts of cash and enormous financial capabilities that are building -- that are investing in these office buildings. Every part of the Silicon Valley, I think, has been essentially remade in a number of different ways. Well, I'll give you another staff that hasn't come up on these calls before, but there are at least 50 non-tech companies that have innovation centers here. John -- actually, John may have mentioned this in his remarks, but non-tech companies with innovation centers here because technology is so integrated in everything we do. So Alex, our -- my belief is that this is an anomaly, not a trend. And as a result of that, things will go back to a more normal balance between the 2 markets.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then going to Southern Cal, where, like L.A, you've had a lot of permits, I think, the fourth biggest metro for permits. Given what we've seen of the overbuilding of the high end in San Francisco and New York, where that's all that penciled, is
componenttext: Okay. And then going to Southern Cal, where, like L.A, you've had a lot of permits, I think, the fourth biggest metro for permits. Given what we've seen of the overbuilding of the high end in San Francisco and New York, where that's all that penciled, is your view that the supply coming online in L.A., again, is all high end? And you think it's going to be an impact as those permits are put into the ground? Or because of either where it's located or just the size of the market that, that supply will be absorbed in a normal fashion?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is John. Number one, you're right on L.A. as far as the total number of permits, but it's a huge market. So we always look at it in a sense of percentages, and then that kind of changes that perspective. But where the supply is located in those
componenttext: Alex, this is John. Number one, you're right on L.A. as far as the total number of permits, but it's a huge market. So we always look at it in a sense of percentages, and then that kind of changes that perspective. But where the supply is located in those pockets, it's very competitive. There's no question about that. The downtown location and other -- Playa Vista. And so it's submarket by submarket, but in the supply U.S., what is it in the sense of A, B? Pretty much anything getting delivered these days is A-quality. So the competition is high if you're an A-quality building across the street from a lease-up. It's very high, and to the degree that you're a B and submarket away, it's not so much. So as we said, Woodland Hills performed well, CBD, a little bit lesser. So does that answer your question?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, but do you -- as the stuff comes online, are we going to see sort of -- in '17, are we going to be hearing about sort of horror stories about 2 months free all over L.A. impacting apartments? Or it's just not big enough to really impact the way w
componenttext: So John, but do you -- as the stuff comes online, are we going to see sort of -- in '17, are we going to be hearing about sort of horror stories about 2 months free all over L.A. impacting apartments? Or it's just not big enough to really impact the way we're seeing it impact in San Francisco and San Jose?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't expect horror story. I don't expect that, Alex. I think that was a combination of a little bit less job growth and the supply hitting in the fourth quarter. NorCal and Seattle tend to be more seasonal. SoCal is less seasonal, and so Southern Calif
componenttext: I don't expect horror story. I don't expect that, Alex. I think that was a combination of a little bit less job growth and the supply hitting in the fourth quarter. NorCal and Seattle tend to be more seasonal. SoCal is less seasonal, and so Southern California, I don't expect to see horror stories in the fourth quarter.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Karin Ford with MUFG.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Karin Ford with MUFG.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There was an article in The Wall Street Journal talking about Facebook building 1,500 new units for the general public on its land on Menlo Park. I know it's coming along with 6,500 new jobs from them, but tech companies, obviously, have a low cost capita
componenttext: There was an article in The Wall Street Journal talking about Facebook building 1,500 new units for the general public on its land on Menlo Park. I know it's coming along with 6,500 new jobs from them, but tech companies, obviously, have a low cost capital, incentives to accept lower returns. Do you see this as a potential source of new supply in the Bay Area?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, it's absolutely new supply, but in the sense if you mean competition with technology companies building multi-family, I don't expect that. In the articles that I read, I think what was -- what they're try to achieve was get approv
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, it's absolutely new supply, but in the sense if you mean competition with technology companies building multi-family, I don't expect that. In the articles that I read, I think what was -- what they're try to achieve was get approvals for their development. There's been a lot of stress, of course, in rents, and so they were trying to build a more balanced development, where they had some housing, as well as the jobs related construction for the office space. So I don't think they're going to be in the business of building multi-family.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you hearing of any other tech companies looking to do something similar?
componenttext: Are you hearing of any other tech companies looking to do something similar?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I haven't, no.
componenttext: I haven't, no.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my second question is just for Mike. Just going back to the cap rate question. In your experience, how severe and how prolonged would the growth slowdown need to be before we should expect to see a change in cap rates?
componenttext: Okay. And my second question is just for Mike. Just going back to the cap rate question. In your experience, how severe and how prolonged would the growth slowdown need to be before we should expect to see a change in cap rates?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Karin, and I'm not sure I have an easy answer. Cap rates tend to be pretty sticky because the first thing that happens is buyers and sellers do not agree on what the price is. So sellers remember the last 10 transactions, and buyers
componenttext: It's a good question, Karin, and I'm not sure I have an easy answer. Cap rates tend to be pretty sticky because the first thing that happens is buyers and sellers do not agree on what the price is. So sellers remember the last 10 transactions, and buyers think the world has changed and so they demand something different. And so that can go on for some period of time, and you would see it in the transaction volumes when the deals are closed. Normally, the things that motivate transactions are financial distress and those types of things, which, in a world of positive leverage, we don't really see that happening, and really great economics as well. So I would say that you would have to see maybe, I'd say, a year before you really saw a real directional change in cap rates because, again, I think you're going to end up with a derth of transactions in the meantime. Maybe the derth of transactions will be the indicator that. Maybe something is changing, but you won't actually see a change for some period of time.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Wes Galloday with RBC.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Wes Galloday with RBC.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the concession comment, you said they were down. Just curious if it's starting to spread, though, to other submarkets, getting outside the core.
componenttext: Looking at the concession comment, you said they were down. Just curious if it's starting to spread, though, to other submarkets, getting outside the core.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No, the concessions really started -- they're standard, of course, with development lease-ups. You're typically -- commonly, it's 4 weeks, and what happened is concessions moved up. People got a little bit more aggressive when the demand was in the sl
componenttext: No. No, the concessions really started -- they're standard, of course, with development lease-ups. You're typically -- commonly, it's 4 weeks, and what happened is concessions moved up. People got a little bit more aggressive when the demand was in the slow season, and so that moved up to 6 to 8 weeks, and now it's moved down. But other than assets that are -- head-on competition and brand your asset next to a lease-up, there's not a lot of concessions in the market, and we do not see it spreading outside of those very competitive zones where the lease-ups are.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And do you have a loss-to-lease for the portfolio and maybe North California?

componenttextpreview: Sure. So loss-to-lease for the portfolio overall is about 5%, and for Northern California right now, it's about 5.2%.
componenttext: Sure. So loss-to-lease for the portfolio overall is about 5%, and for Northern California right now, it's about 5.2%.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next questions come from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next questions come from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Angela, maybe you did this, I missed it, but can you break out that $0.11 that offsets the downdraft that allowed you to raise guidance this quarter, other factors outside of same-store?
componenttext: So Angela, maybe you did this, I missed it, but can you break out that $0.11 that offsets the downdraft that allowed you to raise guidance this quarter, other factors outside of same-store?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy to. So we beat by $0.08 last quarter, and by $0.08 this quarter, so that gets you to the $0.16, right? And we raised by $0.06 for the year. So the remaining $0.10 is really the breakout. So $0.05 of that $0.10 is timing-related. So these are G
componenttext: Sure, happy to. So we beat by $0.08 last quarter, and by $0.08 this quarter, so that gets you to the $0.16, right? And we raised by $0.06 for the year. So the remaining $0.10 is really the breakout. So $0.05 of that $0.10 is timing-related. So these are G&A items and other items that we'll spend in the second half of the year. And $0.05 were really more of the -- and by the way, I'm only talking same-store, just so we're clear. And the other $0.05 were the really more of the one-time spend. So the $0.05 was the lower same-store growth, so that's the other $0.05 hit.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. I'll -- maybe I'll talk to you offline. So let's sort of imagine for a moment, like you said, that we can go to a more normalized balance between Seattle and San Francisco in the future. How -- and I guess, this is a question for Mike or whomev
componenttext: Yes, okay. I'll -- maybe I'll talk to you offline. So let's sort of imagine for a moment, like you said, that we can go to a more normalized balance between Seattle and San Francisco in the future. How -- and I guess, this is a question for Mike or whomever. How does that not mean there'll be a meaningful deceleration next year if that does, in fact, happen since Seattle has basically kind of come to the rescue so far this year?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Mike. I don't know. It's interesting. If I would have said to you that we got 5% rent growth in Northern California this year and 12% last year, that's 17%. If, let's say, it happened at 8.5% and 8.5%, I think we all would have been really h
componenttext: Rich, this is Mike. I don't know. It's interesting. If I would have said to you that we got 5% rent growth in Northern California this year and 12% last year, that's 17%. If, let's say, it happened at 8.5% and 8.5%, I think we all would have been really happy with that because we can't sustain the amount of growth that we've had. Again, I think that we've missed how incredibly great Northern California has done, and we've assumed maybe partially because it's done so great that it has to do very poorly in the future. I don't follow that logic. I don't think that that's right. I think that we can end up with a more normal growth rate in Northern California, and this business works just fine. So I'd be the first to tell you that getting 12% rent growth in a year, as we did in 2015, it's great while it's happening, but it has a secondary effect. And we're seeing part of that secondary effect this year because, again, it stretches affordabilities. It does -- it has implications beyond that 1 year. So I don't think that the fact that you're seeing a slowdown this year, again, relative to what happened last year, the extraordinary year we had last year, is being somehow indicative of what's going to happen next year. I don't -- I just don't see it. I think...

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So you're saying that the closing of that gap is a sort of a decline in Seattle and a similar level of improvement in the Bay Area. Is that what you're saying?
componenttext: All right. So you're saying that the closing of that gap is a sort of a decline in Seattle and a similar level of improvement in the Bay Area. Is that what you're saying?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's just say that the Bay Area goes to be a more normal market as opposed to an extraordinary market that it's been for the last several years. Again, these businesses, our business was not founded upon 6% annual rent growth for long, long periods
componenttext: Well, let's just say that the Bay Area goes to be a more normal market as opposed to an extraordinary market that it's been for the last several years. Again, these businesses, our business was not founded upon 6% annual rent growth for long, long periods of time because income levels have to -- have some relationship to rent levels in order for people to afford it. So there are constraints within this industry or within the housing markets that will constrain you ultimately. Again, it doesn't mean that we're going to go from being a great market to a lousy market. And I think that maybe investors are focused on the Great Recession, which I think was an extraordinary period of time or the Internet boom bust period, where that often neglect the fact that rents went up 40% in 2 years, and then went all the way back down in the ensuing 3 years. But nonetheless, those things, I think, are dominant in people's memories, and -- but I think that the normal cycles would not be nearly that extreme. So again, I think Northern California goes back to being a more normal market. What does that mean? It means, let's say, 3% to 4% revenue growth, let's say, we're going to add some value in renovation and maybe we can add some value in transactions, and the business runs well at that, with that.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how are you able to confidently -- or maybe you're not, but you have this kind of lumpiness effect to your supply in the Bay Area this year. Do you -- is there a way to judge that for next year and have a relative level of confidence that,
componenttext: Okay. And then how are you able to confidently -- or maybe you're not, but you have this kind of lumpiness effect to your supply in the Bay Area this year. Do you -- is there a way to judge that for next year and have a relative level of confidence that, that won't be the case again or is that kind of a wildcard as well?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, in the sense that -- this is John. In the sense of what buildings are out there, it's pretty easy to judge or people drive all the sites and they know what's out there. The thing that moves around a little bit relates to construction timing.
componenttext: Well, I mean, in the sense that -- this is John. In the sense of what buildings are out there, it's pretty easy to judge or people drive all the sites and they know what's out there. The thing that moves around a little bit relates to construction timing. What we expect to happen doesn't necessarily happen. Things get -- tend be slowed down a little bit, and they get pushed into the future period. So to the extent that things get slowed down, they get pushed into a future period. It's to the benefit of the current period, right? And that's a little bit what happened last year. So it's not perfect, but I don't want to give the impression that we can't know the buildings. We know the buildings very well. We literally drive the buildings and have detailed spreadsheets outlining each building and what's going on. It's just, as far as CFOs and when they start to lease-up and get occupied, that moves around a little bit, and it frankly always moves out. It never really surprises us in the sense of being sooner.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I mean, no one's asking you for a perfect crystal ball. But based on what you're seeing right now, you think there's that lumpiness effect that happened this year, who knows for sure? But it feels like it maybe a little bit more of a typical pat
componenttext: Right. So I mean, no one's asking you for a perfect crystal ball. But based on what you're seeing right now, you think there's that lumpiness effect that happened this year, who knows for sure? But it feels like it maybe a little bit more of a typical pattern next year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Currently, it's does. Yes. I think it's really difficult...
componenttext: Currently, it's does. Yes. I think it's really difficult...

componenttext: Yes, actually, it's interesting. Our economics department, we have it broken down by quarter. But they said, "Please don't give that out on the phone call." So it's really challenging to get this exactly right so....

So that gets you to the math.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, okay, great. That makes sense. componenttext: Well, the -- so you're right about Northern California. componenttext: Okay. And then into '17, Mike or John, on that, what's your forecast for Oakland? Do you see that if rent growth in San Francisco is taking it hardest this year, do you expect there to be a greater impact on East Bay rents or rents that are pricing off of San Francisco?

componenttextpreview: It's all relative, obviously. So and with -- well, the one issue we have here throughout California is lack of transit, which, I think, you know a little bit about and traffic, snarl traffic. So people, in general, don't want to commute unless you're righ
componenttext: It's all relative, obviously. So and with -- well, the one issue we have here throughout California is lack of transit, which, I think, you know a little bit about and traffic, snarl traffic. So people, in general, don't want to commute unless you're right against a BART line. And that's why Mr. Eudy has a couple of development deals that are actually near public transit to do it. But basically, I think that there will be maybe some movement because of relationships. I think what's happening is, again, you're producing more in the A category, and you're pulling some B, the top echelon of the Bs into the As because with concessions there and a net effect that it's too close to what some of the Bs are. So I think the movement probably is more the other way, that you're pulling people out of the Oakland MSA and into the city because the net effectives aren't that different, is I think what's happening. But if there's not enough supply, to answer your question, not enough supply in the East Bay to really make a difference.

componenttext: Just a bigger picture one for you, Mike. But at the same time, I think, as you've alluded to, cap rates haven't really moved and valuations haven't moved, has there been times in the past, where those 2 things can disconnect where lenders are pricing in more risk but investors are not?

componenttext: Yes. Mike, I guess, Dennis, welcome to the call. That will be something that I don't think I've seen in 30 years as well. The lenders, at the -- let's say, we're not -- say we're in the second half of the cycle somewhere. And the lenders, at some point, tend to get more aggressive. John and I have seen loan-to-cost or actually loan-to-values on construction loans get to 75%. And now we're somewhere in the 55% to 60% loan-to-cost. I don't think we've ever seen really this amount of discipline by the lenders ever. So I think it's kind of an extraordinary time in that I think the banks have been -- it's probably a bad word, but somewhat neutered in terms of what they're able to do, probably for fear of too big to fail in a variety of other political issues. So...
