headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forward-loo
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Essex Property Trust Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. 
Statements made on this conference call regarding expected operating results and other future events are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Forward-looking statements are made based on current expectations, assumptions and beliefs as well as information available to the company at this time. A number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Further information about these risks can be found in the company's filings with the SEC.
[Operator Instructions] 
It is now a pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Michael Schall, President and Chief Executive Officer for Essex Property Trust. Thank you, Mr. Schall. You may begin.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. John Burkart, Angela Kleiman and I will make brief comments, followed by Q&A. I will discuss the following 3 topics: the third quarter results and current condition
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us today, and welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. John Burkart, Angela Kleiman and I will make brief comments, followed by Q&A. I will discuss the following 3 topics: the third quarter results and current conditions, our 2017 preliminary market forecast and an update on investment market.
First topic. We are pleased with the company's performance during the quarter in which we reacted opportunistically to rapidly changing conditions. As a result, we exceeded our core FFO per share guidance for the quarter by $0.05. I thank the E-team for their great effort and results. 
Similar to the second quarter, Q3 was challenging from an operations perspective against a very tough comp in 2015. Job growth remains strong relative to the U.S., especially in Seattle, where September month-over-month job growth increased from the prior year to 3.5% in 2016 versus 3.2% at September 2015.
Northern California continues to significantly outperform the U.S. in job growth, although it has decelerated. For example, in San Francisco, September 2016 job growth was reported at 2.6%, significantly below 5.1% reported for September 2015. Southern California job growth was significantly better than the nation in Orange County and San Diego and slightly behind in Los Angeles and Ventura. Overall, against the backdrop of decelerating U.S. job growth, the West Coast economies continue to outperform.
Rent growth continued to be muted in Northern California, which we attribute to the large concessions being offered by lease-up subcommunities. Job quality, ranked by annual salary levels for each industry, was another issue in Northern California, as there were more service jobs and fewer tech jobs being produced. In San Jose, for example, approximately 10% of the jobs created year-to-date were in the highest-paying information and manufacturing industries as compared to about 32% in 2015. Less significant deterioration in job quality occurred in San Francisco and Seattle. 
It's not surprising that more service jobs are being created, given the wealth effect to related to the financial success of so many tech companies and their highly compensated workforce. Our venture-capital contacts tell us that there is considerable movement of personnel within the technology industries as the next wave of new products, services and companies emerge.
Recent loss of pricing power in Northern California and a few other submarkets could indicate that we've achieved equilibrium between housing supply and demand. We don't believe that this is correct, and we use historical data from San Francisco and San Jose metros to demonstrate.
For the period 2011 to 2016, San Francisco and San Jose have produced about 440,000 jobs. Assuming 2 jobs equals 1 household, that would equate to demand for about 220,000 homes. The actual total housing units built over that period was about 65,500 or less than 1/3 of the expected demand that would ordinarily result from 440,000 jobs. 
We experienced exceptional pricing power in San Francisco and San Jose from 2011 to 2015, and the delivery of about 10,000 apartments in 2016, which are included in the 65,500 previously noted, has done little, we believe, to eliminate the pent-up demand from prior years, which leaves us with the question of why such large concessions are required if there is so much pent-up demand. We believe that the answer to that question relates to the concentrations of supply, the fundamentally different financial objectives of the apartment lease-up versus the stabilized community and affordability factors. 
Apartment developers, in an effort to minimize overall free rent over the lease-up period, typically set absorption targets of 25 to 30 leases per month. In some markets, as many as 5 lease-ups are directly competing for this leased volume. That means that over 100 leases per month are needed in that submarket to achieve leasing velocity targets. Recent job growth does not generate sufficient demand, and so large concessions drove renters out of stabilized communities. 
2 months free rent, again, equating to 16% of annual rent, drives that absorption and, at least temporarily, resolves the affordability problem at the same time. We see this as a short-term phenomena that will likely clear the market as supply deliveries decline in 2017.
Higher incomes are probably the most important solution to the affordability issue. Many renters are displaced by large rent increases and search for more affordable housing when rents grow faster than income levels. The opposite occurs when incomes begin to grow faster than rents, which is now happening. In Q3 '16 as compared to the comparable period of 2015, San Francisco and San Jose are estimated to have produced 6% growth in median household income, which is a huge growth rate that improves affordability relative to a year ago. As to supply, we expect about a 20% drop in apartment supply in San Francisco and nearly 30% in San Jose in 2017 and fewer deliveries in each quarter throughout 2017.
Therefore, we expect supply pressures to moderate in Northern California, especially in the second half of the year, assuming, of course, that job growth remains on track. Southern California apartment supply will be similar to 2016 and will decelerate throughout 2017 with the exception of Orange County, which is expected to have a 30% to 40% increase in supply. 
I wanted to provide a quick update on rent control. There are ballot proposals to enact rent control in 5 Northern California cities. While slower rent growth has removed some of the motivation for rent control, there are well-organized finance groups that are pushing ahead. At this point, we expect some, but not all, of the ballot proposals to pass. In any event, these measures are not expected to have a significant impact on the company for reasons provided in previous conference calls.
On to my second topic, market outlook for 2017. Page 16 of the supplement provides an overview of the key housing supply-demand and economic assumptions supporting our market rent growth expectation for 2017. As before, our macroeconomic scenario for the U.S. relies on leading third-party sources. The Essex economics will then estimate how the national economic picture will impact housing supply and demand for each submarket we have selected for potential investment. 
For 2017, the U.S. economy is expected to experience muted growth, with U.S. GDP and job growth of 2.2% and 1.6%, respectively. This year, we made 3 notable changes to our assumptions that are incorporated into F '16, including: first, we've modified our definition of multi-family supply to be similar to AXIOMetrics, which includes multi-family properties under development with at least 50 units and exclude senior, student and 100% affordable communities. We diligence this information by driving each property to understand delivery schedules, phasing and removed project duplication. Therefore, our supply estimate should differ from the data vendors. We have observed that the various research providers estimate supply in a variety of ways, often with materially conflicting conclusions. We hope others will follow our lead with respect to using a similar supply methodology. 
Second, as we approach the top of the cycle, development deliveries are often delayed due to shortages of trained construction personnel. This causes some development deals to be pushed into the following year. Thus, some of our 2016 scheduled deliveries have been moved into 2017, and the same thing may happen at the end of 2017. Therefore, our supply estimates may be too high. 
Third, as noted in my previous comments, the typical relationship between supply and demand disconnected in Northern California in 2016. There is no historical precedent for the adjustments we made to consider affordability that represent our best judgment. 
Notably, on Page S-16, each of our West Coast metros is expected to outperform the national average job growth. In each metro, again, assuming that 2 jobs equals 1 household, housing demand exceeds total expected housing supply that's both rental and for sale. The resulting 2017 market economic rent growth is slightly above the long-term CAGR of rent growth in Southern California and Seattle and slightly below in Northern California. 
In summary, 2017 seems likely to produce a soft landing. Thus, the extraordinary rent growth in last several years should transition to the long-term averages in the Essex portfolio. 
And now the third topic, investments. We experienced a relatively quiet quarter from an investment standpoint, as outlined in the press release. During the quarter, the stock traded mostly at or below net asset value, making accretive acquisitions challenging to execute on a match-funded basis. We expect to be more active in the fourth quarter, with all new deals being funded with disposition proceeds. 
Cap rates remained stable in the last quarter, with 8 quality property and locations trading around the 4% to 4.25% cap rate using the Essex methodology, and from time to time, more aggressive buyers will pay sub-4 cap rates. Generally, there are fewer motivated apartment investors in the market as compared to a year ago. We don't see cap rates changing materially, given the extraordinary amount of positive leverage that is generated when cap rates average around 4.5% and if 7-year fixed rate loan is approximately 3%.
In connection with our preferred equity program, we look at both existings and could-be developed apartment communities that are consistent with the Essex portfolio. Recently, we've noticed an increasing number of development transactions that don't meet our criteria, typically used -- due to increased costs of construction and conservative construction lending practices. This supports our belief that 2017 will represent the peak of supply in Coastal California. 
That concludes my comments. Thank you for joining our call today. I'll now turn the call over to John Burkart.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. The Essex team had another good quarter, delivering total same-store revenue growth of 6.9% and NOI growth of 8.3% relative to the comparable quarter. I want to thank our associates for their daily commitment in providing exceptional cust
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. The Essex team had another good quarter, delivering total same-store revenue growth of 6.9% and NOI growth of 8.3% relative to the comparable quarter. I want to thank our associates for their daily commitment in providing exceptional customer service and for their enthusiasm in achieving our company objectives and helping make this possible.
Our markets are reaching the point with the strong performance in Southern California will enable the region to outperform Northern California, although this quarter, they both were equal at 6.5% revenue growth. 
In Seattle, the strong demand in the market, fueled by above-expectation employment growth, enabled the market to absorb the new supply and continue to grow revenues. Our Seattle portfolio grew revenues 8.5% in the third quarter of 2016 relative to the comparable quarter. The CBD submarket outperformed expectations, growing revenue approximately 7%. Eastside North and South submarkets, where over 80% of our portfolio is located, all grew revenues between 8.4% and 10.8% in the third quarter of 2016 relative to the comparable quarter.
During the quarter, the market absorbed 950,000 square feet of office space or about 1% of total stock. Amazon continued to expand with over 10,000 posted job openings and signing another 360,000-square-foot office lease for a building under construction located in Bellevue where the company was founded. Currently, there is approximately 7.2 million square feet of office space under construction, with 41% of it preleased. 
In contrast to the strength of Seattle, the Bay Area rental market has been impacted by affordability and aggressive lease-ups. Currently, AXIO shows September rent in San Francisco and the San Jose markets relatively flat compared to the beginning of the year. Submarkets that are most impacted are those with higher levels of new supply and related lease-up concession. 
Concessions in the marketplace vary. They are driven by the concentrations of high-end lease-ups, which are largely podium and high-rise buildings where, in order to obtain this occupancy, the entire property needs to be largely completed, resulting in hundreds of rent-ready units in each property hitting the market simultaneously. Generally, the lease-up managers generously give away concession to achieve certain coupon rent and absorption goals. In certain markets with concentrations of supply such as San Francisco and South San Jose, we are seeing selected cases where managers are providing 2 months free rent or more.
During the quarter, we completed the lease-up of Agora, a 49-unit luxury property in Downtown Walnut Creek, and continued to successfully lease-up The Galloway at Pleasanton, BART station. Currently, Galloway is 63% leased, and in order to maintain leasing velocity, we've increased concessions to about 6 weeks per lease, which is up from 4 weeks offered during the peak demand season of the summer.
Office absorption continues to be positive in all 3 Bay Area markets, with over 800,000 square feet being absorbed in the quarter. Some of the quarter's leasing activity included General Electric expanding their footprint, adding additional 100,000 square feet in San Ramon; and Google signing a lease to occupy the entire Moffatt [ph] Gateway campus, which is approximately 612,000 square feet. Currently, 11.5 million square feet of office space is under construction in the Bay Area, of which 46% is preleased.
Moving down to Southern California. The region continues to be a solid performer overall. In the L.A. market, CBD grew revenues 4% in the third quarter compared to the prior year's quarter, as it continues to absorb the new supply. The Woodland Hills and Tri-Cities submarkets continue to be strongest in the L.A. market, growing revenues about 8%. 
In Orange County, the North Orange submarket continues to outperform the South Orange submarket in the third quarter, with revenues growing 6% and 4.4%, respectively. With 1.9 million square feet of office space under construction, this will support the addition of approximately 11,000 jobs in the Orange County market. 
Finally, revenues increased 8.4% in San Diego, with northern submarkets outperforming the CBD and southern submarkets relative to comparable quarter. 
Third quarter office absorption in these 3 Southern California markets was over 1.4 million square feet, with San Diego leading the way absorbing almost 1% of total stock. 
Currently, our portfolio occupancy is at 96.7%, and our availability 30 days out is 4.4%. Our renewals on average are being sent out at about 4.5% for Northern California, a little over 5% for Southern California and about 6.3% in the Pacific Northwest. 
We are positioned well for the end of the year and 2017. 
Thank you, and I will turn the call over to Angela Kleiman.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Today, I will discuss our quarterly results, the full year outlook and comment on the balance sheet. We are pleased to report that our core FFO per share exceeded the high end of our guidance. The outperformance this quarter was primarily
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Today, I will discuss our quarterly results, the full year outlook and comment on the balance sheet. 
We are pleased to report that our core FFO per share exceeded the high end of our guidance. The outperformance this quarter was primarily attributed to favorable operation, accretive investments and lower G&A, some of which is timing-related. 
Turning to the full year outlook. We are reaffirming the mid-point of our same-property guidance of 6.8% revenue growth and 8.1% NOI growth. As for core FFO, we have increased the mid-point by $0.05 per share to $11.03. We are now projecting a 12.3% year-over-year core FFO growth, which represents our sixth consecutive year of double-digit growth. 
On to the balance sheet. Our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio improved to 5.7x this quarter from 5.9x last quarter, primarily due to continued growth in EBITDA. In addition, we received an upgrade on our senior unsecured debt rating for Moody's to Baa1 AND FROM S&P to BBB+, with stable outlook. The upgrades substantiated the strength of our balance sheet and our improved debt metric. The rating agencies also based their upgrade on the solid operating track records and long-term favorable economic fundamentals in our select West Coast markets. We believe this upgrade will enhance our cost of debt capital going forward. 
That concludes my comments. I will now turn the call back to the operator for questions.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to just get a little bit more color from you about the comments about the peak in occupancy or, excuse me, the peak in supply in 2017. Does that mean you see the supply pressures still accelerating into 2017? And then looking forward into 2018,
componenttext: So I want to just get a little bit more color from you about the comments about the peak in occupancy or, excuse me, the peak in supply in 2017. Does that mean you see the supply pressures still accelerating into 2017? And then looking forward into 2018, when do you really start to see these supply pressures starting to decelerate and maybe providing a little bit more relief for many of the reasons that you mentioned?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Mike. I would say, what we're seeing is movement of some of the supply from 2016 into 2017, and we see it continuing at a pretty significant level through about mid-year in 2017 and then dropping off pretty significantly from that point. And
componenttext: Rich, this is Mike. I would say, what we're seeing is movement of some of the supply from 2016 into 2017, and we see it continuing at a pretty significant level through about mid-year in 2017 and then dropping off pretty significantly from that point. And again, I think that there's a lot of deals being discussed here on the West Coast. The issue is, because of construction cost increases, delays in the cities are very busy and the construction lending environment, which is becoming more and more conservative, that is starting to make deals push them off or and/or they're not achieving the level of return required to make the deals work. So we're seeing those deals being pushed off. And so that is -- that gives us confidence that the supply that's underway is -- will be delivered and will be delivered late, and hence, the movement from supply from 2016 into 2017. But it gives us confidence that we're going to see a pretty significant slowdown in the middle of 2017.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. Just 2 quick follow-up questions about that. Your same-store revenue growth and same-store NOI growth, is -- should we think about that as the steady state right now, with supply pressures being moved into 2017? And then as a follow-up to that, thank you very much for the disclosure on the high-end job growth. That's really helpful. Did I hear you correctly that you thought that high-end job growth would begin to reaccelerate as some new products are coming to market?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, hitting that one first, we don't know. We can't tell you. We think that there will continue to be more service jobs created and more services consumed for the reasons noted, mainly that we have a very high-income workforce and they're going to consu
componenttext: Well, hitting that one first, we don't know. We can't tell you. We think that there will continue to be more service jobs created and more services consumed for the reasons noted, mainly that we have a very high-income workforce and they're going to consume more services. So we feel pretty confident with that. We do think that there'll be more tech jobs. Again, we think that tech is going through essentially a retrenchment or, really, defining what the next chapter is going to be in tech, which is a variety of things. For example, the Internet of Things, the use of Big Data, more mobile applications, sensors and security devices as it relates to many, many applications, including apartments, for example, sustainability and fiber. So there's a whole bunch of things that are happening in the tech world that are being pursued, but we're not really seeing it in the job numbers yet. So again, we view the tech industry as an ongoing revolutionary type of process, and -- but it's not a straight line. And so -- but we expect it to take on more momentum as we get into the next -- get through the next couple of years.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Got it. Helpful. And the same-store revenue growth, is that sort of a steady state that we can expect at this point, you think? I know it's hard to project.

componenttext: Yes, it's hard. I mean, we don't want to get into giving guidance at this point in time. But from our perspective here, we think that probably Q1 and Q2 will be a little weaker. You have our market forecast expectations on F '16, so you know what the overall view is for the year. But if I were to look at the first part of the year versus the second part of the year, I think we'll have somewhat of a slow start and then pick up momentum as we go through 2017.

componenttext: And then for the 27 [ph] economic rent growth forecast, when you think about the potential variability in each region, which regions are you most or, I guess, which region are you most confident in? And which has the widest range of potential outcomes?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's see. That's a good question. I would always point to Southern California as being more stable. We don't -- it's more like U.S. It doesn't have, really, the upside or the downside typically because you've got more pieces to the economy, and they tend
componenttext: Let's see. That's a good question. I would always point to Southern California as being more stable. We don't -- it's more like U.S. It doesn't have, really, the upside or the downside typically because you've got more pieces to the economy, and they tend to move slower. What I think about Northern California and Seattle, I think, overall, over the long term, it grows faster, but it's more volatile as it's generating faster growth over the longer period of time. So I think that's always the case. I don't think there's anything unique about right now. Southern California is closer to the U.S. economy. Northern California has the ability to move aggressively, a little bit aggressively in both directions. And you're seeing part of that. I mean, affordability is the concern about Northern California because demand grew so quickly, and we have such great pricing power that rents were growing much faster than incomes. And you can do that for some period of time. And -- but at some point, rents and incomes have to reconcile with one another over the long haul.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Omotayo Okusanya from Jefferies.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: First of all, big congratulations on putting up such great numbers against the backdrop you're operating in. Just on Northern California, in general, again, you look at the AXIOMetrics data, [indiscernible] very green pixel. We look at our results, and you guys are still doing very, very well. Just trying to understanding again how you're managing against all that pressure from aggressive developers trying to fill up their building, their concession, the store job growth? I mean, is it just the quality of the portfolio in regards to owning a lot of assets not at the very high end of the market? Is it -- what exactly are you guys doing that is creating this kind of massive alpha?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Tayo, for raising that. I would like to believe it's because we have the smartest operations team led by Mr. Burkart. So we'll give him a shoutout on that point. But I think that if you look at the AXIO charts, what we saw this year was a
componenttext: Well, thank you, Tayo, for raising that. I would like to believe it's because we have the smartest operations team led by Mr. Burkart. So we'll give him a shoutout on that point. But I think that if you look at the AXIO charts, what we saw this year was a pretty weak peak leasing season. And so I think what John and his team did was anticipate and really understand and execute around that. And so -- but I don't want to steal John's thunder. John, what did you do that was magical this quarter?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I prayed a lot. No, as Mike said, we changed our strategy. Typically, the software will do what I call is actually closing the leasing door where it takes certain units, it holds them out above market, trying to identify top potential market rent. And so
componenttext: I prayed a lot. No, as Mike said, we changed our strategy. Typically, the software will do what I call is actually closing the leasing door where it takes certain units, it holds them out above market, trying to identify top potential market rent. And so we made some changes to the settings to bring those units to market, which enabled us to gain occupancy during the peak demand period and positioned us very well going into the fourth quarter. That strategic change, plus the loss-to-lease that we had, taking advantage of that as well as, quite frankly, nickels and dimes, executing in all different -- many different places from collections to reducing models, et cetera, we worked very hard, and I'm very proud of the team. They did a great job.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Nick, it's Mike. This is supposed to be market rents. They're not the Essex portfolio, but all the assets in the submarkets in which we are invested, waited as if it was our portfolio. And so we're not trying to make a comment at all about Essex or As versus Bs or anything else. Just broadly speaking, what do we expect the submarket to do, taking market rents at the beginning of the year versus the end of the year.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess, when we look here at, like, Northern California, 2.5%, that's harder than, I guess, where the latest sort of monthly AXIOMetrics has been what is sort of actual no growth or slightly negative. Is there some sort of difference in -- and y
componenttext: Okay. So I guess, when we look here at, like, Northern California, 2.5%, that's harder than, I guess, where the latest sort of monthly AXIOMetrics has been what is sort of actual no growth or slightly negative. Is there some sort of difference in -- and you're assuming that rents actually do start growing across the market next year? I'm just trying to try to reconcile that.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the question that I would ask rhetorically back to you is, how many straight lines do you see on these rent graphs? And pretty much, the answer is none. They don't act in a straight line. They move. So yes, if you look at September alone, you
componenttext: Yes, I think the question that I would ask rhetorically back to you is, how many straight lines do you see on these rent graphs? And pretty much, the answer is none. They don't act in a straight line. They move. So yes, if you look at September alone, you say, "Okay, that -- let us extrapolate and figure out where things are going from there," I think you end up with a bad answer because I would say, what impact, as of September, that seasonality have on the overall result? We already know that we have affordability issue, we have too much supply in the form of these lease-ups to offering typically 16% off on your annual rents. And then now we have thus affordability factor layered on top of that. No one can disaggregate what each of those pieces mean. So by focusing exclusively on September, I think that you're making an implicit assumption that, hey, this is the way it's going, and it's going to continue that way. We don't believe that if you look at -- just look at the AXIO chart for San Francisco, San Jose, any of the Northern California markets, there was a point at which we were getting 2% to 3% -- 2% to 4% rent growth. And again, trying to stagger leases so we could take advantage of that, made good decisions with respect to building occupancy during the ride period of time allows you to have some ability to manage around that. And so I wouldn't focus too much on the one September number but look more broadly at where rents have gone this year. And I would assume that next year, again, will be a little bit challenging in Q1 and Q2 because we're going to be dealing with this issue of too much supply and big discount because lease-up operator is heavily incentivized, they've got a bunch of other units, to discount and absorb apartment. And he does so by stealing from the stabilized. I think that, that dynamic is not going to change, and that will have the effect of dampening our results. However, we start building demand in February, March and we would expect that to happen. And that will temper that. So again, we try to understand these relationships and how these -- how the rents vary throughout the year and try to make the decisions and execute well around what we expect to happen.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Mike, just as a follow-up. I don't know if I missed this, but could you give a sense for where her new lease growth was in Northern California for your portfolio in the quarter and how it's trending in the fourth quarter so far?

componenttext: Sure, sure. So the -- this is John. So our new leases in the third quarter, SoCal were about 3.6%; NorCal, about 1%; and Seattle, about 5.6%. So on average, about 3% year-over-year. And we're trading we'll go to the low demand period. I don't have the current numbers. But it will trend to be able bit lighter. But one thing to remember is that last quarter or year-ago quarter, '15 was the weak quarter, so that will help the year-over-year comp.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dennis McGill from Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dennis McGill from Zelman & Associates.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one just has to do with the, I think, people are trying to get their arms around whether the supply curve peaks in '17, extends in '18. And the point others have as well that you might get more of a smoothing effect as things get delayed and pushed
componenttext: First one just has to do with the, I think, people are trying to get their arms around whether the supply curve peaks in '17, extends in '18. And the point others have as well that you might get more of a smoothing effect as things get delayed and pushed out. I guess the question you guys look at, do you feel like we end up in a different place in 2018, whether it bulks up into 2017 or gets moved out? Is there a preference in your market as far as 1 or the other? And do you think it matters as far as the end game?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mike again. I think it does matter. And I think that it's very difficult to look out too far out there because conditions change. And back to the point I was trying to make before there are no straight lines in this industry the react based on what w
componenttext: It's Mike again. I think it does matter. And I think that it's very difficult to look out too far out there because conditions change. And back to the point I was trying to make before there are no straight lines in this industry the react based on what we see happening on the market day in and day out. And again, what we see, and what we see a lot of this, with good visibility into what's going on in the development deals because of our preferred equity program where we are coming in at that 55% to 85% loan-to-cost ratio on development deals. And so we have seen a lot of deals, and we're originating these preferred equity loans on properties that we would -- that would be very consistent with the Essex portfolio. But I guess, the point is that a number of those are ready to go, development deals that don't hit yield thresholds that make them viable of the marketplace. And therefore, they are being pushed off, and they don't qualify for our program. And a lot of that is when you get into the discussion of reconciling costs, I think a lot of the land owners think that the costs are much lower than they really are when they sit down and actually price things out. And that process, I don't think it's going to change anytime soon. It's possible, for example, that the construction industry will have less -- fewer projects, and they will become more competitive from a cost standpoint, and some of these land deals will start working. But we're certainly not seeing that at this point in time. So what we have before us is a number of, let's say, half to deals that were scheduled or could come to market are actually getting done because of, again, these constraints, the cost rising issue, the city delays from being planning departments that are really busy and the impediments from conservative construction lenders. So as long as those circumstances remain in place, I think we're going to see the development pipeline moderate as we model for 2017, and you would not expect it to get any better in 2018. Hope that answered the question.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. But just to make sure I'm thinking about it right. So as it gets smoothed out, do you think that it will ultimately lead to more supply because it makes the underwriting a little bit less cautious?
componenttext: Yes, I think so. But just to make sure I'm thinking about it right. So as it gets smoothed out, do you think that it will ultimately lead to more supply because it makes the underwriting a little bit less cautious?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it's a matter of the underwriting being cautious. I think that, again, we've never seen it perform that didn't have the right numbers on it. And so we see lots of performers that have untrended cap rates for development deals in the 5 to
componenttext: No, I don't think it's a matter of the underwriting being cautious. I think that, again, we've never seen it perform that didn't have the right numbers on it. And so we see lots of performers that have untrended cap rates for development deals in the 5 to 5.25. But again, when you actually sit down with someone to price that out, it is coming out to be somewhere in the 4.5 to 4.75 range. And that pressures the numbers in terms of how much equity you need and some of the other constraints. And so -- and again, very conservative lenders, lenders that unless you have a huge balance sheet that are somewhere in the 55% to 60% loan-to-cost ratio, et cetera. So I don't see that changing. I don't see construction cost moderation happening in the very short term. Again, if developers become -- or if developers become less busy -- I'm sorry, contractors become less busy and costs go down, then maybe some of these deals will make it through. But again, right now, I feel pretty confident in our forecast in terms of first half of '17 being a bit heavy and then abating each quarter throughout '17 and the second half of the year being much better. So I feel very confident in that. Although, again, like we've seen before, there could be some movement of projects from quarter-to-quarter as delays and other things happen.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then you did mention a preferred equity program. Can you just give us an update on how you see that pipeline? It seems this quarter was origination quarter and heavy relative to the outlook that you gave last quarter. Are you see
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then you did mention a preferred equity program. Can you just give us an update on how you see that pipeline? It seems this quarter was origination quarter and heavy relative to the outlook that you gave last quarter. Are you seeing more opportunity or that opportunity to expand?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the -- what I'd say about that is we're $186 million outstanding, and we did 2 deals that funded a few million dollars this quarter. We have a pipeline of around $50 million. But in talking to our team there, they are, again, seeing a lot of
componenttext: Yes, I think the -- what I'd say about that is we're $186 million outstanding, and we did 2 deals that funded a few million dollars this quarter. We have a pipeline of around $50 million. But in talking to our team there, they are, again, seeing a lot of deals that just they can't make work. And so, it is not like we have 30 deals and we're picking the best of them. It's more like we're looking at a lot of deals and somewhere around half of them may consent with the other half are, again, not producing the returns one would normally expect if you're going to take development risks. And I would that's against the context of working through an acquisition. An acquisition, you can lock in somewhere around a 4.5 cap rate with 7-year loan in around 3% range. You have a huge amount of positive leverage. So I guess, I would say, why want to take all the development risk when there's so much positive leverage on existing acquisition, all things being equal? I think that the alternatives with respect to where capital gets allocated are pretty interesting. And it means that development deals, it can't flow into the development deals at lower yields because there's another alternative out there that is better economic and certainly the risk reward.

componenttext: Well, as you may recall, we have a $250 million program in place. And we've always been opportunistic when it comes to capital allocation. And so we plan to continue to do so. And so we had a small purchase but not enough as it relates to subsequent advances. So just a very small amount. And like I said, we'll just continue to be opportunistic on that front.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And I guess, where the stock is trading today, how do you evaluate that as opportunity against your overall investment set?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we liked it better yesterday. It was interesting. I mean, the one thing I would add that is a continual conversation between [indiscernible] and me is that it isn't like we can sell our whole portfolio, primarily because of Prop. 13 tax planning,
componenttext: I think we liked it better yesterday. It was interesting. I mean, the one thing I would add that is a continual conversation between [indiscernible] and me is that it isn't like we can sell our whole portfolio, primarily because of Prop. 13 tax planning, et cetera. We have somewhere around $1 billion we can sell relatively easily and either pay a special dividend and/or buy shares back. We don't really care about which of those we might want to do. But I guess, the point is there some assets, that are many assets that we've had huge gains on and there's a large Prop. 13 difference between what we pay as property taxes and what the buyer pays as property taxes. And then the buyer will cap out that difference and get a lower value. So there's something -- there is a headwind in California to large-scale dispositions and repurchase transactions. And so we have essentially gone through our portfolio and categorized them by type. And so we have a list of assets that we know we can sell. We have a [indiscernible] portfolio. We have an opportunistic sale portfolio. And again, we're just trying to get relationships right. But we're not going to do it if it has a very small impact. We'd much rather wait for opportunity to see meaningful differences between the value of the real estate portfolio and the value of the share. And so we're going to be patient on that. As Angela said, we did execute on the repurchase. And so that'd give you some idea that we're interested in it and following through.

componenttext: That's really helpful. And just one last one for me. I think you mentioned the aggregate loss-to-lease figure earlier on the call, but I was wondering if you can provide that between your 3 portfolio segments.

componenttext: Yes, sure. This is John Burkart. So the aggregate, as we said, is about 1.9%. And that breaks down with Southern Cal at about 3.4%; the Bay Area, with a slight gain [indiscernible] at this point in time, about 40 basis points; and then Seattle at about 2.6%.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Hightower from Evercore ISI.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So another sort of twist on the loss-to-lease question. And I don't know if you can answer this readily on this call, but I'm trying to get a sense of what loss-to-lease has represented them in terms of Essex's outperformance in terms of your rent growth
componenttext: So another sort of twist on the loss-to-lease question. And I don't know if you can answer this readily on this call, but I'm trying to get a sense of what loss-to-lease has represented them in terms of Essex's outperformance in terms of your rent growth versus the market trend growth or your competitor's rent growth over the past couple of years. If you could attribute that outperformance to loss-to-lease, if you could attribute part of it to the revenue management. Just trying to get a sense of the split there, again, attribution of outperformance, I guess.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. I'll take a shot at it. Mike wants to follow. Ultimately, loss-to-lease is the product of rent growth, right? it's asset-by-asset in the marketplace and are reinvesting in the right locations? What's the rent growth look like? And the l
componenttext: Yes, this is John. I'll take a shot at it. Mike wants to follow. Ultimately, loss-to-lease is the product of rent growth, right? it's asset-by-asset in the marketplace and are reinvesting in the right locations? What's the rent growth look like? And the loss-to-lease drives by what we actually rent at versus where the market's at. So at Essex, we had very strong markets. As Mike has said many times on the call, as we had a self-imposed rent cap that we put in, that's basically 10%. That has plus the market strength has led to loss-to-lease growth over time and over the last year. As we said earlier, about a year ago, we were about 7.2% loss-to-lease. Now we're about 1.9% loss-to-lease. So you can see that a big portion of that has rolled through to the bottom line. Does that basically answer your question?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John that's very helpful. I'll follow-up for more details. I don't want to waste everybody's time on the call here. And then my second and final question is just on Seattle. I think you guys quoted renewals running around 6% in change in the Pacific
componenttext: Yes, John that's very helpful. I'll follow-up for more details. I don't want to waste everybody's time on the call here. And then my second and final question is just on Seattle. I think you guys quoted renewals running around 6% in change in the Pacific Northwest earlier in his prepared comment. And then when I compare that to the market forecast for next year of around 4.5% and then also measuring that against around 8%, which is what you guys have done so far in 2106, I'm just wondering what all that implies in terms of new lease growth in Seattle for next year. It sounds like it should be pretty low to get the kind of those numbers when you tie it all together.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think we've laid out in our supplement, what we see is rental growth rate there at 4.6% for next year for the marketplace. As it relates to the renewals for the fourth quarter, what we say -- what we're sending out at this point in time, that's going t
componenttext: We think we've laid out in our supplement, what we see is rental growth rate there at 4.6% for next year for the marketplace. As it relates to the renewals for the fourth quarter, what we say -- what we're sending out at this point in time, that's going to be a portion of the leases in place that are there. And as you get to the fourth quarter, you're going to pull back a little bit, but we are sending out like 90 days in advance or 60 to 90 days in advance. So the renewals are very strong. I won't look at that as saying the market is not strong.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- let me add some quickly to that. In Seattle, we have 2 couple of things that are happening. So we have supply in '16 estimated at 9,800 units. This is multifamily. So we have that increasing to about 10,900 units. And we have job growth deceler
componenttext: I think -- let me add some quickly to that. In Seattle, we have 2 couple of things that are happening. So we have supply in '16 estimated at 9,800 units. This is multifamily. So we have that increasing to about 10,900 units. And we have job growth decelerating from 3.5 to 2.7. Now will that happen exactly like that? I'm not sure. But again, our market forecast is based on a scenario, and those are the 2 key scenarios. So we have some moderation of market rent growth in Seattle. Again, this is just market rent growth on F '16. It does not include loss-to-lease.

componenttext: Yes, this is John. From our perspective, we look at that. We try to look at a variety of pieces, and that's one of them, to understand: A, do we have enough office space that's going to be available, which is layoff construction because we've got such jumps strong job growth, we have enough space for the people; and then B, is that space being leased up? In other words, are the companies making decision, real capital efficient preparing for the people? And so that's why we bring that up as somewhat as a leading indicator, confirmation of our jobs numbers.

componenttext: So Mike, to use a weird analogy, if you're aware of mood rings, if you're wearing that last year, it would be kind of a nice shade of blue, and it's now kind of brownish. I don't know if you wear a mood ring, but if you did, that would probably be the right analogy. And you're talking about a soft landing scenario in 2017. But so often, our expectations of whatever happens to the future our, it's hard to identify until they actually happen. So the point is I know you mentioned behaviors of municipalities and behaviors of lenders to kind of cut off the supply chain to some degree. But is that all that's kind of hinging on what could either pivot from being a soft landing to something materially worse than that? Because if you were to kind of just plot how your view has changed over the past year, it would suggest that it's going to be something worse than a soft landing in 2017.

componenttext: Well, Rich, only you could phrase a question like that. I appreciate it. I guess, I would, I'm not sure what color this would translate into is, I would say, we are cautiously optimistic.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Green is jealous [indiscernible]
componenttext: Green is jealous [indiscernible]

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You need to send me that wheel, the motion wheel. I think we're cautiously optimistic. We think it feels kind of like it's starting to be late cycle. And so that is one element of caution. The recent GDP report looks great, but the jobs are decelera
componenttext: Okay. You need to send me that wheel, the motion wheel. I think we're cautiously optimistic. We think it feels kind of like it's starting to be late cycle. And so that is one element of caution. The recent GDP report looks great, but the jobs are decelerating. So we see a lot of inconsistencies out there in the marketplace, and that caused us a great deal of concern. We feel pretty good about the supply projections. We spend a lot of time on them. If we miss that, it's our bad. So the broader issue, I think, is what goes on in the economy. And we're always concerned about that, and especially the last several years where we've just -- every time it seems like we're getting a little bit of a momentum, something comes out of the woodwork to knock it down. And so I guess, cautious optimism is what I would get. As it relates back to supply, just look back, so you get, what's it been? 7% to 12% rent growth in Northern California for 4 years. Guess what's going to happen. Every piece of land that's available, you can put some apartments on it. It's going to be built. And that is predictable. And so the current pipeline deliveries is really a function of the extraordinary rent growth we had over the last several years. Normally, half of those sites or some portions of the site would not have been buildable. And so -- and then this is what always seems to happen is they get delivered in a different economic environment and soften conditions furthers. So this is what causes the greater volatility of Northern California and Seattle again with better, long-term growth rates over time. So I think it's just really a function of what happened, as a function of history, again, huge rent growth, making every deal work and then having all of that, hit the development pipeline at the same time and then delivered at the same time. As you -- again, as you're looking at a development deal today versus looking at it 2 or 3 years ago, it's a completely different world out there. You don't have the expectation of rent growth that you had a couple of years ago. You don't have the financing infrastructure from the banks, especially they're becoming much more conservative. And you've got backlog in the cities and a variety of other constraints. So we feel very comfortable that we're not materially off as it relates to the current conditional and what's going to be built that comes out of this for those reasons. So again, from our perspective, it's all about the economy.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, it just seems to me that you get 12% rent growth, then you're destined to get -- have these swings, as you described. I guess, it's just maybe different this time, I don't know. But if you -- can you call back to when the year or 2 before,
componenttext: Okay. I guess, it just seems to me that you get 12% rent growth, then you're destined to get -- have these swings, as you described. I guess, it's just maybe different this time, I don't know. But if you -- can you call back to when the year or 2 before, Northern California went to heck and if you guys saw that coming as clearly? Or do you think it's just there's so much more information flow now that you just had more of an advantage to see these things coming a little bit more clearly?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, to comment, we saw the supply coming, definitely. What we missed is what's going on with the economy when the economy tanked. So we didn't see how crappy the mortgages became in 2007 and 2008. We didn't know that. And then the impact of tha
componenttext: Well, I think, to comment, we saw the supply coming, definitely. What we missed is what's going on with the economy when the economy tanked. So we didn't see how crappy the mortgages became in 2007 and 2008. We didn't know that. And then the impact of that was something that, clearly, we didn't see. We had, I think, a very good idea what the supply is going to be. But I don't really again this is where at the doubles, something to keep you awake at night because we just didn't see that asset double develop, and we didn't see it blowing up as it did. When you go back to the Internet boom bust period, we would become a lot more conservative. We were moving our portfolio pretty dramatically from Northern California to Southern California because we didn't believe in the rent and we didn't believe in sustainability. And so I actually think that we played that one pretty well. But again, did we see the magnitude of the economic sort of disaster that happened when the Internet companies exploded? No, I don't think we got that one either.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Conor Wagner from Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question is from Conor Wagner from Green Street Advisors.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you guys -- you mentioned the development leasing up and the aggressive pace or rapid pace that they had to do that. How do you guys anticipate things going when most of these lease-ups turn within a year of the development? And do you have any idea
componenttext: So as you guys -- you mentioned the development leasing up and the aggressive pace or rapid pace that they had to do that. How do you guys anticipate things going when most of these lease-ups turn within a year of the development? And do you have any idea what impact that will have on the market? Or are you trying to position yourself for that in any way?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, it's a great question. I was trying to figure out how to put that into my call comments because I think it remains to be seen. It's an enormous question. Developers, there is a limit on which they can offer concessions. And that limit, in effect, w
componenttext: Conor, it's a great question. I was trying to figure out how to put that into my call comments because I think it remains to be seen. It's an enormous question. Developers, there is a limit on which they can offer concessions. And that limit, in effect, what it does is it pressures the first renewal to a huge extent. And in essence, it becomes something that fills up their buildings quickly, sometimes with the wrong tenant. And so when their first lease renewal comes, you end up with either another concession or people that have to leave in internally large numbers. So I'm not sure exactly how that's going to play out. I think that, that has been a big problem, a lot of people that are moving into San Francisco, for example, or San Jose because they can now afford it. And even though they're relying on that 16% concession in order to make those numbers work, I think you're going to see a change because each of those newly developed apartment communities go from being a lease-up with their very unique financial equation to being a stabilized owner. And when they do, I think there's going to be a lot of people who are going to be shocked within their resident pool. In our experience, at 1 month, it's no problem. At 2 months, it begins to be a problem as it relates to your tenants base cannot generally pay market rent. And so you end up with this problem on the renewal. And when you start getting above 2 months, you end up with the real problem. And I think that we are starting to see that, as John noted in his comments, there are some 2-plus month concessions out there by the time you add free parking and a variety of other things. And I think that's going to make for a very ugly first renewal on those buildings.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the impact that'll have on your pricing power or that sounds like a net negative for owners to stabilized assets.
componenttext: And the impact that'll have on your pricing power or that sounds like a net negative for owners to stabilized assets.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think you go back to the normal supply and demand. People that can't afford it have to move into more affordable housing, which means longer commutes for them and/or double-ups. And so I think it's a good thing for us because, again, t
componenttext: I don't think so. I think you go back to the normal supply and demand. People that can't afford it have to move into more affordable housing, which means longer commutes for them and/or double-ups. And so I think it's a good thing for us because, again, they become a stabilized owner. Right now, they're disconnect is from the stabilized ownership. But that 2 different constituency with dramatically different financial objectives. So as soon as they become a stabilized owner, they're interested in generating the most rent they can, they're going to have a messy situation in dealing with the people that they let in that can't afford to pay market rent. And you're just going to see another transition within the renter pool. I think it's all better because, net-net, the places that have the properties, the best locations and the best properties will go back to having the pricing power that they normally have, whereas the secondary or tertiary areas are going to have people move into them that they will probably -- they will underperform, and the better areas will recover the 16% rent that they lost or some portion of it. So it's good for the area.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then with the diminished outlook for rent growth in the Bay Area in 2017, does that change your ability to do revenue-enhancing CapEx in the region or, yes the economics there?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then with the diminished outlook for rent growth in the Bay Area in 2017, does that change your ability to do revenue-enhancing CapEx in the region or, yes the economics there?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I am afraid it does because, again, if you're going to offer your A product to 16% discount, you're going to compress As and Bs. And the rehab premium is somewhere between the difference between the A rent and the B rent. And so your premiums that you're
componenttext: I am afraid it does because, again, if you're going to offer your A product to 16% discount, you're going to compress As and Bs. And the rehab premium is somewhere between the difference between the A rent and the B rent. And so your premiums that you're going to achieve on your rehab properties will likely change a little bit and be lower. And so from our perspective, I would expect the volume of turns in our rehab program to moderate or decline. And as we become more selective and find the markets that we can get premiums that we need in order to make the numbers work.

componenttext: A quick question on the expense growth side. Given the market forecast through the deceleration next year, is there anything you might do differently next year relative to this year in terms of maybe running linear than you normally do, earnings that you're doing specifically there?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. A couple of comments there. To the extent market gets slower, they commonly end of up spending a little bit more on marketing. So cutting back doesn't necessarily work on that spend. But we are pretty focused on procurement in Essex and
componenttext: Yes, this is John. A couple of comments there. To the extent market gets slower, they commonly end of up spending a little bit more on marketing. So cutting back doesn't necessarily work on that spend. But we are pretty focused on procurement in Essex and really refining some of our pricing and taking advantage of our larger scale here. So that's working for us at this point in time. And I think the 2 will work together and will end up in a reasonable spot. But normally, when the markets slow down, you end up spending a little bit more in marketing, and that often pushes those expenses up a little bit. And the other thing, just to note, in California, we have the minimum wage growth. So that is affecting lower-waged positions like the turnover, the landscape security. The effective lease going up at about 7.5% rate a year. It's not same each year, but effectively, that's happening for several years. So that is putting pressure upward pressure on those different areas, and we are working to offset that in the various way.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then secondly, Alameda County had posted -- it wasn't the worst but had a decent amount of sequential revenue growth deceleration. Is that a product of Alameda County just having the most robust growth last year? Or is that an indication that the new supply in downtown San Francisco, San Jose, the concessions are aggressive enough to draw from lower price points further out than the suburbs?

componenttext: Yes, it's more the latter. It benefited from people moving to out there for affordability. And now you can see the reverse of that as people start to the impact as there is not much rent pressure in San Francisco and San Jose.

componenttext: I just have one quick one. And I'm sorry if you answered this previously, but in your developments, at 500 full some [ph], I believe costs went up about $35 million. It didn't seem like any of the under underlying assumptions changed. Do you know what drove that cost increase?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do. This is Mike Schall again. The same things that we've been talking about as it relates to the broader issues and development. It was driven by delays, number one, in terms of getting through the city process and construction costs growing at double-
componenttext: I do. This is Mike Schall again. The same things that we've been talking about as it relates to the broader issues and development. It was driven by delays, number one, in terms of getting through the city process and construction costs growing at double-digit rates, which outstrip our expectation for the property. And so again, back to these conditions that are leading to lower supply, obviously, we're not immune from those conditions. And that 500 full some deal is a good example of that.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is the same thing kind of happening with the Galloway Hacienda in Pleasanton? I mean, is that part of the under the same issues there?
componenttext: And is the same thing kind of happening with the Galloway Hacienda in Pleasanton? I mean, is that part of the under the same issues there?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it really isn't because that was started a couple of years ago. So again, 500 full some, we just find the contract with the general contractor, finished up the city requirements. We hope to have done that several months ago. And again, the delays and
componenttext: No, it really isn't because that was started a couple of years ago. So again, 500 full some, we just find the contract with the general contractor, finished up the city requirements. We hope to have done that several months ago. And again, the delays and movement of cost increases are really the reason for that cost. And Hacienda was fortunately done before that. Again, this is one of the reasons why we tried to decelerate the development pipeline. At the bottom of the cycle, you end up with really good cruise because there's not much going on, cities are couple trying to burst deals through. At the top of the cycle, it's sort of the opposite. The cities are trying to increase fees, increase supportability requirements, have greater say in the product that's being built. They are less motivated to actually get construction workers back working because the construction workers is really busy. And so this is why we tail back development at the top of the cycle.

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: That's very helpful. And then just one follow-up on that. With costs up and pricing power down, how has that affect your yield assumptions on 500 full some?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here. Mike, you mentioned early in the call that the concentration of supply is contributing to the heavy concessions by developers. And I was just wondering if that concentration spreads further out. And if so, can we see that conc
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here. Mike, you mentioned early in the call that the concentration of supply is contributing to the heavy concessions by developers. And I was just wondering if that concentration spreads further out. And if so, can we see that concession start to abate before overall supply actually abates?

headline: Essex Property Trust Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. We do have some increase in Oakland, for example, in terms of development but, again, off a very small base. And we don't see that as a major issue. I think it has more to do with California's Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006 w
componenttext: That's a good question. We do have some increase in Oakland, for example, in terms of development but, again, off a very small base. And we don't see that as a major issue. I think it has more to do with California's Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006 where California is trying to create a residential model that is going verticals as opposed to horizontal and trying to eliminate urban sprawl. And the way to do that is to have high-density projects on all the major transit hubs. So what you're seeing is greater concentrations of apartment buildings and actually condos and other housing in an effort to become more efficient from an environmental perspective. And I don't think that, that changes. I think that, again, in the Bay Area, we need to go through a massive upgrade of our public transit system and -- but I think you're going to see more and more residential construction that's on the main transit lines or in the urban core. I do not think that's going to change anytime in the next several years. And I think that, that access a further supply constraint that is a  more recent phenomena.
